title: State v. Howell
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDTIAL VALUE AND SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Frederick L. Howell, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Orangeburg County
Â James C. Williams, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2007-UP-102
Submitted March 1, 2007 â€“ Filed March 6, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Chief Attorney Joseph L. Savitz, III, of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., all of Columbia; and Solicitor David M. Pascoe, Jr., of Summerville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Â Frederick L. Howell claims the trial court rendered his guilty plea conditional by informing him of his right to appeal and to file a motion for post-conviction relief.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
Howell was indicted for first-degree burglary. Â During the plea colloquy, the trial court informed Howell that in order to plead guilty he would have to give up certain rights, and he would have the right to file an appeal and the right to file a motion for post-conviction relief.Â  The trial court went on to explain that any concerns Howell had would need to be raised at that time instead of waiting until some point in the future.Â  Howell raised no concerns to the trial court and stated that he still wanted to plead guilty.Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Conditional pleas are not valid in South Carolina. â€œPleas of guilty are unconditional, and if an accused attempts to attach any condition or qualification thereto, the trial court should direct a plea of not guilty.â€Â  Â State v. Truesdale, 278 S.C. 368, 370, 296 S.E. 2d 528, 529 (1982).Â  Howell did not attempt to attach any condition to his plea.Â  In the course of the plea colloquy, the trial court simply explained his rights to him.Â  Howell did not raise and the trial court did not accept any specific argument as a condition.Â  Compare State v. Downs, 361 S.C. 141, 146, 604 S.E.2d 377, 379-80 (2004) (finding a guilty plea to be unconditional because defendant did not reserve the right to later deny his guilt); with State v. Oâ€™Leary, 302 S.C. 17, 17-18, 393 S.E.2d 186, 187 (1990) (finding a guilty plea to be conditional because the defendant reserved the right to challenge the constitutionality of a statute in relations to his plea). 
The trial courtâ€™s explanation of the right to appeal and the right to file a motion for post-conviction relief did not render Howellâ€™s plea conditional. 
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, KITTREDGE, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: State v. Jackson
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Adam Jackson, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
Â Paula H. Thomas, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-103
Submitted March 1, 2007 â€“ Filed March 6, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Chief Attorney Joseph L. Savitz, III, of Appellate Defense, Â of Columbia, for Appellant
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General Shawn L. Reeves, Office of the Attorney General, of Columbia; and Solicitor John Gregory Hembree, of Conway, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Adam Jackson appeals his conviction for voluntary manslaughter.Â  Jackson argues the trial court erred by suppressing evidence that the victim possessed cocaine.Â  We affirm.[1]  
FACTS
On May 21, 2004, Jackson shot and killed Jessie Grissette.Â  Jackson testified that he shot in self-defense after Grissette ran up behind him, threatened to kill him, and began reaching for something in his pocket.Â  Jackson testified that he believed Grissette was reaching for a gun because he had previously seen Grissette with a gun, and during the altercation, Grissette told him he had a gun.Â Â  
In Grissetteâ€™s wallet, the police found a small sandwich baggy containing a â€œwhite powder substance.â€[2]Â  However, while the toxicology report from Grissetteâ€™s autopsy was positive for marijuana and showed a blood alcohol content of more than twice the legal limit for driving while intoxicated, there was no cocaine detected.Â Â Â Â  Â 
Prior to trial, the State moved to exclude any evidence concerning the white powder.Â  The trial court asked Jacksonâ€™s counsel what the relevance of the white powder would be considering no cocaine was found in Grissetteâ€™s system, and counsel was unable to offer any direct reasons for its relevance. After Jacksonâ€™s counsel stated that Grissette had allegedly previously robbed Jacksonâ€™s home to obtain money Â for drugs, the trial court stated the white powder evidence would be inadmissible unless this or other evidence â€œties him in enough that it becomes relevant.â€[3]Â Â  
During the trial, a police officer testified on cross-examination regarding the white powder substance found on Grissette.Â  After the officerâ€™s testimony had been completed and the jury was removed from the courtroom for a break, the State cited the in limine decision and moved to strike the testimony concerning the white powder substance.Â  The trial court granted this motion over defense counselâ€™s objection and instructed the jury accordingly.Â  
The jury convicted Jackson of voluntary manslaughter, and the trial court sentenced him to ten years imprisonment.Â  This appeal followed. Â Â 
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Timeliness
Jackson first asserts that the trial court erred in granting the Stateâ€™s motion to strike the white powder evidence because it was untimely.Â  We disagree. 
While a motion to strike may be denied due to the absence of a contemporaneous objection, the ultimate determination lies in the discretion of the court.Â  Lindsey v. City of Greenville, 247 S.C. 232, 241, 146 S.E.2d 863, 868 (1966).Â  Counsel for the State explained no objection was made at the time of the testimony because he did not wish to draw additional attention to the improper testimony.Â  The trial court accepted this reasoning and specifically found the motion to strike was timely.Â  We find no abuse of discretion.
II.Â  Preservation and Res Gestae Â  
Jackson argues the trial court erred in suppressing evidence of the white powder substance.Â  We find this argument is not preserved for appellate review.
Jacksonâ€™s argument on appeal is that the mere possession of cocaine alters the brain chemistry of its owner.Â  Regardless of the merit of this argument, it is an argument which Jackson never made to the trial court.Â  â€œArguments
not raised to or ruled upon by the trial court are not preserved for appellate review.â€Â  State v. Carlson, 363 S.C. 586, 597, 611 S.E.2d 283, 288 (Ct. App. 2005).
Lastly, Jackson argues the trial court erred in suppressing the white powder evidence because it was part of the res gestae of the incident.Â  Jackson never specifically mentioned res gestae to the trial court, but did note that the white powder evidence was relevant in terms of the â€œtotalityâ€ of the incident.Â  Regardless of this potential preservation issue, we find this argument is without merit.
An accepted basis for admitting evidence of other crimes arises when such evidence â€œfurnishes part of the context of the crimeâ€ or is necessary to a â€œfull presentationâ€
of the case.Â  State v. Sweat, 362 S.C. 117, 132-33, 606 S.E.2d 508, 516 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  â€œThe
res  gestae theory recognizes evidence of other bad acts may be an integral part of the crime with which the defendant is charged, or may be needed to aid the fact finder in understanding the context in which the crime occurred.â€Â  Id. at 133, 606 S.E.2d at 517 (quoting State v. King, 334 S.C. 504, 512, 514 S.E.2d 578, 582 (1999)).Â  
We find no error with the trial courtâ€™s determination that the white powder evidence was irrelevant.Â  Because there is no evidence that this incident between Grissette and Jackson was in any way related to cocaine, the record supports a decision that the white powder evidence was not necessary to complete the story of the crime on trial.Â  
CONCLUSION
We find Jacksonâ€™s issue concerning cocaine possession affecting the brain chemistry of its owner is not preserved for our review.Â  Regarding Jacksonâ€™s other issues, we find no abuse of discretion in the trial courtâ€™s suppression of evidence.Â  Based on the foregoing, Jacksonâ€™s conviction is
 AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, KITTREDGE, and SHORT JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] Although Jackson states that victim possessed cocaine and the lawyers refer to the powder as cocaine, there is no evidence in the record that this white powder substance was analyzed and found to be cocaine.Â  Therefore, this court will not refer to the white powder substance as cocaine.Â  
[3] Neither the evidence suggested by Jackson nor any other evidence which rendered the â€œwhite powderâ€ relevant was presented by Jackson.

title: Jordan v. Martin
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Michelle Jordan, Appellant,
v.
Cecelia Martin and Lonnie Martin, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â J. Ernest Kinard, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-104
Submitted March 1, 2007 â€“ Filed March 6, 2007

DISMISSED


  
    
      
Charles Dennis Aughtry, of Columbia, for Appellant
E. Dale Lang, Jr., of Columbia, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â Â Â  Michelle Jordan appeals the trial courtâ€™s denial of her motion for a new trial absolute.Â  Jordan asserts the introduction of evidence concerning insurance coverage entitled her to a new trial under Rules 403 and 411, SCRE.Â  We find Jordanâ€™s arguments on appeal are not preserved for our review.
FACTS
On May 14, 2004, Michelle Jordan was involved in a car accident wherein her vehicle was â€œrear-endedâ€ by Lonnie Martinâ€™s vehicle.Â  As a result of the injuries Jordan suffered in this accident, she brought a personal injury suit against Martin alleging negligence.Â  
During the trial, Jordan was asked by Martinâ€™s counsel:Â  â€œMs. Jordan, how much time did you spend out at the scene of the accident that day?â€Â  Jordan responded in pertinent part:Â  â€œThen he [police officer] got something in his car and called the insurance company I guess to verify that we both had insurance, so while he was doing that we were standing out there.â€[1]Â Â  Â 
After over an hour of deliberations, the jury foreman returned to the courtroom and submitted six handwritten questions to the trial court.Â  These six questions included two questions regarding insurance coverage of the parties and whether any bills had already been paid and by whom.Â  After conferring with the attorneys, the trial court responded by instructing the foreman that there was either â€œno testimony on the issuesâ€ asked about or that â€œan answer to the question would be irrelevant to the issues involved.â€Â  The court further instructed the foreman to â€œdecide the case based upon the admitted evidence.â€Â  
After almost an additional hour of deliberations, the jury returned a verdict in favor of Jordan and awarded her $713.00 in damages.Â  Jordan moved for additur seeking an amount between five and ten thousand dollars or a new trial in the alternative, and the court agreed to take the motions under advisement.Â  In the week following the jury verdict, the court held a hearing to address Jordanâ€™s motions.Â  The court denied Jordanâ€™s motion for a new trial absolute and granted a one thousand dollar additur.[2]Â  This appeal followed.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Jordan asserts the introduction of evidence concerning insurance coverage entitled her to a new trial under Rules 403 and 411, SCRE.Â  We find Jordanâ€™s arguments on appeal are not preserved for our review.
â€œA contemporaneous objection is necessary in all trials beginning after the date of this opinion to properly preserve errors for our direct appellate review.â€[3]Â  State v. Evans, 371 S.C. 27, 31, 637 S.E.2d 313, 315 (2006) (quoting State v. Torrence, 305 S.C. 45, 69, 406 S.E.2d 315, 328 (1991)).Â  A partyâ€™s failure to object at the time evidence is offered constitutes a waiver of the right to object.Â  Doe v. S.B.M., 327 S.C. 352, 356, 488 S.E.2d 878, 880 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  â€œOur courts have held a failure to contemporaneously object to the introduction of evidence claimed to be prejudicial cannot be later bootstrapped by a motion for a mistrial.â€Â  State v. Stanley, 365 S.C. 24, 33, 615 S.E.2d 455, 459 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  Logically flowing from this precedent is the notion that a motion for a new trial cannot cure the failure to contemporaneously object.
After Jordanâ€™s testimony reflecting insurance coverage, her counsel failed to contemporaneously object.Â  Jordanâ€™s counsel further failed to object to the trial courtâ€™s instruction to the jury after the jury foreman presented questions concerning insurance.Â  In fact, the record fails to indicate any objection to this testimony by Jordanâ€™s counsel until after the jury rendered its verdict.Â  Any argument on appeal based upon Jordanâ€™s interjection of insurance coverage is not properly preserved for our review.Â  Since both of Jordanâ€™s arguments on appeal are based on this issue, we must dismiss this appeal.[4]Â  Â Â 
CONCLUSION
We find this appeal is not preserved for our review. Based on the foregoing, Jordanâ€™s appeal is
 DISMISSED.[5]
ANDERSON, KITTREDGE, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] We note the trial courtâ€™s order states that Jordan made these unsolicited comments concerning insurance coverage despite a pre-trial instruction from the court not to mention insurance.Â  Although it does not appear in the record, Martin asserts in his brief that this instruction from the court was prompted by his motion in limine requesting such instruction.Â Â  
[2] The granting of this motion allowed for Martin to accept the additur or to request a new trial.Â  There is nothing in the record to indicate Martinâ€™s unwillingness to accept the additur.Â  
[3] We are mindful of the very limited exception to the contemporaneous objection rule carved out in Toyota of Florence v. Lynch, 314 S.C. 257, 442 S.E.2d 611 (1994).Â  However, in this case, we find neither a vicious, inflammatory argument resulting in clear prejudice nor otherwise â€œextraordinaryâ€ circumstances which would be necessary to excuse Jordanâ€™s failure to make a
contemporaneous objection under this exception.
[4] We recognize Martinâ€™s argument concerning the trial courtâ€™s failure to include in its order â€œcompelling reasonsâ€ for invading the province of the jury and awarding additur.Â  Regardless of the merits of this argument, the trial courtâ€™s decision regarding additur was never appealed by either party.Â  Jordan appealed only from the denial of her motion for a new trial absolute, and Martin did not appeal.Â  Therefore, this issue is not properly before this court.
[5] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Robert Samuel Eakes, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â C. Victor Pyle, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-105
Submitted March 1, 2007 â€“ Filed March 6, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Appellate Defender Eleanor Duffy Cleary, South Carolina Commission on Indigent Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General Deborah R. J. Shupe, Office of the Attorney General, of Columbia; and Solicitor Robert M. Ariail, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Robert Samuel Eakes appeals his convictions for kidnapping, assault and battery of a high and aggravated nature, and malicious injury to real property.Â  We affirm.[1]  
Eakes argues the trial court erred in commenting on the facts of the case when charging the jury on kidnapping.Â  â€œIt is elementary that in the course of the trial of a criminal case, the trial [court] must refrain from all comment which tends to indicate his opinion as to the weight or sufficiency of evidence, the credibility of witnesses, the guilt of the accused, or as to the controverted facts.â€Â  State v. Kennedy, 272 S.C. 231, 234, 250 S.E.2d 338, 339 (1978).Â  The trial court issued the following charge:

Now, with respect to kidnapping, section 16-3-920 says that whoever shall unlawfully seize, confine, inveigle, decoy, kidnap, abduct or carry away any other person by any means whatsoever without authority of law shall be guilty of a felony.Â  So kidnapping is the taking and carrying away of a person from one place to another however slight by unlawful force or by fraud or against that personâ€™s will.
With respect to proving kidnapping, the State must prove, first of all, that there was an intent to violate the law in this case to kidnap the victim.Â  Second, the taking by the person from one place to another, that is, from one place in the house to another or from one place in the house to another location, it makes no difference because it is the fact of removal and not the distance that constitutes kidnapping. 

(emphasis added).Â  Eakes argues the trial court committed reversible error in mentioning kidnapping can include moving a person â€œfrom one place in the house to another location,â€ because the facts of the case involved Eakes moving the victim from one place in a house to another.
The trial court expressed no opinion whatsoever.Â  The trial court did not make an untoward comment on the facts of the case, but simply posited a generic illustration of a legal principle.Â  The trial court merely explicated the legal concept that kidnapping can occur in a house, because kidnapping is based on the removal of a person from one place to another rather than the distance a person is removed.Â Â  
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, KITTREDGE, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: State v. Hollis
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Kevin Chance Hollis, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal from Spartanburg County
Roger L. Couch, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-106
Submitted March 1, 2007 â€“ Filed March 6, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Appellate Defender Aileen P. Clare, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General Shawn L. Reeves, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Harold W. Gowdy, III, of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIUM:Â  Hollis appeals his conviction for malicious injury to personal property, unlawfully carrying a pistol, and discharging a firearm into a dwelling.Â  Hollis contends the trial judge erred in denying his motion to suppress witness identifications.Â  We affirm.[1]
Facts
In the early morning hours of March 22, 2003, security officer Robert Moore, who was working in the parking lot of Club Matrix, escorted two men to their car and asked them to leave the premises.Â  Moore was with the men for about four to six minutes.Â  He observed the men closely so that he could recognize them in the event they attempted to return to the club.Â  As they were leaving, one of the men began shooting at the club.Â  The shooting continued as the men sped away.Â  Approximately three and one-half hours after the shooting, Moore identified Hollis as one of the two men he had escorted from the club.Â  Additionally, Moore identified the vehicle as the one involved in the incident.Â  Moore later testified he was one hundred percent certain of his identification.
Hollis was arrested and charged with malicious injury to personal property, unlawfully carrying a pistol, and discharging a firearm into a dwelling.Â  At Hollisâ€™s trial Moore again identified Hollis as the man he escorted to the vehicle the night of the shooting.Â  Defense counsel moved to suppress both of Mooreâ€™s identifications.Â  The trial judge denied the motion. 
Officers recovered spent nine-millimeter shell casings from the roadway near Club Matrix.Â  Inside the vehicle officers found unspent nine-millimeter bullets, spent nine-millimeter shell cases, and a box that held nine-millimeter bullets.Â  A firearms expert testified the spent shell casings found at the crime scene and inside the vehicle were fired by a handgun found on Hollis at the time of his arrest.Â  Elements consistent with gunshot residue were found on the palm and back of Hollisâ€™s left hand.Â  Possible gunshot residue was found on the palm and back of Hollisâ€™s right hand. Â 
The jury found Hollis guilty on all charges and the trial judge sentenced him to concurrent terms of confinement totaling ten years, suspended to eight yearsâ€™ confinement and eight yearsâ€™ probation.Â  
Standard of Review
In criminal cases, the appellate court sits to review errors of law only. Â State v. Baccus, 367 S.C. 41, 625 S.E.2d 216 (2006); State v. Wood, 362 S.C. 520, 608 S.E.2d 435 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  On appeal, we are limited to determining whether the trial judge abused his discretion. Â State v. Reed, 332 S.C. 35, 503 S.E.2d 747 (1998); State v. Walker, 366 S.C. 643, 623 S.E.2d 122 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  This same standard of review applies to preliminary factual findings in determining the admissibility of certain evidence in criminal cases.Â  State v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 545 S.E.2d 827 (2001).Â  The appellate court does not re-evaluate the facts based on its own view of the preponderance of the evidence but simply determines whether the trial judgeâ€™s ruling is supported by any evidence.Â  Id.Â  In order for an error of law to warrant reversal, the error must result in prejudice to the appellant. Â State v. Patterson, 367 S.C. 219, 625 S.E.2d 239 (Ct. App. 2006); see State v. Beck, 342 S.C. 129, 536 S.E.2d 679 (2000).
Discussion
Hollis argues the trial judge erred in denying his motion to suppress the unreliable witness identifications.Â  We disagree.
Generally, the decision to admit eyewitness identifications is in the trial judgeâ€™s discretion and will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of that discretion or the commission of prejudicial legal error.Â  State v. Brown, 356 S.C. 496, 589 S.E.2d 781 (Ct. App. 2003) (citing State v. Moore, 343 S.C. 282, 540 S.E.2d 445 (2000)).Â  However, a criminal defendant may be deprived of due process of law by an identification procedure that is unnecessarily suggestive.Â  Id. (citing State v. Patterson, 337 S.C. 215, 522 S.E.2d 845 (Ct. App. 1999)).Â  â€œWhile a showup in which a witness views a single suspect is generally suggestive, and hence suspect or disfavored, and less preferable than a lineup, even if requested by accused, a showup may be proper in some circumstances.â€Â  Brown, 356 S.C. at 503, 589 S.E.2d at 785 (quoting State v. Mansfield, 343 S.C. 66, 78, 538 S.E.2d 257, 263 (Ct. App. 2000) (internal citations omitted)); see also Neil v. Biggers, 409 U.S. 188 (1972); State v. Blassingame, 338 S.C. 240, 525 S.E.2d 535 (Ct. App. 1999)).Â  
It is well settled that reliability is the linchpin in determining the admissibility of identifications and suggestiveness alone does not mandate the exclusion of evidence. Â Brown, 356 S.C. at 504, 589 S.E.2d at 785 (citing Manson v. Brathwaite, 432 U.S. 98 (1977); State v. Stewart, 275 S.C. 447, 272 S.E.2d 628 (1980); Blassingame, 338 S.C. at 251, 525 S.E.2d at 541); Patterson, 337 S.C. at 229, 522 S.E.2d at 852). Â To determine whether an identification is reliable, it is necessary to consider the following factors: (1) the opportunity of the witness to view the criminal at the time of the crime; (2) the witnessâ€™s degree of attention; (3) the accuracy of the witnessâ€™s prior description of the criminal; (4) the level of certainty demonstrated by the witness at the confrontation; and (5) the amount of time between the crime and the confrontation.Â  Id. Â (citing Mansfield, 343 S.C. at 78-79, 538 S.E.2d at 263); Biggers, 409 U.S. at 199-200). Â The corrupting effect of a suggestive identification is to be weighed against these factors. See Mansfield, 343 S.C. at 79, 538 S.E.2d at 263. Â After the trial judge determines the witnessâ€™s identification is reliable, the witness is permitted to testify before the jury. Â Id.
Notwithstanding the generally suggestive nature of the identification procedure employed by police in this case, Mooreâ€™s identification of Hollis was reliable in light of the totality of the circumstances.Â  The following excerpt from the record indicates the trial judge considered the relevant factors in determining the reliability of Mooreâ€™s identification:

The factors being considered by this court to determine whether or not the identification in this case is reliable include the witnessâ€™ opportunity to view the subject at the time of the events, the degree of attention paid by the witness to the individual being identified, the accuracy of the witnessâ€™ prior description of the criminal, the witnessâ€™ level of certainty at the time of the actual confrontation, and the length of time between the crime and the confrontation. . . .
In this case the witness testified that he had an excellent opportunity to view the individual that he was attempting to identify.Â  Because of the circumstances of their initial confrontation, he stated that he paid closer attention to these individuals than normal.Â  He said that he got a good idea of what they were wearing, as well as their person.Â  He saw them on that occasion and then say the individual again while being fired upon.Â  And certainly those circumstances would cause someone to pay very close attention to what was going on at that time. 
The show-up identification, he stated that his certainty of his identification at one hundred percent at that time.Â  And certainly that indicates that he felt very strongly concerning his identification as being correct and independent at that time. 

The witness had an extended opportunity to view Hollis while escorting him from Club Matrix, he paid close attention in the event Hollis attempted re-entry into the club, he generally described the men to the authorities, he testified he was one hundred percent certain that he made the correct identification, and he identified Hollis within approximately three and one-half hours after the shooting incident. Â The trial judge concluded the reliability factors weighed in favor of allowing Mooreâ€™s identification testimony.Â  We discern no abuse of discretion in the trial judgeâ€™s ruling. 
Alternatively, we consider any error in the trial judgeâ€™s conclusion concerning the identification harmless.Â  No definite rule of law governs finding an error harmless; rather, the materiality and prejudicial character of the error must be determined from its relationship to the entire case.Â  State v. Reeves, 301 S.C. 191, 391 S.E.2d 241 (1990); State v. Curry, 370 S.C. 674, 636 S.E.2d 649 (Ct. App. 2006)). Â Whether an error is harmless depends on the particular facts of each case.Â  State v. Mizzell, 349 S.C. 326, 333, 563 S.E.2d 315, 318-19 (2002) (quoting Delaware v. Van Arsdall, 475 U.S. 673, 684 (1986)).Â  â€œ[T]he reviewing court must review the entire record to determine what effect the error had on the verdict.â€ Â Mizzell, 349 S.C. at 334, 563 S.E.2d at 319 (internal quotations omitted).Â  Error is harmless where it could not reasonably have affected the result of the trial. Â In re Harvey, 355 S.C. 53, 584 S.E.2d 893 (2003).Â  When guilt is conclusively proven by competent evidence, such that no other rational conclusion could be reached, this court will not set aside conviction for insubstantial errors not affecting result.Â  State v. Kelley, 319 S.C. 173, 460 S.E.2d 368 (1995).
The in-court identification of Hollis was cumulative to the evidence presented at trial.Â  Hollis was apprehended near Club Matrix shortly after the shooting.Â  He was carrying the pistol that was later found to be the one used in the shooting, and he had gunshot residue on one of his hands. Â The vehicle the suspects fled in contained spent shell cases that had been fired by the handgun found on Hollis at the time of his arrest.
Accordingly, Hollisâ€™s conviction is affirmed.
 ANDERSON , KITTREDGE, AND SHORT, JJ., concur.

text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Patrick and Vivian Henry Appellants,
v.
Michael Tucker Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Anderson County
J. Cordell Maddox, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-107
Submitted March 1, 2007 â€“ Filed March 6, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Patrick and Vivian Henry, of Salem, Pro Se, for Appellants.
David J. Brousseau, of Anderson, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  Â Patrick and Vivian Henry appeal the circuit courtâ€™s order upholding the decision of the magistrateâ€™s court. Â We affirm.[1]
FACTS
This matter involves a contract dispute between landowners Patrick and Vivian Henry (hereinafter collectively referred to as â€œHenryâ€) and landscaper Michael Tucker.Â  As a result of their disagreement, Henry brought suit against Tucker in the Anderson County Magistrateâ€™s Court for breach of contract and breach of warranty.Â  Tucker counterclaimed, alleging fraud, constructive fraud, and unjust enrichment.Â  
In his original decision, the magistrate found Tucker had breached the warranty on his work and awarded Henry $2,694.00 in damages.Â  However, the court found Henry had attempted to rely on his own oral modifications to the original contract, and based upon that, as well as the equitable theory of unjust enrichment, found Tucker was entitled to damages from Henry in the amount of $2,612.00.Â  The magistrate found Tucker suffered additional damages of $82.00 as a result of delays Henry had caused.Â  This ultimately resulted in what the magistrate referred to as â€œa wash,â€ with neither party owing further compensation to the other. 
After the magistrate rendered his decision, Tucker asked that the court reconsider its decision.Â  Although never phrasing his request as a â€œMotion for Reconsideration,â€ Tucker stated: â€œMay I just bring a point, your Honor, just by way of the Courtâ€™s ruling,â€ and noted that although the court found Henry caused the project to be delayed, the magistrate failed to adequately assess the damages caused by the delays.Â  Henry filed a written motion to reconsider, arguing the court had not properly considered the damages caused by Tuckerâ€™s failure to adhere to the contractâ€™s requirements.Â  After holding a hearing on these issues, the court agreed with both movants, and the relevant damages were reassessed.Â  However, the ultimate result was the same, with neither party receiving a monetary award as a result of set-off. 
Henry appealed to the circuit court.Â  The circuit court judge affirmed the magistrateâ€™s decision.
DISCUSSION
The standard of review to be applied by a circuit court in an appeal from a magistrateâ€™s judgment is prescribed by the South Carolina Code:

Upon hearing the appeal the appellate court shall give judgment according to the justice of the case, without regard to technical errors and defects which do not affect the merits. In giving judgment the court may affirm or reverse the judgment of the court below, in whole or in part, as to any or all the parties and for errors of law or fact.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 18-7-170 (1985).Â  This standard, and the standard applicable to this court when reviewing the circuit courtâ€™s decision, were discussed extensively in Hadfield v. Gilchrist, 343 S.C. 88, 92-94, 538 S.E.2d 268, 270-71 (Ct. App. 2000):

In Burns v. Wannamaker, 281 S.C. 352, 315 S.E.2d 179 (Ct.App.1984), this Court amplified:
  
As is readily apparent, Section 18-7-170 confers authority upon the Circuit Court to reverse a magistrateâ€™s findings of fact when exercising appellate jurisdiction in an appeal from a magistrateâ€™s judgment. See Dingle v. Northwestern R. Co., 112 S.C. 390, 99 S.E. 828 (1919); Redfearn v. Douglass, 35 S.C. 569, 15 S.E. 244 (1892); cf. Vacation Time of Hilton Head Island, Inc. v. Kiwi Corp., [280 S.C. 232], 312 S.E.2d 20 (Ct. App. 1984) (where the Circuit Court reversed a magistrate's findings of fact in an ejectment action).
  
Burns, 281 S.C. at 357, 315 S.E.2d at 182.
While the Circuit Court maintains a broad scope of review, our standard is more limited:
  
[T]he Court of Appeals will presume that an affirmance by a Circuit Court of a magistrateâ€™s judgment was made upon the merits where the testimony is sufficient to sustain the judgment of the magistrate and there are no facts that show the affirmance was influenced by an error of law [Bagnal v. Southern Express Co., 106 S.C. 395, 400, 91 S.E. 334, 335-36 (1917); Stanford v. Cudd, 93 S.C. 367, 369-70, 76 S.E. 986, 986-87 (1913); see 5B C.J.S. Appeal & Error Â§ 1817 at 152-53 (1958)] . . . .
  
Burns, 281 S.C. at 357, 315 S.E.2d at 182. Our Supreme Court, in Stanford v. Cudd, 93 S.C. 367, 76 S.E. 986 (1913), held that where the testimony is sufficient to sustain a judgment of the magistrateâ€™s court, and it is affirmed on appeal to the Circuit Court, this Court will assume the Circuit Court affirmed the judgment on the merits, in the absence of facts showing the affirmance was controlled or affected by errors of law. The Court enunciated:
  
In obedience to the statute [S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 18-7-170], the circuit court might have concluded that the magistrate erred in refusing some or all of the defendantâ€™s requests, or in admitting some or all of the testimony objected to by defendant, but the court might have thought, upon consideration of the case on the merits, that, notwithstanding such errors, the plaintiff was entitled to judgment; and as there was evidence which would have warranted such a conclusion, and as we cannot say that the judgment was affected or controlled by any error of law, it must be affirmed.
  
Stanford, 93 S.C. at 370, 76 S.E. at 987.
The rule is articulated in Price v. Charleston & W.C. Ry., 93 S.C. 576, 77 S.E. 703 (1913):
  
As the circuit court is required to give judgment, in such cases, according to the justice of the case, without regard to technical errors and defects, which do not affect the merits [S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 18-7-170], and as the record does not disclose the grounds upon which the court rendered its judgment, we must assume that it was rested upon some sound and meritorious ground, and sustain it, if the record discloses any such ground.
  
Price, 93 S.C. at 578, 77 S.E. at 703.

In his appeal to this court, Henry cites a number of issues for which he believes the evidence presented before the magistrate was insufficient to sustain the courtâ€™s factual findings.Â  We disagree. Â 
In an action at law, on appeal of a case tried without a jury, the findings of fact of the judge will not be disturbed unless found to be without evidence which reasonably supports the judgeâ€™s findings.Â  Townes Associates, Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976).Â Â  â€œUnless we find an error of law, we will affirm the judgeâ€™s holding if there are any facts supporting his decision.â€Â  Hadfield, 343 S.C at 94, 538 S.E.2d at 271.Â  With each of the issues he cites, Henry fails to point out any errors of law that occurred during the trial.Â  Furthermore, the record is far from devoid of evidence to support the magistrateâ€™s decision.Â  The circuit court correctly affirmed the decision of the magistrate, who was in the best position to judge the credibility of the testimony and evidence presented.
Henry avers the decision should be reversed because Tucker failed to formally reference his argument at the close of trial as a â€œmotion to reconsider.â€Â  Again, we disagree.Â  
This argument is precisely what S.C. Code 18-7-170 was intended to avoid.Â  Technical rules of procedure are not applicable in magistrateâ€™s court.Â  Wimberly v. Shorter, 204, S.C. 558, 30 S.E.2d 593, 594 (1944).Â  In the magistrateâ€™s court, pleadings, except as otherwise provided, may be oral or written, and may be in any particular form so long as they enable a person of common understanding to know what is intended.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 22-3-190 (1989).Â  
At the close of the trial, Tucker orally moved that the magistrate reconsider his ruling on the basis that the court had not assigned the appropriate monetary value to the delays Henry had caused.Â  Although Tuckerâ€™s trial counsel did not specifically use the technical words â€œmotion to reconsider,â€ it is apparent that Tucker was requesting the magistrate reconsider this issue when rendering his decision.Â  
Henry subsequently filed a written motion to reconsider the magistrateâ€™s decision.Â  At the motion hearing, the magistrate allowed Tucker to argue the issue regarding the appropriate valuation of damages resulting from Henryâ€™s delays.Â  The court specifically found that Tuckerâ€™s trial counsel had presented this issue for argument at the close of trial and was treating the same as a motion to reconsider.Â  There was no error in finding Henry had moved for reconsideration.
CONCLUSION 
Accordingly, the decision of the circuit court is
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, KITTREDGE, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
v.
Harold Justice, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Larry R. Patterson, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-108
Submitted March 1, 2007 â€“ Filed March 6, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Chief Attorney Joseph L. Savitz, III, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General Shawn L. Reeves, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Robert M. Ariail, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Harold Justice appeals his guilty plea for common law robbery and failure to stop for a blue light.Â  He contends the trial judge erred in denying his motion to dismiss court-appointed counsel and to proceed pro se.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
At approximately 12:40 a.m. on November 1, 2004, Justice entered a Hot Spot convenience store on Augusta Road in Greenville. Â After all of the other customers had left the store, Justice purchased a bottle of chocolate milk.Â  He then went to the candy aisle, selected four packages of Reeseâ€™s Pieces, and then walked back to the cash register.Â  When the clerk opened the register, Justice reached over the counter, told the clerk that this was a robbery, and then proceeded to take three ten dollar bills out of the cash drawer.Â  During the course of the robbery, the clerk activated a panic button which alerted law enforcement.Â  
As Justice left the scene on a motorcycle, the clerk called 911 and gave a very detailed description of Justice.Â  Officer Little, who was on patrol in the nearby area, received the dispatched information regarding the robbery.Â  Officer Little observed a motorcycle driven by someone who fit the description of the robbery suspect. Â He activated his blue lights and followed the motorcycle.Â  According to Officer Little, Justice slowed down and put on his turn signal as if he were going to stop.Â  However, instead of stopping, Justice sped off and turned down a side street. Â Ultimately, Justice crashed the motorcycle after hitting an embankment.Â  During the search of Justiceâ€™s person and a motorcycle saddlebag, Officer Little found a bottle of chocolate milk, four packages of Reeseâ€™s Pieces, and three ten dollar bills.
A Greenville County grand jury indicted Justice for common law robbery and failure to stop for a blue light. 
On July 21, 2005, the day Justice was scheduled to be tried for the two charges, he moved for the court to dismiss his appointed counsel.Â  Justice claimed his counsel was â€œineffectiveâ€ because he had not pursued Justiceâ€™s requests regarding certain evidence, including a store surveillance videotape of the robbery and several witnesses.Â  
In response, Justiceâ€™s counsel recounted the following history of his representation of Justice:Â  (1) Justice indicated on March 17, 2005, that he intended to plead guilty to both charges; (2) he changed his mind on May 4, 2005, and decided to go to trial; and (3) he then decided to plead guilty on July 8, 2005.Â  Counsel informed the court that he was ready to try the case if Justice did not plead guilty.
The judge denied Justiceâ€™s motion to dismiss his counsel and instructed Justice that he could either go to trial or plead guilty. Â In so ruling, the judge based his decision on the belief that Justice was â€œplaying games with the Court.â€Â Â Â Â Â  Â Â Â 
After conferring with his counsel, Justice decided to plead guilty.Â  After questioning Justice regarding his decision to plead guilty and instructing him on the constitutional rights that he was waiving by pleading guilty, the judge found Justice:Â  (1) understood his constitutional rights; (2) was satisfied with his counselâ€™s representation; and (3) had not been coerced or forced to plead guilty.Â  Based on these findings, the judge ruled Justice was freely and voluntarily pleading guilty. Â After the State gave a factual account of the offenses and listed Justiceâ€™s prior record, the judge heard from Justice and his counsel.Â  At the conclusion of the hearing, the judge sentenced Justice to thirteen years imprisonment for common law robbery and three years for failure to stop for a blue light.Â  The sentences were to be served concurrently.Â  This appeal followed.
DISCUSSION
Justice asserts the trial judge erred in refusing to allow him to dismiss his court-appointed counsel and proceed pro se.Â  Because he was not permitted to proceed pro se, Justice contends this court should vacate his guilty plea and remand for further proceedings.Â  We disagree.
Initially, we believe Justice has waived his right to raise this issue on direct appeal given he pleaded guilty to the charged offenses.Â  See Â Â Gibson v. State, 334 S.C. 515, 523, 514 S.E.2d 320, 324 (1999) (â€œA defendant who pleads guilty usually may not later raise independent claims of constitutional violations.â€); Rivers v. Strickland, 264 S.C. 121, 124, 213 S.E.2d 97, 98 (1975) (â€œThe general rule is that a plea of guilty, voluntarily and understandingly made, constitutes a waiver of nonjurisdictional defects and defenses, including claims of violation of constitutional rights prior to the plea. Â An accused also waives the right to trial and the incidents thereof and the constitutional guarantees with respect to criminal prosecutions.â€); State v. Snowdon, 371 S.C. 331, 333, 638 S.E.2d 91, 92-93 (Ct. App. 2006) (holding defendant, by pleading guilty, waived any objection he may have had and, therefore, could not assert any constitutionally-based violations).Â  Even if Justice properly preserved this issue, we find his argument to be without merit.Â  
â€œThe question of whether appellantâ€™s court appointed counsel should be discharged was a matter addressed to the discretion of the trial judge. Only in case of abuse of such discretion will this court interfere.â€Â  State v. Marshall, 273 S.C. 552, 555, 257 S.E.2d 740, 742 (1979).Â  The defendant bears the burden to show satisfactory cause for removal.Â  State v. Graddick, 345 S.C. 383, 386, 548 S.E.2d 210, 211 (2001).Â  In evaluating whether the trial judge abused his discretion in denying Justiceâ€™s motion, â€œthe Court may consider several factors: timeliness of the motion, adequacy of the trial judgeâ€™s inquiry into the defendantâ€™s complaint, and whether the attorney-client conflict was so great that it resulted in a total lack of communication, thereby preventing an adequate defense.â€Â  State v. Sims, 304 S.C. 409, 414, 405 S.E.2d 377, 380 (1991).
Applying the above-outlined factors, we find the trial judge did not abuse his discretion in denying Justiceâ€™s motion.Â  First, Justiceâ€™s motion was clearly untimely.Â  According to Justiceâ€™s court-appointed counsel, Justice indicated he wished to plead guilty on March 17, 2005, but then requested a jury trial on May 4, 2005, the date that his plea was scheduled.Â  On July 8, 2005, Justice again changed his mind when he decided to plead guilty.Â  On July 21, 2005, the day Justice was scheduled for trial, Justice moved to dismiss his court-appointed counsel despite his recent decision to plead guilty.Â  Secondly, the judge adequately inquired into Justiceâ€™s complaint regarding his counsel.Â  At the beginning of the hearing, the judge permitted Justice to explain the rationale behind his motion.Â  Finally, the record does not reveal that there existed any conflict between Justice and his counsel so great that it resulted in a total lack of communication.Â  Although there appeared to be a disagreement between Justice and his counsel regarding the approach to certain evidence, this alone is insufficient to constitute a lack of communication.Â  Significantly, Justice conferred with his counsel before deciding to plead guilty.Â  Additionally, Justice acknowledged, under oath, that he was satisfied with his counselâ€™s representation.Â  
To the extent Justice argues in his brief that he should have been permitted to proceed pro se, we question whether this issue was properly preserved for our review given Justice did not specifically raise this issue to the trial judge.Â  See State v. Hicks, 330 S.C. 207, 216, 499 S.E.2d 209, 214 (1998) (holding that issues not raised to or ruled upon by the trial judge are not preserved for appellate review). Although Justice indicated that he wanted to discharge his court-appointed counsel, the request was based on his belief that counsel was ineffective.Â  Thus, the motion could be construed that Justice in fact wanted different counsel.Â  Even if Justice made the motion with the intention of proceeding pro se, this implicit request was not sufficient to constitute an affirmative request or clear assertion of his right to proceed pro se.Â  See Dearybury v. State, 367 S.C. 34, 39-40, 625 S.E.2d 212, 215 (2006) (stating â€œ[t]he right to proceed pro se must be clearly asserted by the defendant prior to trialâ€); Sims, 304 S.C. at 415, 405 S.E.2d at 381 (holding defendantâ€™s contention that the trial judge erred in not allowing him to proceed pro se was without merit where defendant gave no indication of a desire to proceed pro se prior to trial).
Accordingly, Justiceâ€™s convictions and sentences are
 AFFIRMED.
HUFF, BEATTY, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1]  Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Scott B. and Andrea M., Respondents/Appellants,
v.
Melissa M., Everett H., and D. and G., minors, under the age of seven (7) years,
Defendants,
Of whom Melissa M. is Appellant/Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Â Wesley L. Brown, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-109
Submitted March 1, 2007 â€“ Filed March 6, 2007

AFFIRMED IN PART AND VACATED IN PART


  
    
      
Joseph K. Maddox, Jr. and Richard H. Rhodes, both of Spartanburg, for Appellant/Respondent.
James Fletcher Thompson, of Spartanburg, for Respondents/Appellants.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  The family court terminated Melissa M.â€™s (Mother) parental rights (TPR) to the two minor children, D. and G., based on two statutory grounds: (1) Mother willfully failed to provide support for the minor children, and (2) Mother had a diagnosable mental condition, unlikely to change within a reasonable time, that prevented Mother from providing minimally acceptable care for the minor children. Â The family court further determined that termination of Motherâ€™s parental rights was in the childrenâ€™s best interest. We affirm.[1]
Additionally, the family court ordered Andrea M. (Andrea) and Scott B. (Scott) to pay Motherâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Andrea and Scott argue the family court was without statutory authority to award attorneyâ€™s fees in this case.Â  We agree and vacate that part of the family courtâ€™s order. 
FACTS
Mother and Lee H. had two children during the course of an off and on relationship that began in 1999. Â D. was born on September 20, 2000 and G. was born on June 18, 2002.Â  H. left Mother in January of 2000 and was not heard from until October of that year.Â  Mother and H. resumed living together in the spring of 2001 but their relationship deteriorated.Â  On May 15, 2001, Mother was admitted to the hospital after she overdosed on drugs and cut her wrists. Â Following this first suicide attempt Andrea, Motherâ€™s sister, began helping care for D. Â In July, 2001, Mother and H. resumed their relationship. 
Mother had been a reservist with the Air Force for approximately four years when terrorist attacks occurred in New York City on September 11, 2001. Â Subsequently, she volunteered for a thirty-day tour in Charleston that actually turned out to be a sixty-day tour.Â  Ultimately her assignment evolved into a one-year tour of active duty in Charleston. Â H. cared for D. while Mother was on duty until November 2001.Â  However, when Mother discovered H. had been using marijuana, cocaine, and methamphetamines, she made H. leave the home. Â Thereafter, Andrea and her mother helped care for D. in H.â€™s absence.Â  In October of 2001, Mother learned she was pregnant.Â  Subsequently, Mother attempted to reconcile with H. a number of times without success.Â  Her last contact with H. was in September of 2005.Â  Between October 2001 and October 2002, Andrea and Scott took care of D. for most of the time while Mother was in Charleston.Â  
After G.â€™s birth on June 18, 2002, Mother experienced postpartum depression.Â  In June of 2003, at a birthday party for G., Mother slurred her words and fell out of a chair.Â  On that same occasion, Andrea noticed D. had bruises on his face.Â  After talking with D. about the bruises Andrea became concerned about his safety.Â  In February and July of 2004, Mother was hospitalized again for suicide attempts by overdose.Â  Mother left a note to her parents before the July 2004 suicide attempt, stating, â€œAndrea and Scott will make excellent parents, they can provide a life for those children I never could.â€Â  The record indicates multiple hospitalizations for suicide ideation, depression, and drug abuse during 2003 and 2004.Â  Â 
During 2003, Andrea and Scott and Motherâ€™s parents assisted in caring for the children.Â  By 2004, Andrea and Scott took care of D. frequently.Â  In addition, Andrea often interacted with G. at Motherâ€™s residence when she picked D. up or returned him home.Â  In February of 2004, Andrea delivered D. to Motherâ€™s house and discovered the home was a â€œdisaster area.â€ The disarray of the home and Motherâ€™s lethargic condition caused Andrea concern about Motherâ€™s ability to take care of D.Â  Andrea brought D. back to her house, where he remained for the following week.Â  
Following an emergency hearing on August 26, 2004, the family court awarded temporary custody of D. and G. to Andrea and Scott by order dated October 18, 2004.Â  Mother testified she did not provide any financial support for her children during the first eleven months they were in Andrea and Scottâ€™s custody.Â  She explained Andrea never asked for any support.Â  Mother began making fairly regular support payments in July 2005.Â  Additionally, she made approximately six $16 payments to D. and G.â€™s daycare center.Â  In the event she won custody of the children, Mother testified she would probably temporarily go back on food stamps.Â  
Andrea and Scott married on July 7, 2005, after being together fifteen years. Â Andrea testified â€œwe felt like we needed to make our commitment to one another legal so we could make the commitment to the children together.â€Â  Scott had developed a strong relationship with the children.Â  He earned approximately $140,000 in 2005 and Andrea earned approximately $35,000.Â  By order dated August 9, 2005, the family court terminated Motherâ€™s parental rights and awarded her attorneyâ€™s fees. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In a TPR case, the best interest of the child is paramount.Â  Doe v. Baby Boy Roe, 353 S.C. 576, 579, 578 S.E.2d 733, 735 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  Before forever terminating parental rights, the alleged grounds for termination must be proven by clear and convincing evidence.Â  Richberg v. Dawson, 278 S.C. 356, 357, 296 S.E.2d 338, 339 (1982); S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Parker, 336 S.C. 248, 254, 519 S.E.2d 351, 354 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  On appeal, this court may review the record and make its own determination whether the termination grounds are supported by clear and convincing evidence. S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Cummings, 345 S.C. 288, 293, 547 S.E.2d 506, 509 (Ct. App. 2001). Despite the broad scope of review, this court should not wholly disregard the family court findings because the family court is in a better position to evaluate the credibility of the witnesses and assign weight to their testimony. Dorchester County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Miller, 324 S.C. 445, 452, 477 S.E.2d 476, 480 (Ct. App. 1996).
DISCUSSION
I.  Failure to Support
Section 20-7-1572 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005), provides that the family court may terminate parental rights based on one or more of the eleven listed statutory grounds and on the finding that termination is in the best interest of the child.Â  The family court identified section 20-7-1572(4) as one of the grounds for termination of Motherâ€™s parental rights.Â  Section 20-7-1572(4) provides for TPR if:

the child has lived outside the home of either parent for a period of six months, and during that time the parent has wilfully failed to support the child. Â Failure to support means that the parent has failed to make a material contribution to the child's care. Â A material contribution consists of either financial contributions according to the parentâ€™s means or contributions of food, clothing, shelter, or other necessities for the care of the child according to the parent's means. Â The court may consider all relevant circumstances in determining whether or not the parent has wilfully failed to support the child, including requests for support by the custodian and the ability of the parent to provide support

The record contains ample evidence that the children were with Andrea and Scott for eleven months and Mother made no financial contributions to their support during that time.Â  The family court found Mother had a history of putting her own needs ahead of her childrenâ€™s and Motherâ€™s payment of child support in July 2005 was judicially motivated.Â  The family court did not err in terminating Motherâ€™s parental rights for failure to support.
II.  Diagnosable Condition 
As an additional ground the family court cited section 20-7-1572(6) that provides for TPR if:

the parent has a diagnosable condition unlikely to change within a reasonable time including, but not limited to, alcohol or drug addiction, mental deficiency, mental illness, or extreme physical incapacity, and the condition makes the parent unlikely to provide minimally acceptable care of the child. 

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572(6) (Supp. 2005).
The family court heard testimony from Stephen M. Gedo, Jr., Ph.D., Cheryl Fortner-Wood, Ph.D., Kim Rosborough, MSW, and Janis D. Browning,
D.O.  
Dr. Gedo believed Mother needed life long medication and had the potential to become suicidal again.Â  He stated the greatest predictor for suicide is past attempts, followed by having relatives who attempt suicide.Â  Mother has two uncles who committed suicide.Â  Dr. Gedo had concerns about the safety of D. and G. if they were returned to Motherâ€™s custody.Â  
Dr. Cheryl Fortner-Wood testified that Andrea, Scott, and the children had formed a secure attachment.Â  Dr. Fortner-Wood opined that removing the children from an environment with a secure attachment would adversely impact the childrenâ€™s development.Â  
Kim Rosborough testified as an expert in child psychology, trauma to children, and childrenâ€™s therapy. Â Rosborough expressed concern about Motherâ€™s history of treatment failures.Â  She stated that children can be a significant stressor for a parent and the stress of caring for the children may contribute to continued recurrences of depressive episodes.Â  Rosborough observed that Mother had been stable without having the stress of having the children with her. 
Dr. Browning testified Mother had made significant progress with her depression, functioning well with goals, and trying to improve her situation.Â  However, Dr. Browning noted Mother discontinued her treatment because of concern her treatment may adversely affect her case.
Based on the collective and uncontradicted testimony of Dr. Gedo, Dr. Fortner-Wood, and Rosborough, the family court concluded Motherâ€™s mental status fit within the statutory classification in 20-7-1572(6).Â  Moreover, Motherâ€™s own expert, Dr. Browning, testified to the likelihood that Mother would experience recurrences of her depression.Â  
III.  Best Interest 
Once a statutory ground has been proven, section 20-7-1572 requires that the best interest of the child must be served by the parental rights being terminated.Â  In a TPR case, the best interests of the child are the paramount consideration.Â  S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Smith, 343 S.C. 129, 133, 538 S.E.2d 285, 287 (Ct. App. 2000).
Cindy Rawlings, the owner and director of D. and G.â€™s current daycare center, testified the children were always late when Mother brought them to day care and that Mother appeared to be more focused on her own needs rather than on the childrenâ€™s.Â  Rawlings stated that Mother was the â€œworst parent Iâ€™ve ever seen,â€ and she claimed Mother verbally abused D.Â  Andrea helped with D. and G.â€™s tuition and supplies for the daycare.Â  Since Andrea received custody of D. and G., Rawlings testified the children have arrived on time, appear to be happy, and have a good relationship with Andrea.Â  
Dr. Cheryl Fortner-Wood testified that Andrea, Scott, and the children have a secure attachment and removing the children from that secure attachment environment would adversely impact the childrenâ€™s development.Â  Given Motherâ€™s suicide attempts by overdose and depression, the childrenâ€™s lives with Mother lacked stability and security.Â  Dr. Gedo had concerns about the safety of D. and G. if they were returned to Motherâ€™s custody.Â  Moreover, Andrea and Scott have been able to provide for D. and G. financially and emotionally, whereas Mother has not.Â  

The family court found:
Given [Motherâ€™s] multiple suicidal gestures, multiple hospitalizations, abuse of illegal and prescription drugs, the stressor that the children constitute for her, and her diagnoses, this Court finds that returning the children to [Mother] will constitute unreasonable risk to the children, and to [Mother] herself.Â  [Motherâ€™s] recurrent depression has served a paralyzing effect on her ability to parent.

IV. Attorneyâ€™s Fees
â€œIt is well settled that an award of attorneyâ€™s fees is within the sound discretion of the trial judge and will
not be disturbed absent an abuse of that discretion.â€Â  Smith v. Smith, 308 S.C. 492, 496, 419 S.E.2d 232, 234-35 (Ct. App. 1992).Â  However, â€œ[a]ttorneyâ€™s fees are not recoverable unless authorized by contract or by statute.â€ Â S. C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Tharp, 312 S.C. 243, 245-46, 439 S.E.2d 854, 856 (1994) (citing Hegler v. Gulf Ins. Co., 270 S.C. 548, 243 S.E.2d 443 (1978)).
Section 15-77-300 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005) provides attorneyâ€™s fees for a prevailing party in a civil action brought by the State or a State subdivision such as DSS.Â  However, this case was a private cause of action for termination of parental rights.Â  Additionally, although section 20-7-420 of the South Carolina Code provides the family court with a basis for awarding attorneyâ€™s fees to a spouse in marital litigation, that section has no application to private actions for the termination of parental rights.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-420 (Supp. 2005).Â  Therefore, the family court erred in awarding attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  
CONCLUSION
The family court properly terminated Motherâ€™s parental rights based on Motherâ€™s failure to support, Motherâ€™s diagnosable condition, and because termination was in D. and G.â€™s best interests.Â  Thus, the termination of Motherâ€™s parental rights is affirmed.Â  However, no contract or statute provided for attorneyâ€™s fees for this case; therefore, the family court erred in awarding attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  The award of attorneyâ€™s fees is thereby vacated.Â  Accordingly, the family court is
AFFIRMED IN PART AND VACATED IN PART. 
ANDERSON, KITTREDGE, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  We decide this case without oral argument, pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Holmes v. Holmes
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Cynthia Holmes, Appellant,
v.
James Kevin Holmes, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Â Jeffrey Young, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-110
Submitted March 1, 2007 â€“ Filed March 7, 2007

APPEAL DISMISSED


  
    
      
Cynthia E. Collie, of Sullivans Island, for Appellant.
James Kevin Holmes, of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Cynthia Holmes (Mother) appeals the family courtâ€™s orders[1] denying her motion for an order prohibiting James Kevin Holmes[2] (Father) from taking the partiesâ€™ two minor children out of the country before there is a final determination of permanent custody. Â We dismiss this appeal as moot.[3]
FACTS
After a twenty-five-year marriage, the parties divorced on January 30, 2004.Â  Three children were born to the marriage.Â  Of the three children, two are still minors.Â  Although neither party has been awarded custody of these children, they reside with Mother, who has been their primary caretaker.Â  
In anticipation of the childrenâ€™s school vacation, Mother filed a motion in March of 2006 in which she sought an order from the family court prohibiting Father from taking the children out of the country pending resolution of the custody issue.Â  Specifically, Mother moved before the family court for an order prohibiting Father from taking the partiesâ€™ minor son on a vacation to Miami, Florida and the Bahamas from April 8 through April 16, 2006.Â  
On April 6, 2006, the family court held an emergency hearing on Motherâ€™s motion.Â  At the hearing, both Mother and Father proceeded pro se.Â  In support of her motion, Mother expressed she was concerned that Father would abscond with the minor child if he was permitted to leave the country before the issue of custody was resolved.Â  In response, Father stated he had no intention of absconding with the child.Â  He further explained that:Â  he was a thirty-year member of the South Carolina Bar Association; he was employed by a Charleston law firm; he owned property in Charleston, and had strong community ties in the area; his son spends every weekend with him; and he and his son had previously taken vacations to Hawaii, New Jersey, Washington, D.C., North Carolina, and Georgia without incident. Â He also informed the court that he and his son were going to meet the partiesâ€™ twenty-one-year-old daughter in Miami and then go to the Bahamas. 
At the conclusion of the hearing, the court orally ruled that Father â€œbe allowed to take the child on the planned vacation, with the child being returned to the mother per the itinerary that has been set out.Â  And that will be the times for the visitation.â€Â  
By written order dated the day of the hearing, the court denied the motion without explanation.Â  The next day, April 7, 2006, the court issued a written order in which he elaborated on his ruling with findings of fact and conclusions of law.Â  Mother appeals both orders.
DISCUSSION
In her appeal, Mother argues the family court erred in:Â  (1) failing to comply with Rule 41.1 of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure by considering the partiesâ€™ sealed 1998 action for separate support and maintenance; (2) ruling where it did not have jurisdiction to issue an order â€œpurportedly operational, in whole or in part, outside the borders of the U.S.â€; (3) issuing orders which are â€œnull and voidâ€ because they are unenforceable outside the territorial limits of the United States; (4) â€œfailing to recognize the courtâ€™s interest in maintaining jurisdiction pending final adjudication on the meritsâ€ of the custody issue; (5) â€œfailing to recognize the purpose of the temporary hearing as preservation of the status quo pending an adequate factual showing at a full and fair hearing on the meritsâ€; and (6) issuing two different orders from the same hearing.Â  Based on these alleged errors, Mother contends the family courtâ€™s orders should be reversed in the interest of â€œsubstantial justice affecting substantial rights.â€Â  For reasons that will be discussed, we find Motherâ€™s appeal is moot and we need not address these issues.Â  
â€œGenerally, this Court only considers cases presenting a justiciable controversy.â€Â  Sloan v. Friends of Hunley, Inc., 369 S.C. 20, 25, 630 S.E.2d 474, 477 (2006).Â  â€œA justiciable controversy exists when there is a real and substantial controversy which is appropriate for judicial determination, as distinguished from a dispute that is contingent, hypothetical, or abstract.â€ Id.
â€œA moot case exists where a judgment rendered by the court will have no practical legal effect upon an existing controversy because an intervening event renders any grant of effectual relief impossible for the reviewing court. If there is no actual controversy, this Court will not decide
moot or academic questions.â€Â  Seabrook v. Knox, 369 S.C. 191, 197, 631 S.E.2d 907, 910 (2006)(citations omitted); see Collins Music Co. v. IGT, 365 S.C. 544, 549, 619 S.E.2d 1, 3 (Ct. App. 2005), cert. denied (Dec. 7, 2006)(noting a matter becomes moot when some event occurs making it impossible to grant effectual relief).
In the orders at issue, the family court made the limited ruling of denying Motherâ€™s motion and permitting Father to take one of the partiesâ€™ minor children on a vacation to Miami, Florida and the Bahamas from April 8 through April 2006.Â  Even if we were to find the family court erred in denying Motherâ€™s motion, our decision would have no practical effect on this controversy given the vacation at issue is over.Â  Because a decision on this issue would not grant Mother any effectual relief, we hold the appeal is moot. 
Furthermore, after reviewing the case, we do not believe any exceptions to the mootness doctrine are applicable.Â  See Collins Music Co., 365 S.C. at 549, 619 S.E.2d at 3 (â€œIn civil cases, there are three exceptions to the
mootness doctrine:Â  (1) an appellate court can retain jurisdiction if the issue is capable of repetition yet evading review, (2) an appellate court can decide cases of urgency to establish a rule for future conduct in matters of important public interest, and (3) if the decision by the trial court can affect future events or have collateral consequences to the parties, the appellate court can take jurisdiction.â€).Â  Accordingly, we dismiss Motherâ€™s appeal as moot.
APPEAL DISMISSED.
HUFF, BEATTY, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] 
Mother filed a separate appeal for each of these orders.Â  Because the appeals involve identical issues, this court granted Motherâ€™s motion to consolidate the appeals into one opinion.Â  See Rule 214, SCACR (â€œWhere there is more than one appeal from the same order, judgment, decision or decree, or where the same question is involved in two or more appeals in different cases, the appellate court may, in its discretion, order the appeal to be consolidated.â€).
[2]  Father did not file a Respondentâ€™s Brief.
[3]  Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
