title: Village West v. International Sales
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Village West Horizontal Property Regime, Respondent,
v.
International Sales and Marketing Group, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
Jackson V. Gregory, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-111
Submitted February 1, 2007 â€“ Filed March 7, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Jack D. Simrill, of Hilton Head Island, for Appellant.Â  
Edward E. Bullard and Sonja N. Friedman, both of Hilton Head Island, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  International Sales and Marketing Group appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order granting Village West Horizontal Property Regime summary judgment.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
The Village West Horizontal Property Regime consists of three phases.Â  Phases I and II contain the Schooner, Clipper, Galleon, and Flagship buildings.Â  Phase III contains the Spinnaker Building.Â  International Sales and Marketing Group owned Unit 14 in the Spinnaker Building.
The misapplication of synthetic stucco in Phases I and II caused water intrusion in those buildings.Â  Consequently, the regime filed suit against the developer.Â  The suit was settled, and the regime paid court costs and attorneyâ€™s fees from the settlement.Â  The remaining proceeds were not enough to repair the buildings.Â  Because of this deficiency, the regimeâ€™s board of directors included the cost of repairing these buildings in its annual assessment against all unit owners in Phases I, II, and III.Â  
On March 21, 2005, the regime filed suit against International for its failure to pay this assessment.Â  During the pendency of the action, International sold Unit 14 and paid the assessment in order to consummate the transaction.Â  However, International refused to stipulate to the dismissal of the regimeâ€™s suit.Â  The regime then moved for summary judgment, asking the circuit court to dismiss the action and award attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  
In response, International moved to amend its answer, asserting counterclaims against the regime for return of its payment and unfair or deceptive trade practices.Â  International contended the assessment was improper because the Spinnaker Building was not water damaged and therefore not the subject of repair.Â  International also argued the regimeâ€™s by-laws prohibited the assessment.Â  
The circuit court held a hearing and granted the regime summary judgment, holding the regimeâ€™s by-laws permitted the assessment.Â  International moved for reconsideration, which the circuit court denied.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
An appellate court reviews the grant of summary judgment under the same standard applied by the circuit court.Â  David v. McLeod Regâ€™l Med. Ctr., 367 S.C. 242, 247, 626 S.E.2d 1, 3 (2006).Â  The circuit court should grant summary judgment â€œif the pleadings, depositions, answers to interrogatories, and admissions on file, together with the affidavits, if any, show that there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and that the moving party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law.â€ Â Rule 56(c), SCRCP; Byrd v. City of Hartsville, 365 S.C. 650, 656, 620 S.E.2d 76, 79 (2005).Â  In determining whether any triable issues of fact exist, the evidence and all reasonable inferences therefrom must be viewed in the light most favorable to the non-moving party.Â  Law v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Corr., 368 S.C. 424, 434, 629 S.E.2d 642, 648 (2006).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  The Regimeâ€™s By-Laws
International argues the circuit court erred in granting summary judgment to the regime because the regimeâ€™s by-laws prohibited the assessment.Â  Specifically, International contends Articles IX and X of the by-laws require the regime to assess only the unit owners whose units are damaged.Â  Alternatively, International maintains the by-laws are ambiguous.Â  We disagree.
The operative documents that govern a horizontal property regime constitute a contract between the association and its individual members.Â  Swanson v. Parkway Estates Townhouse Assâ€™n, 567 N.W.2d 767, 768 (Minn. Ct. App. 1997); see also Reyhani v. Stone Creek Cove Condo. II Horizontal Prop. Regime, 329 S.C. 206, 211-13, 494 S.E.2d 465, 468-69 (Ct. App. 1997) (applying principles of contract law to interpret the operative documents of a horizontal property regime).Â  The interpretation of a clear and unambiguous agreement is a question of law for the court. Â Stribling v. Stribling, 369 S.C. 400, 404, 632 S.E.2d 291, 293 (Ct. App. 2006). 
In construing a contract, the primary objective is to ascertain and give effect to the intention of the parties.Â  D.A. Davis Constr. Co., v. Palmetto Props., Inc., 281 S.C. 415, 418, 315 S.E.2d 370, 372 (1984).Â  The partiesâ€™ intention should first be determined from the language of the contract.Â  Schulmeyer v. State Farm Fire & Cas. Co., 353 S.C. 491, 495, 579 S.E.2d 132, 134 (2003).Â  â€œIn general, if the contract is unambiguous, clear, and explicit, it must be construed according to the terms the parties have used, and the terms are to be taken and understood in their plain, ordinary, and popular sense.â€Â  Ingram v. Kaseyâ€™s Assocs., 340 S.C. 98, 110, 531 S.E.2d 287, 293 (2000).Â  

Article IX of the regimeâ€™s by-laws provides, in pertinent part:
  
In the event of casualty loss or damage to the Property, the [regimeâ€™s] Board of Directors shall be responsible for applying the proceeds of all casualty insurance to the repair or reconstruction of the Property in accordance with the provisions of this ARTICLE IX . . . . Â If less than two-thirds (2/3) of the Property is destroyed or substantially damaged, then such Property shall be repaired in the following manner:
. . . .
(3) Â If the insurance proceeds paid to the Board are insufficient to cover the cost of reconstruction, the deficiency shall be paid as a special assessment by the Unit Owners whose units are being reconstructed or repaired in proportion to the damage done to their respective Units.Â  
  
Article X of the regimeâ€™s by-laws reads, in relevant part:
  
(2) Â Insurance proceeds paid on account of loss or damage to less than all of the Units, when the damage is to be restored, shall be held [by the Regimeâ€™s Board of Directors] for the benefit of Unit Owners of the damaged Units . . . in proportion to the costs of repairing each damaged unit.Â  
  

Using these provisions, International asserts the regime could not require unit owners in the Spinnaker Building to pay for reconstruction and repair costs with respect to the other buildings in the regime.Â  We disagree.
Articles IX and X of the regimeâ€™s by-laws are not applicable to the present case.Â  A
contract is read as a whole document so that one may not, by pointing out a single sentence or clause, create an ambiguity.Â  S. Atl. Fin. Servs., Inc. v. Middleton, 356 S.C. 444, 447, 590 S.E.2d 27, 29 (2003).Â  In this case, the opening paragraph of Article IX refers to â€œcasualty loss or damage to the Property . . .â€ and â€œthe proceeds of all casualty insurance.â€Â  The remainder of Article IX guides the board in how to apply these proceeds and what procedure to follow if the proceeds are deficient.Â  The clear, unambiguous intent of this provision is to provide the board guidance in the event of a casualty loss or damage caused by a casualty.Â  The damage at issue was the result of negligent construction so that the casualty provisions are not implicated.
Moreover, we agree that other provisions within the regimeâ€™s master deed and by-laws specifically allow the assessment.Â  Article V, Section (e) of the master deed reads, in part:


The obligations of all Unit owners with regard to assessments for common expenses and the maintenance and repair of the individual Units shall be as provided in the By-Laws of the [Regime] . . . .

Article VII, Section 6(c) of the by-laws provides, in part:
  
All maintenance, repair and replacement to the common elements as defined in the Master Deed, the painting and decorating of the exterior doors and exterior window sash and the washing of exterior glass shall be made by the [Regimeâ€™s] Board [of Directors] . . . and shall be charged to the Unit Owners as a common expense . . . .
  

Article VIII, Section A(1) of the master deed defines the regimeâ€™s common elements, which include â€œthe foundations, roofs, perimeter walls, [and] walls and partitions separating units . . . .â€Â  
In this case, the parties do not dispute the relevant repairs involved application of stucco on the walls of the buildings.Â  Accordingly, the regimeâ€™s master deed and by-laws clearly provide for the assessment of all unit owners for construction defects with respect to any of the buildings within the regime.Â  Additionally, this language complies with statutory law and the general purpose behind horizontal property regimes.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 27-31-190 (Rev. 2007) (â€œThe co-owners of the apartments are bound to contribute pro rata . . . toward the expenses of administration and of maintenance and repair of the general common elements.â€).
II. Â Genuine Issues of Material Fact
International maintains the circuit court erred in granting summary judgment because several genuine issues of material fact exist for trial.Â  Specifically, International contends the following factual issues should be submitted to a jury: Â (1) whether the assessment would be used to make repairs to the Spinnaker Building; (2) whether Articles IX and X of the by-laws prohibited the regimeâ€™s use of the assessment to make repairs on the buildings; and (3) whether the repair and reconstruction would be made to individual units or common elements.Â  We disagree.
In light of our holding above, the issue of whether the assessment would be used to make repairs on the Spinnaker Building is immaterial.Â  Additionally, we have held the by-laws are clear and unambiguous.Â  Consequently, we have decided the issue of whether Articles IX and X prohibit the assessment as a matter of law.Â  Moreover, International produced no evidence repairs would be made to individual units within the regime.Â  In fact, International argued the assessment would be used to pay for water damage caused by the use of synthetic stucco on the buildings.Â  Therefore, we hold the circuit court properly found no genuine issues of material fact existed for trial.
III. Â Timing of Summary Judgment
International argues the circuit court erred by prematurely granting summary judgment.Â  International did not make this argument until it filed its Rule 59, SCRCP, motion.Â  â€œA party cannot for the first time raise an issue by way of a Rule 59(e) motion which could have been raised at trial.â€Â  Patterson v. Reid, 318 S.C. 183, 185, 456 S.E.2d 436, 437 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  Therefore, International did not preserve this issue for our review.
IV. Â The Business Judgment Rule
As an alternative sustaining ground, the regime contends the business judgment rule prevents Internationalâ€™s counterclaims.Â  In response, International contends this issue is not preserved because the circuit court failed to rule on the issue.Â  We hold the regime properly preserved this issue and agree with the regime on the merits.
â€œUnder the present rules, a respondentâ€”the â€˜winnerâ€™ in the lower courtâ€”may raise on appeal any additional reasons the appellate court should affirm the lower courtâ€™s ruling, regardless of whether those reasons have been presented to or ruled on by the lower court.â€Â  Iâ€™On, L.L.C. v. Town of Mt. Pleasant, 338 S.C. 406, 419, 526 S.E.2d 716, 723 (2000).Â  Accordingly, the regime may raise the issue of whether the business judgment rule prohibits Internationalâ€™s counterclaims on appeal.
The regime is a non-profit corporation. Â Under the business judgment rule, a court will not review the business judgment of a corporate governing board when it acts within its authority, and it acts without corrupt motives and in good faith.Â  Dockside Assâ€™n, Inc. v. Detyens, 291 S.C. 214, 217, 352 S.E.2d 714, 716 (Ct. App. 1987) (applying the business judgment rule to the assessment decision of a horizontal property regimeâ€™s board of directors) affâ€™d, 294 S.C. 86, 362 S.E.2d 874 (1987).Â  International produced no evidence of bad faith or the failure of the regime to act within its scope of authority in levying and applying the assessment.Â  Accordingly, we hold the business judgment rule prevents Internationalâ€™s counterclaims.
V. Â Attorneyâ€™s Fees
International contends the circuit court erred in awarding attorneyâ€™s fees to the regime for proceedings occurring after payment of the assessment.Â  International did not raise nor did it obtain a ruling from the circuit court on this issue.Â  Therefore, International failed to preserve it for our review.Â  See Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (â€œ[A]n issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€).Â  
Based on all of the foregoing, the decision of the circuit court is 
 AFFIRMED.
 HEARN, C.J., GOOLSBY, and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

[1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Linda E. Whetsell, Appellant,
v.
Kermit T. Whetsell, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Dorchester County
Â William J. Wylie, Jr., Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-112
Submitted January 1, 2007 â€“ Filed March 7, 2007

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, and REMANDED


  
    
      
Deborah K. Lewis, of Charleston, for Appellant.
James A. Bell, of St. George, and James B. Richardson, Jr., of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this appeal from the family court, Linda Whetsell (Wife) appeals the family courtâ€™s failure to grant her a divorce on the grounds of adultery and desertion.Â  Wife also contends the family court erred in failing to award her alimony and attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We affirm in part, reverse in part, and remand. 
FACTS
Kermit Whetsell (Husband) and Wife married on June 26, 1971.Â  Toward the end of the marriage, Husband regularly returned home late at night. Â On July 14, 2002, Husband returned home around four oâ€™clock in the morning, and Wife became upset and asked him to leave.Â  Since that time, Husband and Wife have lived at all times in separate households.Â  On August 29, 2004, Wife filed for divorce on the grounds of adultery, desertion, and one yearâ€™s continuous separation.Â  Wife also requested alimony and attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  The parties reached an agreement regarding the division of marital assets and debts.Â  
Pursuant to the agreement, Wife received the marital home, two vehicles, fifty percent of Husbandâ€™s pension plan, and the partiesâ€™ time share, which was in foreclosure.Â  Also, Wife received fifty percent of Husbandâ€™s 401(k) account, offset by the value of her 401(k) account, which she retained in full.Â  Husband received his share of inherited family property, a 1981 double-wide home, two vehicles, and the remaining funds in his pension and 401(k) plans.Â  Additionally, the parties were solely responsible for the mortgages, taxes, and insurance on their respective assets as well as for their own debts. 
At the time of the divorce hearing, Wife was 52 years old and Husband was 54 years old.Â  Wife worked as a medical courier and had gross earnings of $1,780.72 per month and net earnings of $1,156 per month.Â  Husband worked as a meter reader and had gross earnings of $3,144.26 per month and net earnings of $2,214.91 per month.Â  In 2004, Husband reported earnings of $41,969.41 and Wife reported earnings of $22,439.25.Â  
At the hearing, Wife testified the marriage had been â€œa roller coaster ride.â€Â  The marriage was damaged by Husbandâ€™s gambling and involvement with pornography.Â  She testified they used to take family trips around the country, but since the separation, her lifestyle was â€œalmost null and voidâ€ because she did not have â€œmuch money to [be able to] do anything.â€Â  Following the separation, she has been experiencing financial difficulty and has received help from her family to buy food and to pay her phone bill.Â  Further, her brother and sister paid for her to go to a family reunion because she could not afford it. Â Wife claimed that after their separation, Husband continued to bowl regularly and take trips.Â  
Wife testified she believed Husband had an affair because he was never home. Â He would sometimes not tell her who he was with, and she testified he told her that he had found someone else.Â  She believed Husband had an affair with Loretta Coker because he is currently living at Cokerâ€™s residence.Â  As further evidence of Husbandâ€™s alleged adultery, Wife presented a charge to â€œFlowers and Thingsâ€ on the partiesâ€™ joint bank statement, made after their separation, for flowers she neither sent nor received.Â  On cross-examination, Wife acknowledged that on the day she alleged flowers were purchased for $7.50, Flowers and Things credited the account $14.
Wifeâ€™s niece, Milicent Haynes, testified she saw Husband at a basketball game with Coker. Â Haynes stated they were not â€œlovey-dovey.â€ Â In fact, Husbandâ€™s grandson was sitting between the two of them.Â  Haynes testified that Husbandâ€™s daughter had pointed out Coker at the mall as â€œdaddyâ€™s girlfriend or friend.â€Â  
Husband responded that he currently resides in the residence with Coker, her uncle, and her granddaughter.Â  Further, he pays rent of $434 per month. Â He admitted that he gambled during the marriage and that he still occasionally gambles.Â  
Husband acknowledged that during the marriage, he stayed out until four oâ€™clock in the morning on occasion but claimed Wife knew he was going to see his brotherâ€™s band.Â  He acknowledged gambling during the marriage and that he still occasionally gambles. Â 
The family court found Wife failed to prove adultery by a clear preponderance of the evidence and granted the divorce on the ground of one yearâ€™s continuous separation.Â  Based upon the sole finding that neither party was more at fault in causing the breakup of the marriage, the family court denied Wife alimony.Â  Further, the family court ordered the parties to pay their own attorneyâ€™s fees and costs. Â The family court approved the partiesâ€™ agreement and resolved the remaining issues.Â  This appeal followed. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
On appeal from a family court order, this Court has authority to correct errors of law and find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â 
E.D.M. v. T.A.M., 307 S.C. 471, 473, 415 S.E.2d 812, 814 (1992).Â  When reviewing decisions of the family court, we are cognizant of the fact that it had the opportunity to see the witnesses, hear â€œthe testimony delivered from the stand, and had the benefit of that personal observance of and contact with the parties which is of peculiar value in arriving at a correct result in a case of this character.â€ Â DuBose v. DuBose, 259 S.C. 418, 423, 192 S.E.2d 329, 331 (1972); see also 
Scott v. Scott, 354 S.C. 118, 124, 579 S.E.2d 620, 623 (2003) (â€œBecause the family court is in a superior position to judge the witnessesâ€™ demeanor and veracity, its findings should be given broad discretion.â€). 
When the evidence is conflicting and susceptible of different inferences, the family court has the duty of determining not only the law of the case, but the facts as well, because it had the benefit of observing the witnesses and determining how much credence to give each oneâ€™s testimony. Â Anders v. Anders, 285 S.C. 512, 514, 331 S.E.2d 340, 341 (1985); see also Woodall v. Woodall, 322 S.C. 7, 10, 471 S.E.2d 154, 157 (1996) (holding when evidence is disputed, the appellate court may adhere to the family courtâ€™s findings). 
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Divorce on the Ground of Adultery
Wife argues the family court erred in failing to grant her a divorce on the ground of adultery.Â  We disagree.
â€œ[P]roof of adultery as a ground for divorce must be clear and positive[,] and the infidelity must be established by a clear preponderance of the evidence.â€ Â Odom v. Odom, 248 S.C. 144, 146, 149 S.E.2d 353, 354 (1966).Â  A â€œpreponderance of the evidenceâ€ is evidence which convinces as to its truth. Â DuBose v. DuBose, 259 S.C. 418, 424, 192 S.E.2d 329, 331 (1972).Â  Because of â€œthe clandestine natureâ€ of adultery, obtaining evidence on the commission of the act by eyewitness testimony is rarely possible, and direct evidence is not necessary to establish the charge.Â 
Fulton v. Fulton, 293 S.C. 146, 147, 359 S.E.2d 88, 88 (Ct. App. 1987).Â  
Adultery may be proven by circumstantial evidence, but it â€œmust be so convincing as to exclude any other reasonable hypothesis but that of guilt.â€ Â Fulton, 293 S.C. at 147, 359 S.E.2d at 88.Â  Proof of adultery by circumstantial evidence must establish both a disposition and opportunity to commit the offense. Â Hartley v. Hartley, 292 S.C. 245, 247, 355 S.E.2d 869, 871 (Ct. App. 1987).Â  Generally, â€œproof must be sufficiently definite to identify the time and place of the offense and the circumstances under which it was committed.â€ Â Loftis v. Loftis, 284 S.C. 216, 218, 325 S.E.2d 73, 74 (Ct. App. 1985). Â However, a divorce on the ground of adultery should be denied if proof of the offense is inconclusive following the consideration of all the evidence. Â Rabon v. Rabon, 289 S.C. 49, 53, 344 S.E.2d 615, 617 (Ct. App. 1986).
Wifeâ€™s only evidence of adultery is Husband now resides, along with two other individuals, in a house owned by Coker.Â  Husband and Coker also bowl together, occasionally have dinner with one another, and they attend basketball games together.Â  Wife also testified that Husband told her he found someone else. Â Evidence placing a spouse and a third party together on several occasions, without more, does not warrant the conclusion that the spouse committed adultery.Â  Fox v. Fox, 277 S.C. 400, 402, 288 S.E.2d 390, 391 (1982).Â  
Wife fails to provide convincing evidence of Husbandâ€™s romantic demonstrations toward Coker.Â  See McElveen v. McElveen, 332 S.C. 583, 598, 506 S.E.2d 1, 8 (Ct. App. 1998) (â€œ[T]here is virtually no evidence of a romantic or sexual relationship between the two. Â The trial judge commented in his final order on the lack of evidence to support a showing
of inclination, noting there were no love letters, romantic cards, no hand-holding, hugging, kissing, or any other romantic demonstrations or actions between the two.â€).Â  Wife may have demonstrated opportunity for Husband to commit adultery, but she presented no evidence that Husband ever was alone with the alleged paramour, nor any evidence of a romantic relationship between the two.Â  
Accordingly, the family court did not abuse its discretion when it denied Wifeâ€™s request for a divorce on the ground of adultery.
II.Â  Divorce on the Ground of Desertion
Next, Wife maintains the family court erred in failing to grant her a divorce on the ground of desertion.Â  
We decline to address this issue because it is not preserved for our review.Â  Although Wife raised this issue in her complaint, the family court failed to rule on it, and Wife did not file a Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion.Â  When the family court makes a general ruling on an issue, but it does not address the specific argument raised by the appellant, and the appellant does not make a motion to alter or amend pursuant to Rule 59(e), SCRCP, to obtain a ruling on the argument, this Court cannot consider the argument.Â  Floyd v. Floyd, 365 S.C. 56, 73, 615 S.E.2d 465, 474 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  Accordingly, Wifeâ€™s request for a divorce on the grounds of desertion is not preserved for review on appeal.
III.Â  Alimony
Wife argues the family court erred in denying her request for alimony.Â  We agree.
The amount to be awarded for alimony, as well as a determination of whether the spouse is entitled to alimony, is within the sound discretion of the family court.Â  Smith v. Smith, 264 S.C. 624, 628, 216 S.E.2d 541, 543 (1975).Â  An abuse of discretion occurs when the decision is controlled by an error of law or is based on factual findings that are without evidentiary support.Â 
Degenhart v. Burriss, 360 S.C. 497, 500, 602 S.E.2d 96, 97 (Ct. App. 2004). Â 
The purpose of alimony is to place the supported spouse, as close as is practical, in the same position of support as during the marriage.Â  Johnson v. Johnson, 296 S.C. 289, 300, 372 S.E.2d 107, 113 (Ct. App. 1988). Â If the claim for alimony is well-founded, the family court has the duty of making â€œan alimony award that is fit, equitable, and just.â€Â  Allen v. Allen, 347 S.C. 177, 184, 554 S.E.2d 421, 424 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  The family court must consider the following factors in awarding alimony: 

(1) the duration of the marriage together with the ages of the parties at the time of the marriage and at the time of the divorce or separate maintenance action between the parties; (2) the physical and emotional condition of each spouse; (3) the educational background of each spouse, together with need of each spouse for additional training or education in order to achieve that spouseâ€™s income potential; (4) the employment history and earning potential of each spouse; (5) the standard of living established during the marriage; (6) the current and reasonably anticipated earnings of both spouses; (7) the current and reasonably anticipated expenses and needs of both spouses; (8) the marital and nonmarital properties of the parties, including those apportioned to him or her in the divorce or separate maintenance action; (9) custody of the children, particularly where conditions or circumstances
render it appropriate that the custodian not be required to seek employment outside the home, or where the employment must be of a limited nature; (10) marital misconduct or fault of either or both parties, whether or not used as a basis for a divorce or separate maintenance decree if the misconduct affects or has affected the economic circumstances of the parties, or contributed to the breakup of the marriage, except that no evidence of personal conduct which may otherwise be relevant and material for the purpose of this subsection may be considered with regard to this subsection if the conduct took place subsequent to the happening of the earliest of (a) the formal signing of a written property or marital settlement agreement or (b) entry of a permanent order of separate maintenance and support or of a permanent order approving a property or marital settlement agreement between the parties; (11) the tax consequences to each party as a result of the particular form of support awarded; (12) the existence and extent of any support obligation from a prior marriage or for any other reason of either party; and (13) such other factors the court considers relevant.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-130(C) (Supp. 2005).
Further, the South Carolina Supreme Court has stated: â€œThree important factors in awarding periodic alimony are (1) the duration of the marriage; (2) the overall financial situation of the parties, especially the ability of the supporting spouse to pay; and (3) whether either spouse was more at fault than the other.â€Â  Patel v. Patel, 359 S.C. 515, 529, 599 S.E.2d 114, 121 (2004).Â  
In its order, the family court held: â€œ[N]either party is more at fault than the other [in] causing the breakup of the partiesâ€™ marriage.Â  Therefore, [Wifeâ€™s] request for alimony is denied.â€Â  The family court failed to mention any of the other thirteen factors or reference the statute.Â  Our case law and court rules are clear that the family court must make specific findings of fact on the record for each of the required factors that the court considers in making its decisions.Â 
Griffith v. Griffith, 332 S.C. 630, 646, 506 S.E.2d 526, 534-35 (Ct. App. 1998); see also Atkinson v. Atkinson, 279 S.C. 454, 456-57, 309 S.E.2d 14, 15 (Ct. App. 1983) (holding the family court, on remand, must set forth specific findings of fact concerning alimony factors).
Rule 26(a), SCRFC, provides that â€œ[a]n order or judgment pursuant to an adjudication in a domestic relations case shall set forth the specific findings of fact and conclusions of law to support the courtâ€™s decision.â€Â  When an order violates Rule 26(a), SCRFC, this Court may remand the matter to the family court, or if the record is sufficient, make its own findings of fact in accordance with the preponderance of the evidence. Â Holcombe v. Hardee, 304 S.C. 522, 524, 405 S.E.2d 821, 822 (1991).Â  
In the present case, we make our own findings of fact and find Wife is entitled to an award of alimony.Â  While these statutory factors are not the only ones to consider in awarding alimony, we believe they provide a sufficient basis to support an award of alimony. Â The parties were married for thirty-three years.Â  Husband earns significantly more than Wife. Â On their 2004 income taxes, Husband reported earnings of $41,969.41 and Wife reported earnings of $22,439.25.Â  Husbandâ€™s current expenses are $2,359.63 and Wifeâ€™s expenses are $2,210.69.Â  Because Husband earns significantly more than Wife, we surmise that while his expenses are only slightly higher, he can pay them with greater ease than Wife.Â  Husband appears to enjoy the same or a similar standard of living that he was accustomed to during their marriage. On the other hand, the record indicates that Wifeâ€™s standard of living was higher during the partiesâ€™ marriage, and due to the divorce, she now experiences financial difficulties. Â Â An award of alimony would place Wife in a position of support similar to that which she enjoyed during marriage. See Smith, 264 S.C. at 628, 216 S.E.2d at 543.
Because the record provides sufficient evidence to support an award, we find the family court erred in denying Wife alimony.Â  We remand to the family court to determine the proper amount of alimony considering all of the factors, not just fault.Â  Furthermore, once the family court determines the appropriate award, Wife is entitled to retroactive alimony from the date of the original order.
IV.Â  Attorneyâ€™s Fees
Wife argues the family court erred in denying her request for attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We agree.
The family court has discretion in deciding whether to award attorneyâ€™s fees, and its decision will not be overturned absent an abuse of discretion. Â Donahue v. Donahue, 299 S.C. 353, 365, 384 S.E.2d 741, 748 (1989).Â  An abuse of discretion occurs when the decision is controlled by an error of law or is based on factual findings that are without evidentiary support.Â 
Degenhart, 360 S.C. at 500, 602 S.E.2d at 97.Â  
Section 20-7-420(A)(38) of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005) authorizes the family court to award attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  In deciding whether to award attorneyâ€™s fees, the family court should consider: (1) each partyâ€™s ability to pay his or her own fee; (2) the beneficial results obtained by the attorney; (3) the partiesâ€™ respective financial conditions; and (4) the effect of the fee on each partyâ€™s standard of living.Â 
E.D.M., 307 S.C. at 476-77, 415 S.E.2d at 816.Â  If an award of attorneyâ€™s fees is appropriate, the reasonableness of the fees should be determined according to:
(1) the nature, extent, and difficulty of the case; (2) the time necessarily devoted to the case; (3) the professional standing of counsel; (4) the contingency of compensation; (5) the beneficial results obtained; and (6) the customary legal fees for similar services.Â 
Glasscock v. Glasscock, 304 S.C. 158, 161, 403 S.E.2d 313, 314 (1991).
As with alimony, â€œ[o]ur case law and court rules make clear that when a contract or statute authorizes an award of attorneyâ€™s fees, the trial court must make specific findings of fact on the record for each of the required factors to be considered.â€ Â Griffith, 332 S.C. at 646, 506 S.E.2d at 534-35; see also Atkinson, 279 S.C. at 457, 309 S.E.2d at 16 (remanding to the family court for specific findings of fact in determining whether to award attorneyâ€™s fees).Â  The family court did not make any findings of fact or acknowledge the appropriate factors in determining whether to award attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Accordingly, we remand the issue of attorneyâ€™s fees to the family court. 
Additionally, the award of alimony is a beneficial result, which will bear on the family courtâ€™s decision to award attorneyâ€™s fees. Â In light of this fact, the family court should reconsider the issue of attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Peirson v. Calhoun, 308 S.C. 246, 255, 417 S.E.2d 604, 609 (Ct. App. 1992); see also Epperly v. Epperly, 312 S.C. 411, 416, 440 S.E.2d 884, 886-87 (1994) (â€œAs to the beneficial result obtained, it is clear that Wife did not prevail in
the initial action. Â However, upon appeal, she has succeeded in part. Â Therefore, this issue is remanded to the [f]amily [c]ourt for reconsideration.â€).Â  On remand, the family court should consider all of the factors set forth in
E.D.M., make the appropriate findings of fact, and decide whether to award Wife attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  If the family court awards Wife attorneyâ€™s fees, it should determine what amount to award according to the factors provided in Glasscock.Â  
CONCLUSION
Accordingly the family courtâ€™s decision is
AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED.[1]
HEARN, C.J., KITTREDGE, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA

Submitted March 1, 2007 â€“ Filed March 7, 2007Â Â

Stephen L. Brown and Elizabeth B. Luzuriaga, Young Clement Rivers, LLP, of Charleston, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Sharon McCarthy filed a claim for compensation with the Workerâ€™s Compensation Commission.Â  The single commissioner denied her claim, and an appellate panel of the Commission (as the ultimate fact-finder) affirmed.Â  The circuit court, sitting in its appellate capacity, affirmed.Â  McCarthy appeals, and we affirm.[1]
1.  McCarthy first argues the Commission erred in rejecting the expert testimony of Lawrence C. Davis, a Microsoft certified systems engineer.Â Â  This argument fails because Davisâ€™s testimony was not rejected by the Commission.Â  It is clear from the record that the Commission both admitted and considered Davisâ€™ evidence.Â  The Commission simply did not assign it any significant weight.Â  The single commissioner concluded, â€œthe work order issued on June 27, 2002 carries little weight with regard to the issue of a causal relationship between the Claimantâ€™s work environment and her ongoing neck condition.â€Â  Such determinations of weight are within the purview of the Commission and will not be disturbed on appeal.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(5) (2006) (â€œThe court may not substitute its judgment for the judgment of the agency as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact.â€); see also Fields v. Regâ€™l Med. Ctr. Orangeburg, 363 S.C. 19, 25-26, 609 S.E.2d 506, 509 (2005) (â€œQualification of an expert and the admission or exclusion of his testimony is a matter within the sound discretion of the trial court . . . the trial courtâ€™s decision will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.â€).Â  â€œExpert medical testimony is designed to aid the Commission in coming to the correct conclusion; therefore, the Commission determines the weight and credit to be given to the expert testimony.Â  Once admitted, expert testimony is to be considered just like any other testimony.â€Â  Tiller v. Natâ€™l Health Care Ctr. of Sumter, 334 S.C. 333, 340, 513 S.E.2d 843, 846 (1999) (internal citations omitted).Â  
2.  McCarthy further argues the Commission applied an incorrect standard of proof to her claim.Â  McCarthyâ€™s argument relies on the statement in the Commissionâ€™s order that â€œsubstantial and convincing evidence connecting the Claimantâ€™s job to her injuryâ€ is required, arguing this is error and that the applicable standard is preponderance or greater weight of the evidence.Â  This issue is not preserved for review, as it was not ruled upon by the circuit court in its order and McCarthy did not make a Rule 59(e) motion to alter or amend the judgment. See Shealy v. Aiken County, 341 S.C. 448, 460, 535 S.E.2d 438, 444-45 (2000).
3.  McCarthy argues the Commissionâ€™s finding that she did not suffer a compensable work-related injury is not supported by substantial evidence in the record.Â  We disagree.Â  There is considerable and substantial evidence in the record that McCarthyâ€™s injuries did not have a provable link to her work conditions.Â  Dr. Marzluff, who treated McCarthyâ€™s condition for over a decade, stated that â€œI cannot say with a reasonable degree of medical certainty that the problems related to her work station were the causes of her neck pain.â€Â  Dr. Khoury corroborated Marzluffâ€™s evaluation, stating â€œit would have to be something pretty unusual about her work station that would have caused this problem.â€Â  The record contains substantial evidence to support the Commissionâ€™s finding that McCarthy did not suffer a compensable injury to her cervical spine arising out of her working conditions.Â  Accordingly, the finding must be affirmed.Â  Tiller, 334 S.C. at 338, 513 S.E.2d at 845 (â€œThis Court must affirm the findings of fact made by the Commission if they are supported by substantial evidence.â€).
4.  Finally, McCarthy disputes the Commissionâ€™s findings that she did not sustain a compensable emotional â€œpsychological overlayâ€ injury.Â  This argument fails because any â€œpsychological overlayâ€ claim is necessarily dependent upon an underlying compensable physical injury.Â  See Shealy, 341 S.C. at 457, 535 S.E.2d at 443 (â€œMental or nervous disorders are compensable accidental injuries under the statute when â€˜the emotional stimuli or stressors are incident to or arise from unusual or extraordinary conditions of employment.â€™â€).Â  Because we affirm the Commissionâ€™s finding that McCarthy did not suffer a compensable injury to her cervical spine arising out of her working conditions, there is no need to address this issue.Â  Whiteside v. Cherokee County Sch. Dist. No. One, 311 S.C. 335, 340-341, 428 S.E.2d 886, 889 (1993) (holding appellate court need not address remaining issues when resolution of prior issues is dispositive). 
AFFIRMED. 
ANDERSON, KITTREDGE, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Mary Green, as Guardian for Sateria Bettis, a minor,
Appellant,
v.
Judith Hoover, M.D., Cindy Besson, M.D., Margo Muniz, M.D., and Women's Health Associates, LLC,
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Aiken County
 Doyet A. Early, III, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-116
Submitted February 1, 2007 â€“ Filed March 7, 2007Â Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Jared Sullivan Newman, of Beaufort, for Appellant.
James D. Nance, of Aiken, Russell Harter, of Greenville, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Mary Green, as guardian for Sateria Bettis, a minor, appeals the trial courtâ€™s award of summary judgment to Judith Hoover, Cindy Besson, Margo Muniz, and Womenâ€™s Health Associates, LLC (collectively Doctors).Â  Green argues the trial court erred in its factual findings, which led to dismissing her medical negligence action, and its sanction dismissing her case was unduly harsh and not in conformity with South Carolina precedent.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
On April 12, 2004, Green brought a claim against Doctors for medical negligence. Â Thereafter, Doctors filed two motions to compel Green to provide information pertaining to her expert witness.Â  In July 2004, Green named her expert, but withdrew the expert on January 11, 2005, indicating she would get another expert.
On January 13, 2005, the trial court issued a scheduling order, which required Green to name an expert witness by April 1, 2005.Â  The scheduling order also required a deposition of the expert by May 15, 2005, and completion of all discovery by September 15, 2005.Â  On June 27, 2005, Doctors informed Green by letter that she had yet to provide notice of her expert in accordance with the scheduling order.Â  Doctors then requested that Green provide the expertâ€™s information at that time.Â  Green did not respond to Doctorsâ€™ request. Â 
On October 5, 2005, Doctors moved for summary judgment against Green.Â  On October 10, 2005, Greenâ€™s counsel moved to be relieved as counsel because he did not believe Green had a case and he considered it futile to continue the case.Â  On the same date, the trial court held a hearing on all pending motions.Â  The trial court denied Greenâ€™s counselâ€™s motion to be relieved and granted summary judgment to Aiken Regional Medical Center.[2]Â  The trial court held Doctorsâ€™ motions in abeyance because ten days notice had not been provided to Green.Â Â  
Also at the October 10th hearing, Green informed the trial court that she did not have an expert witness who could provide testimony of proximate cause and damages to sustain her case.Â  Because Green had ten (10) days to respond to Doctorsâ€™ motions for summary judgment, the trial court afforded Green ten (10) days to also name an expert witness and move to expand the scheduling order.Â  On October 12, 2005, Green named the expert in her supplemental answers to the Doctorsâ€™ interrogatories; however, she did not move to expand or amend the scheduling order.[3]Â  
On October 19, 2005, Doctors informed Green by letter that it was their position that the January 13th scheduling order remained in effect until it was amended by court order.Â  On November 2, 2005, Green provided the expertâ€™s affidavit to Doctors.Â  On November 7, 2005, Greenâ€™s counsel sought consent from Doctors to continue the hearing set for November 8, 2005, or that he be allowed to participate in the hearing by way of telephone, because he was, at the time, preparing for a different trial.Â  Doctors did not consent to a continuation of the hearing.Â  Greenâ€™s counsel also requested of the trial court a continuation on the same grounds, but the court denied the request.Â  On November 8th, Green sent Doctors her response opposing summary judgment, along with the expertâ€™s affidavit.Â  Green sent the trial court a copy of the response and affidavit via facsimile on the same date.Â  
Also on November 8th, in Greenâ€™s counselâ€™s absence, the trial court heard Doctorsâ€™ October 5th summary judgment motion.Â  The trial court granted the motion on November 10, 2005 on the grounds that Green had not complied with the scheduling order.Â  On November 28, 2005, Green moved to reconsider the summary judgment award and amend the scheduling order. Â Â The trial court denied Greenâ€™s motion for reconsideration on January 23, 2006 on the ground that Green neglected to timely move for an amendment of the scheduling order.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
When reviewing the circuit courtâ€™s order granting summary judgment, the appellate court is instructed to apply the same standard that governs the circuit court under Rule 56(c) of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure: summary judgment is proper when there is no genuine issue as to any material fact, and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  Fleming v. Rose, 350 S.C. 488, 493-94, 567 S.E.2d 857, 860 (2002).Â  To determine whether any triable issue of fact exists, the evidence and all inferences, which can reasonably be drawn therefrom, must be viewed in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.Â  Faile v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Juvenile Justice, 350 S.C. 315, 324, 566 S.E.2d 536, 540 (2002).Â  If triable issues exist, those issues must go to the jury.Â  Young v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Corr., 333 S.C. 714, 718, 511 S.E.2d 413, 415 (Ct. App. 1999).
On the other hand, summary judgment is not appropriate where further inquiry into the facts of the case is desirable to clarify the application of the law.Â  Vermeer Carolinaâ€™s, Inc. v. Wood/Chuck Chipper Corp., 336 S.C. 53, 59, 518 S.E.2d 301, 305 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  All ambiguities, conclusions, and inferences arising from the evidence must be construed most strongly against the moving party.Â  Bayle v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Transp., 344 S.C. 115, 120, 542 S.E.2d 736, 738 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  Even when there is no dispute as to evidentiary facts, but only as to the conclusions or inferences to be drawn from them, summary judgment should be denied.Â  See Hall v. Fedor, 349 S.C. 169, 173-74, 561 S.E.2d 654, 656 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  Summary judgment is a drastic remedy; it should therefore be cautiously invoked to prevent the improper deprivation of a trial of the disputed factual issues.Â Â  Lanham v. Blue Cross & Blue Shield, 349 S.C. 356, 363, 563 S.E.2d 331, 334 (2002).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.  Factual Findings for Summary Judgment 
Green contends the trial court erred in its factual findings, which led to dismissing her medical negligence action.Â  Green specifically contends the trial court erred in finding that she did not present her expertâ€™s affidavit to the trial court or opposing counsel.Â  We disagree.
A scheduling order may be altered or amended whenever justice so requires.Â  See Rule 26(f), SCRCP.Â  Accordingly, the trial court in this case informed Green of its willingness to amend the order, but only if Green both named her expert and moved to expand the order.Â  Within the ten-day period provided Green by court order, Green only named her expert, but did not move to expand the scheduling order.Â  Within the ten-day period, Doctors even reminded Green, by letter, that the January 13th scheduling order remained in effect until it was amended by court order.Â  However, Green still did not move to amend the scheduling order by October 20th.Â  Green, instead, waited until November 28, 2005, to move to amend the order.Â  
As the trial court concluded, â€œnotice of an expert witness after the time required by a scheduling order is no notice until, and if, the order is amended.â€Â  Therefore, even though Green presented her expertâ€™s affidavit to the trial court, she did not do so until November 8, 2005, eighteen days after the deadline given her by the trial court.Â  Because Green did not fully comply with the courtâ€™s order, her eventual submission of the expertâ€™s affidavit could not be considered. 
Moreover, and despite Greenâ€™s contention, the trial courtâ€™s finding that Green did not present her expert affidavit to the trial court or Doctors, did not ultimately lead to the trial courtâ€™s dismissal of Greenâ€™s medical negligence action.Â  The trial court dismissed the action because, at the time of the summary judgment hearing, the January 13th scheduling order was still in effect, and Green provided notice of her expert without amending the order. 
II.  Appropriateness of Sanction 
Green contends the trial courtâ€™s sanction dismissing her case was unduly harsh and not in conformity with South Carolina precedent.Â  We disagree. 
â€œIf a party fails to obey an order to provide or permit discovery, the trial court may impose sanctions such as striking pleadings, dismissing the action, or rendering a default judgment.â€Â 
Griffin Grading & Clearing v. Tire Serv. Equip. Mfg. Co., Inc., 334 S.C. 193, 198, 511 S.E.2d 716, 718 (Ct. App. 1999); Rule 37(b)(2)(B), SCRCP (stating that if a party fails to obey an order to permit discovery or fails to obey a scheduling order, the trial court may make an order refusing to allow the disobedient party to support or oppose designated claims or defenses or prohibiting him from introducing designated matters in evidence).Â  
Additionally, whenever a trial court orders default or dismissal as a sanction for discovery violation, or sanction itself results in default or dismissal, the trial court must determine whether there is some element of bad faith, willfulness, or gross indifference to the rights of other litigants.Â  Karppi v. Greenville Terrazzo Co., Inc., 327 S.C. 538, 543, 489 S.E.2d 679, 682 (Ct. App. 1997); Baughman v. Am. Tel. and Tel. Co., 306 S.C. 101, 109, 410 S.E.2d 537, 542 (1991) (holding that where the effect of excluding a witness as a sanction will be the same as granting judgment by default or dismissal, a preclusion order may be made only if there is some showing of willful disobedience or gross indifference to the rights of the adverse party).Â Â  
Here, even upon acknowledging that the exclusion of a witnessâ€™s testimony should not be lightly invoked, the trial court found that Green willfully disregarded the order of the court, to which she consented, establishing a schedule for discovery.Â  As further basis for the trial courtâ€™s finding of willfulness, the trial court acknowledged that the scheduling order not only required Green to provide notice of an expert by April 1, 2005, but the order also required Green to make the expert available for a deposition by May 15, 2005 and to complete discovery by September 15, 2005.Â  The trial court additionally acknowledged that Doctors notified Green, during June 2005, that she had not complied with the scheduling order and requested that she comply by providing notice of the expert.Â  
This case is distinct from Orlando v. Boyd, in which the Supreme Court reversed the trial courtâ€™s award of summary judgment on the ground that the appellantsâ€™ efforts to comply with the scheduling order did not constitute willful disobedience of the order.Â  320 S.C. 509, 466 S.E.2d 353 (1996).Â Â Â  In Orlando, the trial court issued a scheduling order, which required the plaintiffs to make their experts available for deposition by August 3, 1992.Â  Id. at 510, 466 S.E.2d at 354.Â  The plaintiffs did not comply with the scheduling order.Â  Id.Â  Following the respondentsâ€™ motion to dismiss, on September 9, 1992, the plaintiffs moved to extend the time to depose the expert.Â  Id.Â  The trial court denied the plaintiffâ€™s motion and granted respondentsâ€™ summary judgment motion on the basis of the plaintiffâ€™s failure to follow the scheduling order.Â  Id.Â  Upon review, the Supreme Court found there was neither evidence of intentional misconduct in the record which would warrant the exclusion of the expert, nor was there evidence the respondents were prejudiced by the failure to depose the expert.Â  Id. at 512, 466 S.E.2d at 355.Â  
As distinct from Orlando, in the present case, the record demonstrates that Green repeatedly failed to comply with the trial courtâ€™s orders.Â  Also, unlike Orlando, Green did not move to extend the scheduling order.Â  Based on Orlando, the trial courtâ€™s sanction dismissing Greenâ€™s case on the basis of failure to comply with more than one court order was not unduly harsh.
This case is also distinct from Kirkland v. Peoples Gas Co., upon which Green relies in support of this appeal.Â  269 S.C. 431, 237 S.E.2d 772 (1977).Â  In Kirkland, the Supreme Court determined whether proper notice had been given to appellants of respondentâ€™s witness, when appellant had the witnessâ€™s report, interviewed him prior to trial, and listed him as one of his own witnesses.Â  Id. at 435, 237 S.E.2d at 774.Â Â  In response to Appellantâ€™s motion to exclude Respondentâ€™s witness, the Supreme Court held that because Appellant had prior knowledge of the existence and testimony of the witness, exclusion of the witness was not justified, even if Respondent violated a circuit court rule.Â  Id.Â Â  
In the present case, exclusion of the expert could be justified because Doctors did not have an opportunity to depose the expert and had no knowledge that Green would name the same expert that she previously withdrew.Â  Therefore, the trial courtâ€™s sanction dismissing Greenâ€™s case, in conformity with South Carolina precedent, was not unduly harsh.
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, the trial court did not err in its factual findings or abuse its discretion in dismissing Greenâ€™s medical negligence case.Â  Accordingly, the trial courtâ€™s award of summary judgment is
 AFFIRMED.
BEATTY and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] Aiken Regional Medical Center is a former defendant in this matter, but is not a party to this appeal.Â  
[3] On this date, Green named the same expert in her supplemental answers as she initially named in July 2004, although she withdrew the expertâ€™s name based on the expertâ€™s alleged inability to provide adequate testimony to support her case.Â

text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Father, Appellant,
v.
John and Mary Doe, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Dorothy Mobley Jones, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2007-UP-117
Submitted March 1, 2007 â€“ Filed March 8, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
John D. Elliott, of Columbia, for Appellant.
James Fletcher Thompson, of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
Richard Giles Whiting, of Columbia, for Guardian Ad Litem.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Â Father appeals the family courtâ€™s order upholding the Doesâ€™ adoption of Child, finding Fatherâ€™s consent to the adoption was not required, and terminating Fatherâ€™s parental rights.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
Father and Mother[2] met in the fall of 2001 at a cub scout meeting for their sons.Â  Thereafter, Mother and Father had a brief romantic relationship wherein they had sexual intercourse on a few different occasions.
In late November 2001, Mother told Father that she was pregnant.Â  A pregnancy test confirmed Motherâ€™s assertion.Â  Thereafter, Mother informed Father that she wanted to have an abortion.Â  Father, at least in part motivated by his personal beliefs, argued against Mother having an abortion.Â  Nevertheless, Mother insisted on having the abortion and asked Father to assist her financially during this period.Â  Father gave Mother around $250.00.
In the ensuing weeks, Mother and Fatherâ€™s relationship, which was already strained, completely subsided.Â  Mother embarked on a â€œdrug bingeâ€ in the latter part of December and subsequently entered a rehab program in the Richland County area.Â  In February of 2002, Mother moved to the Shalom House, a halfway house in Anderson County, where she remained through the end of June 2002.Â  During this period, Mother and Father did not see one another.
Mother decided to put Child up for adoption and contacted Bethany Christian Services, an adoption agency in Columbia.Â  In June 2002, Mother provided Bethany with a sworn affidavit explaining, in relevant part:

[Child] of course has a birthfather, unfortunately his identity is unknown to me.Â  During the time (mid-Nov. â€™01) that she was conceived I was drinking and using drugs.Â  I had not had sex in several months before the few days in Nov. that I had sex with at least 3 men over a weekendâ€™s time.Â  

In July 2002, she provided Bethany with another affidavit stating she was unsuccessful in her attempts to discover the names of the three men with whom she had sex with in mid-November.Â  Motherâ€™s July affidavit further provides, â€œI feel as if I have exhausted all options of locating the father or knowing who it could be.â€
Child was born on August 11, 2002.Â  Mother then signed a Relinquishment for Adoption, which gave custody of Child to Bethany.Â  On August 16, 2002, Child was placed with her prospective adoptive parents, John and Mary Doe.Â  The Does published a notice of the adoption of Child in January and February of 2003; the notice provided that an action for the adoption of minor child Baby Doe, born to Jane Doe, has been filed.Â  In March 2003, the adoption was concluded and an adoption decree entered.
In November 2003, Father began to wonder whether Mother ever had an abortion.Â  Father asked Motherâ€™s mother about the abortion, and learned Mother actually gave Child up for adoption.Â  Motherâ€™s mother provided Father with pictures of Child that Father believed looked like him.[3]
Father then investigated the adoption of Child and discovered the Does were her adoptive parents.Â  In late November 2003, Father met with and informed John Doe that Child was Fatherâ€™s biological child.Â  During this initial meeting, Father offered to have a co-parenting relationship of some sort; John Doe refused Fatherâ€™s suggestion.Â  In January 2004, Fatherâ€™s attorney sent the Does a letter again inquiring whether they were willing to have a co-parenting situation and explaining that Father was willing to contribute financially.
In February 2004, after Father received no response from the Does, he initiated an action to set aside the adoption of Child and grant him sole entitlement to Childâ€™s legal and physical custody.Â  After a hearing, the family court upheld the adoption, found Father was not required to provide consent, terminated Fatherâ€™s parental rights, and held removal of Child from the Does would be against Childâ€™s best interest.Â  This appeal followed.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œWhen reviewing the factual determinations of the family court, an appellate court may take its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.â€Â  Woodall v. Woodall, 322 S.C. 7, 10, 471 S.E.2d 154, 157 (1996).Â  Where the evidence is disputed, the appellate court may adhere to the findings of the family court, who was in a superior position to judge the witnessesâ€™ demeanor and veracity.Â  Id.Â  However, â€œthe appellate courtâ€™s broad scope of review does not relieve the appellant of the burden of showing that the family court committed error.â€Â  Ex parte Morris, 367 S.C. 56, 62, 624 S.E.2d 649, 652 (2006).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Father contends the family court erred in failing to set aside the adoption of Child based on Motherâ€™s alleged extrinsic fraud.Â  Specifically, Father argues Motherâ€™s failure to name Father as a potential father in her affidavit to Bethany deprived Father of the opportunity to participate in the adoption proceeding.Â  We disagree.
Section 20-7-1800(B) of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2006) provides that the family court may set aside a decree of adoption on the ground of â€œextrinsic fraud,â€ which is defined as â€œfraud that induces a person not to present a case or deprives a person of the opportunity to be heard.â€Â  
In Brown v. Malloy, this court analyzed whether a decree of adoption could be set aside where a birthfather alleged birthmother fraudulently precluded his participation in the adoption proceedings.Â  345 S.C. 113, 546 S.E.2d 195 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  In Brown, the birthmother provided the incorrect county of the childâ€™s conception and the birthfatherâ€™s residence which led to publication of the notice of adoption proceedings in a county in which birthfather did not reside.Â  Id. at 116-17, 546 S.E.2d at 196-97.Â  The family court found the birthmotherâ€™s misrepresentations were unintentional and upheld the adoption.Â  Id. at 119, 546 S.E.2d at 198.Â  This court affirmed the family courtâ€™s decision based on our determination that the issue was â€œheavily dependent on credibility.â€Â  Id.Â  Nevertheless, our holding in Brown suggests that extrinsic fraud may result if a birthmother intentionally misrepresents facts that prevent the birthfather from being notified of the possible adoption of child.Â  Id. at 118-19, 546 S.E.2d at 197-98.
In this case, the record indicates Mother has always believed that Father was not Childâ€™s biological father.Â  Consistent with her affidavit to Bethany, Mother testified that she did not even know she was pregnant when she confronted Father about being pregnant and sought money for an abortion, explaining that she was just trying to get â€œmoney out of a man.â€Â  Similarly, when confronted about failing to give Father a chance to take a DNA test, Mother explained, â€œI didnâ€™t believe he was the father.â€Â  Mother also testified that she did not remember ever having sex with Father without using a condom.Â  Further, after learning Father was contesting the adoption, Mother phoned Father and left a message on his answering machine in which she assured him there was a â€œ99.9 percent guarantee that you are not the father . . . .â€Â  Likewise, in a letter Mother sent to the Does after Father began to contest the adoption, Mother apologized for â€œall that has happened,â€ and explained, â€œI did the best I could and I thought I was doing everything right.â€
We recognize there is evidence in the record that indicates Mother lied to Father about getting an abortion and Father believed the lie until he learned otherwise in November 2003.Â  We also acknowledge there is testimony from one of Fatherâ€™s friends about a long conversation they had in which Father expressed his deep regrets about the supposed abortion of Child.Â  The friend also testified Father appeared genuinely excited and surprised after learning Child was not aborted.
Nevertheless, after a thorough review of the record, we find Father failed to provide clear and convincing proof that Mother committed extrinsic fraud by neglecting to identify him as a possible father.Â  In this case, the family court, who saw and heard the witnesses, found Mother credible and Father not credible.Â  In this instance, we defer to the family courtâ€™s findings because the evidence in the record supports the courtâ€™s holding.Â  Having found that Father failed to prove Mother committed extrinsic fraud, we need not address Fatherâ€™s remaining issues.Â  See Whiteside v. Cherokee County Sch. Dist. No. One, 311 S.C. 335, 340, 428 S.E.2d 886, 889 (1993) (stating the appellate court need not address remaining issues when resolution of prior issue is
dispositive).
 AFFIRMED.
 GOOLSBY and STILWELL, JJ., and CURETON, A.J., concur.

[1] Â We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] Â This case is sealed.Â  As such, all names are omitted in order to protect the partiesâ€™ identities.Â  
[3] Â In April 2004, DNA test results confirmed that there was a 99.97% probability Father was Childâ€™s birthfather.

PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Joseph Eubanks, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Aiken County
 Doyet A. Early, III, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-118
Submitted March 1, 2007 â€“ Filed March 14, 2007Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Appellate Defender Kathrine H. Hudgins, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Teresa A Knox, S.C. Dept. of Probation Parole & Pardon, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Joseph Eubanks appeals the revocation of his probation, arguing the circuit court erred by not making a finding his probation violation was willful.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
Eubanks pleaded guilty to third-degree burglary in November 2001.Â  He was sentenced to four years, suspended upon ninety-six daysâ€™ credit for time served and two yearsâ€™ probation.Â  Eubanks stopped reporting to his probation officer in April of 2002, and his revocation hearing was held on January 16, 2006.Â  
At the revocation hearing, Eubanksâ€™ attorney explained that Eubanksâ€™ failure to report coincided with the birth of his child.Â  Eubanks had been behind on paying his supervision fees, and he worried that his probation would be revoked.Â  He later turned himself in â€œbecause he knew that [the violation] was out there.Â  It was going to happen sometime, and he just, basically, wanted to get it over with . . . .â€ The circuit court revoked three years of the suspended sentence, terminated Eubanksâ€™ probation, and converted his past due fees into a civil judgment.Â  This appeal followed.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Eubanks argues the circuit court erred in revoking his probation without making a finding that his violation was willful.Â  We find this issue is not preserved for our review. 
At the revocation hearing, Eubanks did not contest the violations of his probation.Â  Because the issue of willfulness was never raised to the circuit court, we cannot now consider this argument on appeal.Â  See State v. Conyers, 326 S.C. 263, 266, 487 S.E.2d 181, 183 (1997) (holding that an issue must be raised to and ruled upon by circuit court to be preserved for appellate review); cf. State v. Hamilton, 333 S.C. 642, 648, 511 S.E.2d 94, 98 (Ct. App. 1999) (finding appellantâ€™s argument that his probation violation was not willful was preserved for appeal because â€œthe essence of defense counselâ€™s argument at the revocation hearing was that the violation was not willful because [appellant] believed his probationary period had terminatedâ€).
 AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and GOOLSBY and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Corbin v. City of Columbia
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Charlie L. Corbin, Respondent,
v.
City of Columbia, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â John C. Hayes, III, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-120
Submitted March 1, 2007 â€“ Filed March 14, 2007Â Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Kenneth E. Gaines, of Columbia, for Appellant.
J. Leeds Barroll, IV, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: The City of Columbia appeals from the circuit courtâ€™s order affirming the order of the Appellate Panel of the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission, which awarded benefits to Charlie Corbin for sustaining a repetitive trauma injury to his back.Â  The City argues that Corbinâ€™s claim should be barred because it was not filed within the two-year statute of limitations period and because Corbin failed to give the City notice within ninety days of the accident.Â  We affirm.[1]  
FACTS
Corbin began working as a nighttime garbage collector for the City of Columbia Sanitation Department in 1994.Â  His truck did not have a â€œclaw,â€ the device which lifts up trash cans automatically, so Corbin and an assistant had to manually lift the trash cans to dump them into the truck.Â  
Corbin experienced back problems, and on February 28, 2002, he visited Dr. Brett Gunter.Â  Dr. Gunter diagnosed Corbin as having lumbar spinal stenosis with neurogenic claudication.Â  Corbin was out of work until March 4, 2002, and when he returned to work, Dr. Gunter restricted Corbin from lifting more than ten pounds.Â  With that restriction, Corbin was unable to work for the sanitation department because it did not have any light duty positions.Â  Corbin returned to Dr. Gunterâ€™s office seeking a change to his weight lifting restrictions, which he received.Â  
Corbin returned to his employment as a trash collector, and his back pain continued.Â  On October 3, 2002, Corbin ceased his employment with the City due to his injury, and he had surgery on his back later that month.Â  
On June 9, 2004, Corbin filed a Form 50 with the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission for a work-related, repetitive trauma injury to his back.Â  The City argued Corbinâ€™s claim was barred by the two-year statute of limitations because his injury occurred in February of 2002.Â  The City further argued, inter alia, that Corbin failed to provide the City with notice of his accident within ninety days.Â  The single commissioner disagreed and awarded Corbin benefits.Â  The Appellate Panel adopted the order of the single commissioner, and the circuit court affirmed.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The Administrative Procedures Act establishes the standard by which to review decisions from the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission.Â  Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 134-35, 276 S.E.2d 304, 306 (1981).Â  Any review of the Appellate Panelâ€™s factual findings is governed by the substantial evidence standard.Â  Bursey v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 360 S.C. 135, 141, 600 S.E.2d 80, 84 (Ct. App. 2004); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6)(e) (2005).Â  Accordingly, when confronted with a challenge to a factual determination by the Appellate Panel, this courtâ€™s review is limited to deciding whether the Appellate Panelâ€™s decision is supported by substantial evidence.Â  Rodriguez v. Romero, 363 S.C. 80, 84, 610 S.E.2d 488, 490 (2005).Â  â€œSubstantial evidence is not a mere scintilla of evidence, but is evidence that, considering the record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion the agency reached.â€ Â Pratt v. Morris Roofing, Inc., 357 S.C. 619, 622, 594 S.E.2d 272, 274 (2004).Â  However, where the Appellate Panelâ€™s decision is controlled by an error of law, this courtâ€™s review is plenary.Â  Lizee v. S.C. Dept. of Mental Health, 367 S.C. 122, 126, 623 S.E.2d 860, 862 (Ct. App. 2005).
LAW/ANALYSIS
The City first argues the circuit court erred in finding Corbinâ€™s claim was timely filed.Â  We disagree.
Pursuant to section 42-15-40 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2006), a claim for workersâ€™ compensation must be filed within two years of the date of accidental injury.Â Â Â  When the injury results from repetitive trauma, the statute of limitations begins to run from the last day of exposure, which is the last day of work.Â  Schurlknight v. City of North Charleston, 352 S.C. 175, 179, 574 S.E.2d 194, 196 (2002).
In the case before us, there is substantial evidence to support the Appellate Panelâ€™s determination that Corbinâ€™s injury resulted from repetitive trauma.Â  Dr. Gunter opined that based on his examinations of Corbin and Corbinâ€™s work history, Corbinâ€™s injury was caused by repetitive trauma to the back.Â  Corbin also testified that his every day job duties caused his back problems, explaining that the lifting of boxes and constant climbing into and out of the truck bothered his back.Â  
Because there is substantial evidence Corbinâ€™s injury resulted from repetitive trauma, his Form 50 needed to be filed within two years of his last day of work to be timely.[2]Â Â  The parties agree Corbinâ€™s last day of work was October 3, 2002, and Corbinâ€™s Form 50 was filed by June 9, 2004, which was within the two year-limitation period.Â  Accordingly, we find no merit to the Cityâ€™s argument that Corbinâ€™s claim should be barred.
Next, the City argues Corbin failed to provide notice within ninety days that his injury was work-related.Â  We disagree, finding substantial evidence in the record to support the Appellate Panelâ€™s finding that notice was timely made.
Corbin testified that in March 2002, he explained the injury and its repetitive trauma nature to his supervisor. Corbinâ€™s supervisor testified that he had â€œconstantâ€ discussion with Corbin about his worsening conditions after this March 2002 discussion.Â  Furthermore, Corbin presented notes from his physician to his employer shortly before he had surgery in October.Â  
Based on the foregoing, we find substantial evidence supports the Appellate Panelâ€™s finding that Corbinâ€™s claim was timely filed and the City was given timely notice.Â  Accordingly, the order of the circuit court is
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and GOOLSBY and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] The City also seems to argue that the date of injury should have been February 28, 2002, when he first saw Dr. Gunter.Â  Although Corbin was out of work for a few days after that visit, it is undisputed he returned to work on March 4 and worked continuously until October 3, 2002.Â  The statute of limitations begins to run the last day of work, not the day the claimant learns an injury is work-related.Â  See White v. Medical University of South Carolina, 355 S.C. 560, 566, 586 S.E.2d 157, 160-61 (Ct. App. 2003) (â€œ[E]ven if substantial evidence supported the commissionâ€™s determination that White knew since 1997 that his back pain was work-related, the statute of limitations did not begin to run until the last day of exposure â€“ Whiteâ€™s last day of work in April of 2000.â€).
