In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        The State of South Carolina, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Bryan Floyd, Defendant, and Beach Bonding Company, Bondsman, Palmetto Surety Corporation, Surety, Defendants,
        of whom Palmetto Surety Corporation is the Appellant.
      
    
  

AND

  
    
      
        The State of South Carolina, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Boris V. Ojasoo, Defendant, and Beach Bonding Company, Bondsman, Palmetto Surety Corporation, Surety, Defendants,
        of whom Palmetto Surety Corporation is the Appellant. 
      
    
  

AND

  
    
      
        The State of South Carolina, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Ronald Scott Renwrick, Defendant, and Beach Bonding Company, Bondsman, Palmetto Surety Corporation, Surety, Defendants,
        of whom Palmetto Surety Corporation is the Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
Â Steven H. John, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-121
Submitted March 1, 2007 â€“ Filed March 15, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      Robert T. Williams, Sr., of Williams, Steigner & Brink, P.A., of Lexington, for Appellant.
      Solicitor Bradley C. Richardson of Conway, for Respondent.
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  This case is an appeal from a bond estreatment matter involving several defendants.[1]Â  Palmetto Surety Corporation (Palmetto Surety) appeals from orders of the circuit court (1) denying Palmetto Suretyâ€™s motions for relief of judgment and (2) affirming consent orders partially estreating the bonds on defendants Bryan Floyd, Ronald Scott Renwrick, and Boris V. Ojasoo. Â We affirm.[2]
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
In September and October 2003, Priscilla Spivey signed appearance recognizance bonds as surety on behalf of the above named defendants.Â  Each bond noted the name of the surety company as Beach Bonding Company, and attached Powers of Attorney from Palmetto Surety appointing â€œthe below named agent,â€ Spivey, as Palmetto Suretyâ€™s attorney-in-fact to execute and deliver on itâ€™s behalf, as surety, a bail bond.Â  All three of the defendants failed to appear in court as required and Notices of Forfeited Recognizance were filed in the Clerk of Courtâ€™s office on February 24, 2004 as to each defendant.Â  A bond estreatment hearing was scheduled regarding all three defendants for April 5, 2004.Â  However, in lieu of a hearing, the parties reached a settlement and on April 16, 2004, entered into consent orders, estreating $4,500 on each defendantâ€™s bond.Â  Each of the consent orders was signed by Spivey, as representative for Beach Bonding Company and for Palmetto Surety.Â  
On December 9, 2004, Palmetto Surety filed a motion for relief of judgment pursuant to Rule 60, SCRCP asserting, among other things, that Palmetto Surety had not been properly notified of the bond estreatment hearing, that the bond itself was not properly signed so as to bind Palmetto Surety, and Palmetto Surety did not authorize the signing of the consent order.Â  A hearing was held on the motion on January 5, 2006.Â  At that time, Palmetto Surety argued (1) that it did not authorize the signing of the consent orders; (2) that it did not â€œowe the money to begin withâ€ because Spivey did not sign the bonds themselves as an agent for Palmetto Surety and the attached Powers of Attorney were merely exhibits that failed to indicate Palmetto Surety accepted the underwriting of the bonds; and (3) the notices of recognizance sent to Palmetto Surety were insufficient to put Palmetto Surety on notice that it had reason to attend the bond estreatment hearing.Â  The State countered, if the court found notices of the bond estreatment hearings were proper, Palmetto Surety should have appeared at that time to argue there was no agency relationship to bind Palmetto Surety and, having failed to appear, Palmetto Surety waived the issue.Â  The State further argued that there was an existing express agency relationship between Beach Bonding and Palmetto Surety and Palmetto Surety was required to file paperwork with the clerk of court to relieve it of that relationship with Beach Bonding.
The trial court orally ruled that the records filed with the clerk of court and documentation provided by the State indicated that proper notice was given to Palmetto Surety, that no representative appeared on its behalf to argue against Spiveyâ€™s authority or the bond forfeiture request, and Palmetto Surety therefore waived any arguments regarding Spiveyâ€™s authority when it failed to appear and present evidence at the hearing.Â  The court additionally found that Spivey did have authority to bind Palmetto Surety as she had an established business relationship representing Palmetto Surety in these matters, and that documentation had been filed with the clerk of court indicating, at that time, Spivey had authority to write bonds that were backed by Palmetto Surety, and there had been no filing with the clerk of court that withdrew that authority.Â  The trial court also found Palmetto Surety had given Spivey Powers of Attorney documentation thereby establishing an apparent agency such that Spivey had the authority to enter into the consent orders.Â  By written order dated January 17, 2006, the trial court held that notice of the April 5, 2004 bond estreatment hearings was proper as to both Beach Bonding and Palmetto Surety, as the notices were sent by certified return receipt mail to each party, and because any agency argument should have been made at that hearing, such argument was deemed waived.Â  The court further held, assuming arguendo that the agency argument was properly raised at the motion for relief of judgment hearing, an agency relationship between the bondsman and Palmetto Surety did exist at the time and that the Powers of Attorney and bonds were properly executed so as to bind the bondsman and Palmetto Surety.Â  Accordingly, the court determined the motions for relief of judgment should be denied, and it affirmed the estreatment of $4,500 as to each defendant's bond.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Whether to grant or deny a motion under Rule 60(b)[3] lies within the sound discretion of the judge.Â  BB & T v. Taylor, 369 S.C. 548, 551, 633 S.E.2d 501, 502 (2006).Â  This courtâ€™s standard of review is therefore limited to determining whether the trial court committed an abuse of discretion.Â  Id. at 551, 633 S.E.2d at 502-03.Â  An abuse of discretion arises where the trial courtâ€™s ruling is controlled by an error of law or where it is based on factual conclusions that are without evidentiary support.Â  Id. at 551, 633 S.E.2d at 503.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Palmetto Surety couches its appeal as to each of the defendantsâ€™ bonds in a single issue, asserting that the trial court â€œerred in estreating [each of the defendantsâ€™] bond[s] and in requiring Palmetto Surety Corporation to be responsible for same where [Palmetto Surety was] not a party properly noted on the notice of forfeiture recognizance nor [was Palmetto Surety] properly noted on the bond instrument itself and [Palmetto Surety] was not subject to the consent order signed by Priscilla Spivey.â€Â  It argues that the notices of recognizance failed to include Palmetto Surety in the caption of the notices, as well as on the face of the notices indicating the parties to whom they were addressed.Â  Palmetto Surety further maintains that Spivey signed the bonds only as surety for Beach Bonding, and the attached Powers of Attorney reveal her authority was limited as they appointed her only to execute the bond, and specified Spivey was not authorized to act as agent for receipt of service of process.Â  Palmetto Surety contends, because it was not â€œsummonedâ€ as required by statute, the notice mailed to it was insufficient to bind it.Â Â  Â 
The trial court based its ruling on two alternative grounds: (1) that Palmetto Surety received notice of the bond estreatment hearings in these matters and therefore waived any issue as to the existence of an agency relationship when it failed to appear and argue the issue at the bond estreatment hearings and (2) even if the agency argument was properly raised in the motion for relief hearing, an agency relationship did in fact exist so as to bind Palmetto Surety.Â  The trial courtâ€™s oral ruling found that Spivey had authority to bind Palmetto Surety based on her established business relationship representing Palmetto Surety in these matters, as well as the existence of documentation that had been filed with the clerk of court indicating she had authority to write bonds that were backed by Palmetto Surety but for which there was no subsequent filing with the clerk of court to withdraw that authority.Â  The trial court also determined Palmetto Surety had given Spivey Powers of Attorney documentation establishing an apparent agency.Â  Accordingly, the court held Spivey had the authority to enter into the consent orders.Â  
We hold Palmetto Surety has failed to challenge the trial courtâ€™s alternative finding on the existence of an agency relationship.Â  In its brief, Palmetto Surety asserts that it was not subject to the consent orders signed by Spivey.Â  It does so, however, in a conclusory manner and does not specifically challenge the trial courtâ€™s finding that an agency relationship existed between the bondsman and Palmetto Surety which acted to bind Palmetto Surety.Â  Houck v. State Farm Fire and Cas. Ins. Co., 366 S.C. 7, 17 n. 5, 620 S.E.2d 326, 332 n. 5 (2005) (noting an issue is abandoned if the appellantâ€™s brief treats it in a conclusory manner).Â  
The closest Palmetto Surety comes to arguing against an agency relationship appears to be its assertion that the Powers of Attorney did not authorize Spivey to sign the consent orders on its behalf.Â  The thrust of Palmetto Suretyâ€™s argument as to agency in this regard is that, because Spivey signed the bond instruments themselves only as surety for Beach Bonding and not Palmetto Surety, and because the Powers of Attorney attached to the bonds revealed the authority of Spivey is â€œlimited to appearance bond . . . .[and Spivey]Â  is appointed only to execute the bondâ€ consistent with that power, â€œthe power did not authorizeÂ  . . . anything beyond signing the bond itself,â€ thereby rendering the consent orders ineffective to bind Palmetto Surety.Â  (emphasis in original)Â  Palmetto does not, however, challenge the trial courtâ€™s findings of an agency relationship based on the established relationship between the bondsman and Palmetto Surety, nor on the documentation of that relationship filed with the clerk of court along with the lack of any filing regarding the withdrawal of that agency relationship.Â  Thus, even if we were to find Palmetto Suretyâ€™s argument sufficient to challenge the courtâ€™s finding of apparent authority based on the Powers of Attorney, Palmetto Surety has failed to argue against the trial courtâ€™s determination that an agency relationship existed as a result of the established relationship between Spivey and Palmetto Surety, as well as its finding of agency based on the documents filed with the clerk of court.Â  Further, the argument Palmetto Surety raises on appeal regarding the limited authority accorded Spivey by the Powers of Attorney was never argued below.[4] Â Because Palmetto Surety did not argue to the trail court that Spiveyâ€™s authority was limited by the Powers of Attorney, this argument is not preserved for our review.Â  Taylor v. Medenica, 324 S.C. 200, 216, 479 S.E.2d 35, 43 (1996) (noting an issue not raised in the trial court will not be considered on appeal;Â  an issue is not preserved if a party argues one ground for objection at trial and another ground on appeal).Â  
As there is no other argument made by Palmetto to challenge the trial courtâ€™s ruling on the agency relationship, this finding by the trial court is affirmed.Â  South Carolina Tax Commâ€™n v. Gaston Copper Recycling Corp., 316 S.C. 163, 170, 447 S.E.2d 843, 847 (1994) (holding an appellate court will affirm where an appellant fails to appeal the alternative ground of a trial courtâ€™s ruling);Â  Biales v. Young, 315 S.C. 166, 168, 432 S.E.2d 482, 484 (1993) (holding the failure to challenge an alternative ground for a holding constitutes abandonment of the issue and precludes consideration on appeal).Â  Because we affirm the trial courtâ€™s ruling on the agency issue, we need not address Palmetto Suretyâ€™s argument regarding notice of the bond estreatment hearing.Â  See Futch v. McAllister Towing of Georgetown, Inc., 335 S.C. 598, 613, 518 S.E.2d 591, 598 (1999) (holding an appellate court need not address remaining issues when disposition of a prior issue is dispositive.).
CONCLUSION
In conclusion, we hold Palmetto Surety failed to challenge the trial courtâ€™s ruling that an agency relationship did in fact exist such that Spivey had authority to bind Palmetto Surety.Â  Because Palmetto Surety failed to challenge this alternative ground, the orders below are
AFFIRMED.
HUFF, BEATTY, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] Because these matters were heard at the same time, in the same hearing, resulting in the same transcript, and involve the same issues, we have consolidated these cases on appeal.Â  See Rule 214, SCACR (â€œWhere there is more than one appeal from the same order, judgment, decision or decree, or where the same question is involved in two or more appeals in different cases, the appellate court may, in its discretion, order the appeal to be consolidated.â€).
[2] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[3] While Palmetto Surety did not specify whether it was moving from relief of judgment under Rule 60(a) or (b), SCRCP, it is clear Palmetto Surety never asserted there was any clerical mistake that would entitle it to relief under Rule 60(a).Â  We therefore treat the motions as having been brought pursuant to Rule 60 (b), SCRCP, which provides relief of final judgment for the following reasons:Â  (1) mistake, inadvertence, surprise, or excusable neglect;Â  (2) newly discovered evidence;Â  (3) fraud, misrepresentation, or other misconduct of an adverse party; (4) the judgment is void;Â  (5) the judgment has been satisfied, released, or discharged, or is based upon a prior judgment which has been reversed or otherwise vacated, or it is no longer equitable that the judgment should have prospective application.
[4] Before the trial court, Palmetto Surety only argued it was never liable on the bonds themselves because Spivey failed to sign on behalf of Palmetto Surety on the face of the bonds, an issue it does not continue to maintain on appeal.Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Delores D. Leonard, Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      Kershaw County, State of South Carolina, Respondent.
    
  


Appeal From Kershaw County
Â James R. Barber, III, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-122
Submitted March 1, 2007 â€“ Filed March 15, 2007Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Gerald F. Smith, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Â J. Kennedy DuBose, Jr. and Jonathan M. Robinson, of Camden, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Delores Leonard, a former part-time magistrate for Kershaw County, appeals the circuit courtâ€™s dismissal of her action for unpaid wages pursuant to the Magistratesâ€™ Pay Act.[1]Â  We affirm.[2]
FACTS
In 1996, Leonard began working as a part-time magistrate for Kershaw County, and she continued in this capacity until her resignation in April 2003. As a magistrate, Leonard worked twenty hours a week and was â€œon-callâ€ seventy-nine hours per week.Â  Leonard wrote to the chief magistrate on September 15, 2000, requesting compensation for her â€œon-callâ€ hours.Â  This letter from Leonard was followed by a letter to the Kershaw County Administrator from Leonardâ€™s attorney, inquiring about Leonardâ€™s claim for â€œon-callâ€ hoursâ€™ compensation.Â  The Countyâ€™s attorney responded by letter on January 22, 2003, explaining that after discussing the matter with the County Administrator and Chief Magistrate â€œit has been determined that Magistrate Delores D. Leonard is being appropriately compensated.â€ 
In February 2003, Leonard filed an action for unpaid wages pursuant to the Payment of Wages Act,[3] alleging that the County failed to pay her for the time she spent â€œon-call.â€Â  The County filed a motion to dismiss, which was granted.Â  A panel of our court affirmed the dismissal, finding Leonard should have filed her claim pursuant to the Magistratesâ€™ Compensation Act because it provided the exclusive remedy for magistrates with disputes over wages.Â  Leonard v. Kershaw County, 2005-UP-164 (Ct. App. 2005).
On July 15, 2004, while her case seeking relief pursuant to the Payment of Wages Act was pending, Leonard filed an action for unpaid wages pursuant to the Magistratesâ€™ Pay Act.Â  The County again moved to dismiss the case, arguing Leonard failed to file for judicial review within thirty days of the Countyâ€™s final decision pursuant to section 1-23-380 of the South Carolina Code.[4]Â  Leonard argued that the thirty-day period for judicial review had not yet begun because section 22-8-50(B) of the South Carolina Code requires that there first be a formal hearing.Â  
After a hearing on the matter, the circuit court found the January 22, 2003 letter from the Countyâ€™s attorney denying Leonard additional compensation was the final decision of the County.Â  Because Leonard failed to request judicial review within thirty days of that letter, the circuit court granted the Countyâ€™s motion to dismiss.Â  
Leonard filed a Rule 59(e) motion, arguing the circuit court failed to rule on whether Leonard received a hearing pursuant to section 22-8-50(B) of the South Carolina Code.Â  The circuit court denied the motion to reconsider.Â  This appeal followed.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Leonard argues she is entitled to a hearing pursuant to section 22-8-50(B) of the South Carolina Code, and because she has not been afforded this hearing, the circuit court erred in dismissing her action as untimely.Â  We disagree.
Section 1-23-380 of the South Carolina Code requires that review of the Countyâ€™s decision be â€œinstituted by serving and filing notice of appeal . . . within thirty days after the final decision of the agency . . . .â€Â  The thirty day timeline is triggered, not by when or whether a hearing was held, but by the issuance of a final decision.Â  
In Cox v. County of Florence, 337 S.C. 340, 523 S.E.2d 776 (1999), three part-time magistrates sued Florence County for wages they claimed to have earned while working extra hours.Â  Florence County denied the magistrates relief in a letter.Â  Id. at 344, 523 S.E.2d at 778.Â  On appeal, our supreme court found this letter, which provided the magistrates with written notice of Florence Countyâ€™s decision, triggered the thirty-day period during which the magistrates could seek judicial review of Florence Countyâ€™s decision.Â  Id.
Here, Leonard received written notice of the Countyâ€™s decision in January 2003. She did not file this action until July 2004, well outside the thirty-day window for seeking judicial review.Â  Accordingly, the order of the circuit court is
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and GOOLSBY and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

[1] South Carolina Code Â§ 22-8-10, et seq.
[2] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[3] South Carolina Code Â§ 41-10-10, et seq.
[4] This code section is part of the South Carolina Administrative Procedures Act.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
        v.
        Roger Platt, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Florence County
Â J. Mark Hayes, II, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-123
Submitted March 1, 2007 â€“ Filed March 15, 2007Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Appellate Defender Eleanor Duffy Cleary, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Edgar Lewis Clements, III, of Florence, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Roger Platt appeals his convictions for armed robbery and possession of a weapon during a crime of violence, arguing the trial court erred by refusing to suppress the victimâ€™s identification of him.Â  Specifically, Platt argues the show-up identification was unreliable under the totality of the circumstances.Â  We affirm.[1] 
FACTS
At 9:30 p.m. on March 9, 2004, Ryan Brown was pumping gas at a service station in Florence County when he was approached by a man who asked, â€œYo, man, you want some green?â€ Ryan declined the offer and drove away to his friend Jimmy Brownâ€™s house.Â  
After arriving at Jimmyâ€™s house, Ryan invited Jimmy out to his car to see the new TV he had purchased.Â  When both Ryan and Jimmy were in Ryanâ€™s car, Ryan stepped outside to take a phone call.Â  Suddenly, the man who had approached him at the gas station appeared, took Ryanâ€™s phone, grabbed Ryan by the collar, and announced that Ryan was coming with him.Â  Ryan pushed the man away and ran to the safety of Jimmyâ€™s home where he asked someone inside to call the police.Â  Jimmy, meanwhile, locked himself in the car to remain out of harmâ€™s way.Â  
The police arrived shortly.Â  Ryan described his assailant as a black male who was approximately five foot seven inches tall and between 160 and 170 pounds, wearing blue jeans, a blue shirt with a stripe on it, and a gray toboggan or bandana.Â  Ryan and Jimmy drove around the area with police, and Ryan recognized a car on the side of the road as the one he had seen his assailant exit at the service station.Â  However, neither Ryan nor Jimmy could identify the man standing next to the vehicle.Â  As the victims continued to ride with police, Ryan recognized his assailant walking down the side of the road, but by the time the police cruiser turned around, the man was gone.Â Â  
The police set up a perimeter, and Platt was found hiding in the bushes with Ryanâ€™s cell phone within a few feet of him.Â  Both Ryan and Jimmy identified Platt as the perpetrator, and according to the officer with whom they spoke, both men were one hundred percent certain of the identification. When Platt was booked, he reported being five feet eight inches tall and 180 pounds.Â  He was wearing a black shirt with a stripe on it and a toboggan.Â  Platt also had little braids in his hair, which the victims never reported to the police and which the trial court opined were major physical identifying marks of Platt.Â  
Prior to trial, Platt made a motion to suppress both Ryanâ€™s and Jimmyâ€™s identification of him.Â  The trial court suppressed Jimmyâ€™s identification, finding his view of the assailant was obscured because he observed the assailant through the rearview mirror and through the carâ€™s heavily tinted windows. However, the trial court refused to suppress Ryanâ€™s identification, finding that although the show-up identification was unduly suggestive it was nonetheless reliable under the totality of the circumstances.Â  Despite the trial courtâ€™s concern regarding Ryanâ€™s failure to mention Plattâ€™s braids to police, the court ultimately concluded it would be for the jury to conclude how much weight to give the identification based on that discrepancy.Â  
The jury found Platt guilty of armed robbery and possession of a weapon during a crime of violence.Â  The trial court sentenced Platt to concurrent twenty-year terms in prison.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œIn criminal cases, the appellate court sits to review errors of law only.â€ Â State v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 5, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001).Â  A trial courtâ€™s decision to admit an eyewitnessâ€™s identification is discretionary and will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of that discretion or the commission of prejudicial legal error.Â  State v. Brown, 356 S.C. 496, 502, 589 S.E.2d 781, 784 (Ct. App. 2003).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Platt argues the trial court should have suppressed Ryanâ€™s identification because it was unduly suggestive and unreliable.Â  While we agree the show-up procedure was unduly suggestive, we find the trial court did not abuse its discretion by concluding the identification was reliable under the totality of the circumstances.Â  
To determine whether an out-of-court identification is admissible, South Carolina employs the two-prong inquiry developed by the United States Supreme Court in Neil v. Biggers,Â  409 U.S. 188, 199-201 (1972).Â  The first prong considers whether the identification process was unduly suggestive.Â  State v. Brown, 356 S.C. 496, 503, 589 S.E.2d 781, 784 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  If the identification procedure is deemed suggestive, we then consider the second prong of the analysis: whether a substantial likelihood of irreparable misidentification occurred.Â  State v. Moore, 343 S.C. 282, 287, 540 S.E.2d 445, 447-48 (2000).Â  â€œAlthough one-on-one show ups have been sharply criticized, and are inherently suggestive, the identification need not be excluded as long as under the circumstances the identification was reliableâ€ despite the suggestive procedure.Â  Id. at 287, 540 S.E.2d at 448 (finding show-up procedure unduly suggestive where witness was brought to a location where two individuals wearing similar clothing to that described by the witness were surrounded by uniformed police).Â  Therefore, the overarching inquiry is whether under the totality of circumstances a substantial likelihood of irreparable misidentification exists.Â  Id.Â  
The trial court found the show-up procedure employed by police in this case was unduly suggestive, and the State does not appeal from that ruling.Â  Thus, our only inquiry is whether, under the totality of the circumstances, the identification was reliable and the opportunity for misidentification was slight.Â  The factors to be considered in evaluating the likelihood of misidentification include the opportunity of the witness to view the criminal at the time of the crime, the witnessâ€™s degree of attention, the accuracy of the witnessâ€™s prior description of the criminal, the level of certainty displayed by the witness at the confrontation, and the length of time between the crime and the confrontation.Â  State v. Blassingame, 338 S.C. 240, 252, 525 S.E.2d 535, 541 (Ct. App. 1999) (citations omitted).Â  
Applying these factors to the present case, we find Ryanâ€™s identification testimony reliable.Â  Ryan had the opportunity to observe his assailant on two occasions:Â  once under the fluorescent lights of the service station when the assailant was ten feet away, and once in the well-lit area around Jimmyâ€™s driveway when the assailant was an armâ€™s length away.Â  As for the degree of Ryanâ€™s attention, he testified that he was in fear for his life because Platt had a gun pointed at him.Â  â€œ[A] person in fear of his life presumably has a more acute degree of attention to his surroundings than a mere passerby.â€ State v. Johnson, 318 S.C. 372, 375, 458 S.E.2d 49, 51 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  Furthermore, Ryan was absolutely certain of his identification, which occurred the same evening of the robbery and within a short distance from the scene of the crime.Â  Although Ryan failed to mention the assailantâ€™s braids to the police, his description was otherwise remarkably accurate.Â  The discrepancy regarding Plattâ€™s hair is not enough to overturn the trial courtâ€™s ruling regarding reliability.Â  See State v. Mansfield, 343 S.C. 66, 79-80, 538 S.E.2d 257, 264 (Ct. App. 2000) (finding witnessâ€™s description of defendant accurate as a whole despite witnessâ€™s memory that the defendant had an Afro and wore boots when actually the defendantâ€™s hair was in plaits and he wore tennis shoes).
Viewing the totality of the circumstances, we find no error in the admission of Ryanâ€™s identification.Â  Accordingly, Plattâ€™s convictions are
AFFIRMED. 
HEARN, C.J., and GOOLSBY and STILWELL, JJ., concur

R. Markley Dennis, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Per curiam:Â  Ishama M. Nelson appeals his conviction for armed robbery, contending the trial judge erred in not allowing Nelsonâ€™s counsel to argue in closing that â€œ[t]his defendantâ€™s life is at stake.â€Â  We affirm.[1]
Facts
Nelson and Franklin Wright, armed with handguns, robbed an Exxon station in Goose Creek on February 23, 2003.Â  Wright pled guilty to the lesser offense of strong-armed robbery in consideration for testifying against Nelson.Â  
During his closing argument, Nelsonâ€™s counsel began the statement â€œThis defendantâ€™s life--.â€Â  The State immediately objected, contending Nelsonâ€™s counsel was â€œcommenting on sentencing.â€Â  The trial judge cautioned Nelsonâ€™s counsel but allowed him to proceed.Â  Nelsonâ€™s counsel then stated, â€œThis defendantâ€™s life is at stake.â€Â  The trial judge immediately ruled the argument was improper.Â  Counsel for Nelson stated â€œAll right.Â  All right.â€Â  The judge instructed the jury to disregard the statement. Â Â 
Nelson was found guilty of armed robbery and sentenced to imprisonment for eighteen years. 
Standard of Review
In criminal cases, the appellate court sits to review errors of law only. Â State v. Baccus, 367 S.C. 41, 625 S.E.2d 216 (2006); State v. Wood, 362 S.C. 520, 608 S.E.2d 435 (Ct. App. 2004); State v. Mattison, 352 S.C. 577, 575 S.E.2d 852 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  On appeal, we are limited to determining whether the trial judge abused his discretion. Â State v. Reed, 332 S.C. 35, 503 S.E.2d 747 (1998); State v. Walker, 366 S.C. 643, 623 S.E.2d 122 (Ct. App. 2005); State v. Bowie, 360 S.C. 210, 600 S.E.2d 112 (Ct. App. 2004). Â In order for an error of law to warrant reversal, the error must result in prejudice to the appellant. Â State v. Patterson, 367 S.C. 219, 625 S.E.2d 239 (Ct. App. 2006); see State v. Beck, 342 S.C. 129, 536 S.E.2d 679 (2000); State v. Wyatt, 317 S.C. 370, 453 S.E.2d 890 (1995).
Discussion
Nelson argues his statement was entirely proper because it served to impress upon the jurors the gravity of their decision.Â  This argument was not raised to and ruled on by the trial judge and is not preserved for our review.Â  State v. Williams, 303 S.C. 410, 401 S.E.2d 168 (1991) (issues not raised to and ruled on by the trial judge are not preserved for appeal); State v. Newton, 274 S.C. 287, 262 S.E.2d 906 (1980) (questions neither presented to nor passed upon by the trial judge are waived and should not be considered by the appellate court for the first time on appeal). Â The record of the case shows that Nelsonâ€™s counsel only argued sentencing, and the State objected on that the ground.Â  The trial judge sustained the Stateâ€™s objection. 
Even if Nelsonâ€™s contention were preserved for appellate review, it fails on the merits.Â  The trial judge is vested with broad discretion in dealing with the scope of closing arguments, and ordinarily the judgeâ€™s rulings on such matters will not be disturbed. Â State v. Patterson, 324 S.C. 5, 482 S.E.2d 760 (1997).Â  The jury is concerned only with determining guilt, and a closing argument about sentencing and punishment is improper. Â State v. Dildine, 306 S.C. 198, 410 S.E.2d 597 (Ct. App. 1991).Â  Accordingly, the trial judge did not abuse his discretion in controlling the defendantâ€™s closing argument. 
Though we find no abuse of discretion in the trial judgeâ€™s ruling, such an error would have been harmless.Â  Nelsonâ€™s counsel conveyed the gravity of the juryâ€™s task in the remainder of his closing argument:Â  â€œWhat you do here today is important to the justice system, to all of the participants involved.Â  What you do today helps determine how our justice system works.â€
Accordingly, Nelsonâ€™s conviction is affirmed.
ANDERSON, KITTREDGE, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
        v.
        Michael M. Walker, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenwood County
Wyatt T. Saunders, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-125
Submitted March 1, 2007 â€“ Filed March 15, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Appellate Defender Katherine H. Hudgins, of Columbia, for Appellant.Â  
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Assistant Attorney General Shawn L. Reeves, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Jerry W. Peace, of Greenwood, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Michael M. Walker appeals his convictions of two counts of assault of a high and aggravated nature, two counts of pointing and presenting a firearm, and one count of possession of a handgun by a person convicted of a violent crime.Â  We affirm.[1] 
FACTS
Walker dated Danny Brownâ€™s sister.Â  When Brown learned of a physical altercation between his sister and Walker, Brown and his cousin, Christopher McKinney, drove around searching for Walker.Â  When they found Walker walking down the road, Brown exited the car and approached him.Â  Walker pulled a handgun on Brown and fired it.Â  Brown ran. Â Walker then approached the car, banged the gun on the car window, opened the car door, and fired the gun into the car. Â 
At a pre-trial hearing, Walker moved to relieve his counsel and proceed pro se.Â  At a second pre-trial hearing, Walker reaffirmed his wish to represent himself. Â The solicitor informed the trial judge that Walker had represented himself in a prior criminal trial.Â  The judge asked Walker if he heard the explanation of the dangers of self-representation the judge made to another defendant that morning.Â  Walker acknowledged he listened to the explanation.Â  Walker then explained he wanted the trial to proceed because he had already been incarcerated for almost a year.Â  The judge generally cautioned Walker about representing himself.Â  Walker reiterated his demand to represent himself. Â Trial commenced the following week.Â  Walkerâ€™s appeal raises three issues.Â  
DISCUSSION
I.Â  Self-Representation
Walker argues the trial judge erred in permitting him to proceed pro se without obtaining a valid waiver of the right to counsel.Â  We disagree.
â€œIt is well-established that an accused may waive the right to counsel and proceed pro se.â€Â  State v. Brewer, 328 S.C. 117, 119, 492 S.E.2d 97, 98 (1997).Â  To establish a valid waiver of counsel, the defendant must be adequately warned of the dangers of self-representation.Â  Faretta v. California, 422 U.S. 806, 835 (1975).Â  â€œIn the absence of a specific inquiry by the trial judge addressing the disadvantages of proceeding pro se, this Court will look to the record to determine whether petitioner had sufficient background or was apprised of his rights by some other source.â€Â  Bridwell v. State, 306 S.C. 518, 519, 413 S.E.2d 30, 31 (1992).Â  The ultimate test is not the trial judgeâ€™s advice, but the defendantâ€™s understanding.Â  Brewer, 328 S.C. at 119, 492 S.E.2d at 98.
In this case, the record reflects Walker was emphatic about representing himself.Â  Furthermore, he acknowledged listening to the trial judge explain the dangers of self-representation to another defendant.Â  Walker also had an understanding of the legal system and his legal rights due to his self-representation in a previous criminal trial.Â  Finally, the trial judge addressed the danger of self-representation in a general sense.Â  Upon a review of the record, we find Walkerâ€™s waiver of counsel was knowing and voluntary and although the trial judge did not specifically address the disadvantages of self-representation directly to Walker, Walker made a valid waiver.Â  
II.Â  Error Preservation
Walkerâ€™s remaining issues on appeal are not preserved for appellate review.Â  Walker argues the trial judge erred in not directing a verdict on the charge of possession of a handgun by a person convicted of a crime of violence.Â  Walker failed to move for a directed verdict on this issue at trial.Â  Walker also argues the trial judge erred in instructing the jury that the burden of proving self-defense is on the defendant.Â  Walker failed to object to the erroneous instruction.Â  Issues may not be raised for the first time on appeal but must be raised to and ruled upon by the trial court to be preserved for appellate review.Â  State v. Rogers, 361 S.C. 178, 183, 603 S.E.2d 910, 912-13 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., GOOLSBY and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Ethel Grant and Betty Grant Williams, Respondents,
        v.
        Oliver Seabrook, Sr.; Josephine Seabrook; Oliver Seabrook, Jr.; Harriett Seabrook; and Celia Seabrook, if living, and if deceased, their heirs at law, next of kin and distributees; also and all persons claiming under or through them; also the heirs at law, next of kin and distributees of Angenell Moultrie, and any and all persons unknown, claiming any right, title, estate or interest in or lien upon the real property described in the complaint therein, being designated as John Doe and Richard Roe, including any heirs, distributees, or any unknown defendants who may now be deceased, and including all minors, persons in the Armed Forces, persons non compos mentos, and all other persons under any disability who might have, or claim to have, any right, title or interest in or lien upon the real property described in the complaint designated as class Mary Roe, Defendants,
        of whom the heirs of Oliver Seabrook, Sr., are, Appellants.
        
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
Â Curtis L. Coltrane, Special Circuit Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-126
Submitted March 1, 2007 â€“ Filed March 21, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        George H. Oâ€™Kelley, Jr., of Beaufort, Â for Appellants.
        Horace Anderson Jones, Jr., of Rock Hill, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  This is an action in equity to quiet and confirm title[1] in the respondents Ethel Grant[2] and Betty Grant Williams to three parcels of land in Beaufort County and for a partition of that land (hereafter â€œsubject propertyâ€).Â  The heirs of Oliver Seabrook, Sr., appeal. Â They contend the trial judge erroneously found a 1974 action to clear title voided a prior 1974 deed into Oliver Seabrook.Â  The respondents filed no brief.[3]Â  We affirm.[4]
March Seabrook, Jr., and his second wife had one child, Janie Bolden Seabrook Ackerman.Â  He and his first wife, however, had seven children, among them being Oliver Seabrook, Ethel Seabrook Grant, and Florence Seabrook Shadrick.[5] Â By a deed dated August 13, 1974, and recorded on August 26, 1974, Ethel Seabrook Grant and Florence Seabrook Shadrick conveyed their interest in the subject property to their brother, Oliver Seabrook, for a nominal consideration.
Some months later, the circuit court entered an order in an action brought by Janie Bolden Seabrook Ackerman against the heirs and distributees of March Seabrook.[6]Â  This order, which is dated December 18, 1974, partitioned certain property, which the trial judgeâ€™s order describes as â€œproperty of the heirs of March Seabrook,â€ between and among Janie Bolden Seabrook Ackerman and March Seabrookâ€™s other heirs, with each receiving separate tracts. Â The order, which no one apparently appealed, found title to the property at issue in the Ackerman action was vested in the following individuals: Florence Shadrick, Ethel Grant, Oliver Seabrook, and the children of Cecelia Seabrook Moultrie, James Moultrie, Angenell Moultrie, Sara Moultrie, and Martha Moultrie. Â Nowhere in the order is there any mention of a deed by which Oliver Seabrookâ€™s sisters conveyed to him their interests in the subject property.
Here, the trial judge viewed the principal issue before him to be the effect of the judgment in the Ackerman action, a judgment filed after the date of the quit claim deed by which Florence Shadrick and Ethel Grant conveyed their interests in the subject property to their brother.Â  The two sisters would have no interest in the subject property if the judgment entered in the Ackerman case did not void Oliver Seabrookâ€™s previously recorded deed; however, the trial judge viewed the judgment, and not the deed, as controlling.
The trial judge reached this conclusion because he was not â€œable to reconstruct the events surrounding the family membersâ€™ actions from 1974â€ and because the judgment entered in the Ackerman case bound all parties and settled their interests in the subject property.[7]
The Seabrook heirs make no contention that the judgment rendered in the 1974 quiet title action is not regular on its face.Â  Rather, they contend that judgment did not void the earlier deed that conveyed to Seabrook the interests of his two sisters because the court lacked jurisdiction over one of the parties, namely, Oliver Seabrook.[8]
When a court of competent jurisdiction renders a judgment, as did the one here, that appears regular on its face, there is a presumption that the court has jurisdiction of both the subject matter of the action and of the parties and that the court acquired its jurisdiction regularly and exercised its jurisdiction lawfully.[9]Â  â€œThe presumptions in favor of the regularity and validity of a judgment become stronger with the lapse of years.â€[10]Â  These presumptions apply â€œwhenever a judgment is involved in the trial of another case.â€[11]Â  To overcome these presumptions, the party who attacks the judgment must offer â€œaffirmative proof to the contraryâ€;[12] and this proof must establish â€œthe invalidity of the judgment by competent and convincing proof.â€[13]
Here, more than thirty-two years have come and gone since the court entered the judgment at issue in the 1974 quiet title action.[14]Â  Although the Seabrook heirs argue that â€œthere is no evidence that Oliver Seabrook was actually served in the 1974 quiet title action,â€ they put forward no evidence that he was not so served, either personally or by publication.Â  They simply point to the transcript of testimony that does not show Seabrook â€œin attendance at the 197[4] hearing[]â€ and that shows nothing being said about the quit claim deed by either of the two sisters who did attend the hearing and who both testified.
But whether Seabrook actually attended the hearing or not (as opposed to his testifying) is a matter we can only guess at, as is the matter concerning why the two sisters did not testify about the quit claim deed they had executed months before.Â  Regarding whether Seabrook was personally served with the summons and complaint in the quiet title action, even the Seabrook heirs acknowledge in their brief that â€œ[i]t is not clear if [he] was personally served.â€Â  Suffice it to say, they did not carry their burden of proving the court, in 1974, lacked jurisdiction of both the subject matter and of the parties; therefore, the 1974 judgment, and not the 1974 deed, controls.
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and GOOLSBY and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  Bryan v. Freeman, 253 S.C. 50, 52, 168 S.E.2d 793, 793 (1969).
[2] Â Ethel Grant is now deceased, having died in 2004.
[3] Â Their failure to file a brief allows us, if we want, to reverse the judgment below. Â See Rule 208(a)(4), SCACR; Turner v. Santee Cement Carriers, Inc., 277 S.C. 91, 96, 282 S.E.2d 858, 860 (1981); Robinson v. Hassiotis, 364 S.C. 92, 93 n.2, 610 S.E.2d 858, 859 n.2 (Ct. App. 2005).
[4] Â We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[5] Â Oliver Seabrook and Florence Shadrick are also deceased, having died in 1981 and 1998, respectively.
[6] Â The transcript in that case shows Florence Shadrick and Ethel Grant participated in the hearings.Â  Although named as a party to that action, the record before us does not show whether Oliver Seabrook participated.Â  It also does not show whether he was served.
[7]Â  The trial judge also pointed to another action also filed by Ackerman.Â  That action, which Ackerman commenced in 1989 against H.B. Attaway, Jr., and Dorothy L. Attaway, alleged Ackerman and the heirs of March Seabrook, Sr., had an interest in property claimed by the Attaways.Â  A consent order, dated December 21, 1990, ended the action and expressly recognized that Ethel Grant, Florence Seabrook, and Oliver Seabrook each held an interest in the Attaway property.Â  Like the other action brought by Ackerman, there was no mention of a deed to Oliver Seabrook from his sisters.Â  Moreover, the courtâ€™s order sets out the heirsâ€™ respective interests in that action, as the trial judge in this case observed, â€œas if no such deed was ever executed.â€Â  Larry Seabrook, Oliver Seabrookâ€™s son, testified, however, that his father died in 1981.Â  He also denied ever being served in the second Ackerman action.Â  The file therein contained the final order and an affidavit of publication, but no order of publication; who was served with what and how cannot now be determined. Â The trial judge, however, found he did not need to resolve the factual dispute regarding whether Larry Seabrook was ever served in the second Ackerman action because he found Oliver Seabrook and his heirs were bound by the judgment in the first action and without reference to the deed.
[8]Â  See Turner v. Malone, 24 S.C. 398, 401-02 (1885) (â€œ[J]udicial proceedings are void, when the court, in which they are taken, is acting without jurisdiction . . . . If the jurisdictional defect appears in the record itself . . . the judgment may be disregarded as a nullity whenever and wherever it is encountered, in any proceeding direct or collateral . . . .â€).
[9]Â  Gregoire v. Byrd, 338 S.C. 489, 494, 527 S.E.2d 361, 364 (Ct. App. 2000); 46 Am. Jur. 2d Judgments Â§ 34, at 408 (2006); 50 C.J.S. Judgments Â§ 520, at 73 (1997).
[10]Â  46 Am. Jur. 2d Judgments Â§ 32, at 407.
[11] Â Id.
[12] Â Id. Â§ 33, at 408.
[13] Â 50 C.J.S. Judgments Â§ 520, at 73.
[14] Â The caption in that action, as revealed by the transcript of the testimony, includes Oliver Seabrook.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
        v.
        Titonton Belfort, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Aiken County
Â Reginald I. Lloyd, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-127
Submitted February 1, 2007 â€“ Filed March 23, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Assistant Appellate Defender Eleanor Duffy Cleary, South Carolina Commission of Appellate Defense, of Â Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Sr., Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., Office of the Attorney General, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Barbara R. Morgan, of Aiken, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: A jury found Titonton Belfort guilty and sentenced him to nine years imprisonment for trafficking cocaine.Â  Belfort contends the trial judge should have appointed an interpreter pursuant to Section 17-1-50 (2003) of the South Carolina Code.Â  
FACTS
Belfort is a native of Haiti and speaks Creole.Â  He immigrated to the United States in 1981 and has never received formal education in Haiti or in the United States.Â  A grand jury in Aiken County indicted Belfort for trafficking cocaine.Â  Subsequently, a jury found Belfort guilty.Â  Pursuant to Anders v. California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967), counsel for Belfort attached to the final brief a petition to be relieved as counsel, stating she reviewed the record and concluded the appeal was without legal merit sufficient to warrant a new trial.Â  After a thorough review of the record, we ordered the parties to brief whether the circuit court erred in failing to comply with Section 17-1-50 (2003) of the South Carolina Code and whether this issue was preserved for appeal.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Belfort argues the trial judge failed to conform to section 17-1-50.Â  Section 17-1-50(B)(1) provides:

  Notwithstanding any other provision of law, whenever a party, witness, or victim in a criminal legal proceeding does not sufficiently understand or speak the English language to comprehend the proceeding or to testify, the court must appoint a certified or otherwise qualified interpreter to interpret the proceedings to the party or victim or to interpret the testimony of the witness.

We do not address the issue of whether the trial judge fulfilled the obligations of this section because the issue is not preserved for our review. 
â€œIt is axiomatic that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€Â  Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998).Â  It is uncontested that defense trial counsel did not raise the issue of whether the trial court was required to order an interpreter.[1] 
Nonetheless, Belfort argues that under State v. Blair, 275 S.C. 529, 273 S.E.2d 536 (1981), we can adjudicate this issue even though it is not preserved.Â  However, counselâ€™s reliance on Blair is misplaced.Â  
In Blair, the South Carolina Supreme Court addressed the issue of whether a defendantâ€™s failure to request a competency hearing, when the defendantâ€™s sanity was a crucial issue throughout the trial, constituted a waiver.Â  Id. at 532, 273 S.E.2d at 537.Â  Our Supreme Court concluded defendantâ€™s failure to request a hearing did not constitute a waiver because of the United States Supreme Courtâ€™s decision in Pate v. Robinson, 383 U.S. 375 (1966).Â  Id. Â Â Â Â Â Â 
In Pate, the accused did not demand a sanity hearing, even though the hearing was provided by Illinois law.[2]Â  Pate, 383 U.S. at 376, 385.Â  The U.S. Supreme Court concluded that because defense counsel placed the accusedâ€™s sanity in issue throughout the proceedings, there was no waiver.Â  Id. at 384.
In the present case during the trial defense counsel did not place in issue Belfortâ€™s ability to speak and comprehend English.Â  When the trial judge asked why Belfort had not been provided an interpreter, defense counsel replied, â€œYour Honor, when Iâ€™ve had my meetings with [Belfort], heâ€™s understood my talks with him.Â  I asked him if he needed an interpreter and he [said no].â€Â  Therefore, Blair and Pate do not support the proposition that a failure to raise the issue of the appointment of an interpreter need not be preserved for our review.
We are aware other jurisdictions do not require this issue to be preserved for appellate review.[3]Â  However, we are not prepared to overrule the long-standing rule that only preserved issues are appropriate adjudication. 
CONCLUSION
Accordingly, the circuit courtâ€™s decision is 
AFFIRMED.[4]
BEATTY, SHORT, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] Belfort states in his brief, â€œCounsel did not make a motion for the appointment of a Haitian Creole interpreter for [Belfort].â€Â  (Appellantâ€™s Br. 9).
[2] Under Illinois law, if the court is put on notice of facts which raise a bona fide doubt regarding a defendantâ€™s sanity, it becomes the duty of the court to determine if a defendant is competent to stand trial.Â  People v. Robinson, 22 Ill.2d 162, 167, 174 N.E.2d 820, 822 (1961). 
[3] See e.g., Garcia v. State, 149 S.W.3d 135, 143-45 (Tex. Crim. App. 2004) (If the trial court is aware that the defendant does not speak or understand English, defendant need not preserve by objection the trial courtâ€™s failure to appoint an interpreter.); Duroff v. Commonwealth, 192 Ky. 31, 34, 232 S.W. 47, 49 (1921) (The trial court is vested with a broad discretion in the matter of calling an interpreter. However, it is the duty of the court to call an interpreter when witnesses are unable to understand and speak English; yet, when they can understand and speak the English language reasonably well, it is not necessary to call an interpreter.); but see Luna v. Black, 772 F.2d 448, 451 (8th Cir. 1985) (holding the district court has wide discretion in determining whether an interpreter is needed); Fairbanks v. Cowan, 551 F.2d 97, 99 (6th Cir. 1977) (rulings on appointment qualifications of interpreter need to be objected to in order to preserve that issue for review).
[4] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

Submitted March 1, 2007 â€“ Filed March 23, 2007

PER CURIAM:Â  Attorney John William Ray appeals the circuit courtâ€™s imposition of Rule 11, SCRCP, sanctions against him and his client, BB&T of South Carolina.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
This case requires a rather lengthy discussion of the facts in order to provide the backdrop for the imposition of sanctions against Ray and his client, BB&T.Â  Ray has exclusively practiced in the areas of collection and bankruptcy work since 1990, and he has represented BB&T in these actions since 1994.Â  While representing BB&T, Ray developed the practice of attaching verified statements of account (VSA) to his proposed default orders, which he had signed himself.Â  Beginning in early 2000, issues arose relating to Rayâ€™s practice of signing the VSAs.Â  At that time, the chief administrative judge of the thirteenth circuit instructed all the circuitâ€™s judges to deny Rayâ€™s default judgment requests if Ray personally signed the VSAs.Â  After denying the second of Rayâ€™s signed VSAs, the circuit court also imposed prospective sanctions against Ray under Rule 11, SCRCP, in the event he filed another self-signed VSA.Â  On appeal, this court affirmed, finding the issues unpreserved.Â  The supreme court reversed, finding the issue preserved and holding Ray as agent of BB&T and custodian of the files, could sign the VSAs himself.Â  The supreme court also removed the proactive sanctions against Ray because the sanctions were imposed based upon a misapplication of the law by the circuit court.[2]
Evidently, the tension between Ray and the judges of the thirteenth circuit continued as further disagreements arose regarding Rayâ€™s handling of default actions on behalf of BB&T.Â  In early 2005, the circuit court began a dialogue with Ray concerning his current practice of submitting proposed default judgment orders.Â  In these proposed orders, Ray requested an award of attorneyâ€™s fees but failed to provide his legal basisâ€”the contractual or statutory authorityâ€”that entitled him to such an award.Â  In April 2005, Ray filed a proposed order (first Kerns order)[3] requesting attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  The circuit court denied the proposed order, finding Ray failed to provide in the proposed order any contractual or statutory authority authorizing an award of attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Immediately after denying the Kerns order, the circuit court sent Ray a letter, explaining that:

  [F]or the Court to award attorneyâ€™s fees, there must be a provision regarding entitlement in the contract.Â  You have ignored the requirement and persisted to submit inappropriate proposed orders.Â  If you continue to submit proposed orders of default awarding attorneyâ€™s fees without sufficient proof of entitlement, sanctions will be imposed.

Ray responded in a letter in which he admitted the contract submitted with the Kerns complaint did not contain an attorneyâ€™s fees provision.Â  Ray explained, however, that attorneyâ€™s fees provisions are so common in this type of case that the circuit court could take judicial notice that he was entitled to fees.Â  Ray relied on Rule 8(d), SCRCP, to support this position, asserting that when a defendant is in default all allegations are deemed admitted, and with â€œdeemed admission,â€ submission of â€œfurther evidence of fees would be cumulative to those admissions and simply not needed.â€Â  Lastly, Ray stated that fees are â€œredundantlyâ€ addressed by statute, and therefore, he was entitled to them; however, the letter did not reference any statutory authority for the fees.
In reply to Rayâ€™s letter, all five judges of the thirteenth circuit signed a letter to Ray, once again explaining the requirements for obtaining default judgments.Â  The letter read:

  It is the position of the Court of the Thirteenth Judicial Circuit that you produce the specific contractual provision that entitles you to attorneyâ€™s fees in all debt collection actions in which you seek attorneyâ€™s fees. Absent existence of such documentation . . . you must submit specific statutory authority proving your entitlement.Â  It is black letter law in South Carolina that attorneyâ€™s fees in a contract action are not recoverable absent a contractual provision or specific statutory authority.Â  Your signature on both the complaint and the default motion papers acts as certification of the veracity of the allegations.Â  Continuing to file documents seeking attorneyâ€™s fees without the proper authority or proof to receive them is improper and interferes with the orderly administration of the Court.Â  If you continue in this misleading practice, the Court will take appropriate action.

Shortly after receipt of this letter, Ray filed a notice of appeal of the denial of his proposed Kerns order.Â  However, that same day, and without notice to the circuit court, Ray filed a second Kerns order.Â  This second Kerns order was identical to the first Kerns order in every aspect except it did not contain an award of attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  The circuit court, unaware the first Kerns order was under appeal, signed the second Kerns order.[4] Â 
In June of 2005, the circuit court sent Ray a third letter directing him to refrain from submitting two different orders in a caseâ€”one with a request for attorneyâ€™s fees but no contractual or statutory authority, and one without a request for fees.Â  In late August and early September, Ray submitted two proposed default judgment orders in the cases of BB&T v. Milton Baldwin and BB&T v. Rachel Lamont, neither of which contained a request for attorneyâ€™s fees (Baldwin and Lamont orders).Â  The circuit court signed and filed both orders.Â  
Simultaneous to the filing of the Lamont order, the circuit court sent a fourth letter to Ray requesting him to remove attorneyâ€™s fees language from the proposed orders he had sent to the court where in fact he had not made a request for attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Thereafter, in late September, Ray filed a third proposed Kerns default order to the circuit court, in which he again requested attorneyâ€™s fees, notwithstanding the previously signed and filed second Kerns order.Â  That same day, Ray also filed successive orders in the Baldwin and Lamont cases, in which he requested attorneyâ€™s fees, again notwithstanding the previously signed and filed default orders in both those matters. Â 
In October, the circuit court sent Ray a letter and rule to show cause asking him to explain, among other things, his submission of the successive orders in Kerns, Baldwin, and Lamont, and to set a hearing for sanctions under Rule 11, SCRCP.Â  After the hearing, at which Ray was present, the circuit court found Ray lacked good faith reasons to file the successive proposed orders, and that Ray interfered with the orderly administration of the court.Â  Therefore, the circuit court imposed Rule11 sanctions against Ray in the amount of $2,422, and against BB&T in the amount of $1,000.Â  Ray filed a Rule 59(e) motion, which the court denied.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
A trial judgeâ€™s ruling on Rule 11, SCRCP, sanctions will not be disturbed absent a clear abuse of discretion.Â  Russell v. Wachovia Bank, N.A., 370 S.C. 5, 19, 633 S.E.2d 722, 729 (2006); Culbertson v. Clemens, 322 S.C. 20, 24, 471 S.E.2d 163, 165 (1996). Â â€œAn abuse of discretion may be found where the trial judgeâ€™s conclusion had no reasonable factual support, resulted in prejudice to the rights of appellant, and therefore amounted to an error of law.â€Â  Id.Â Â Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.
Ray first argues the circuit court improperly sanctioned him under Rule 11, SCRCP, because his actions did not warrant sanctions.Â  Also, throughout his brief to this court, Ray argues the circuit court improperly raised the sanctions issue sua sponte. Â We disagree.
Rule 11, SCRCP, reads in pertinent part:

  The signature of an attorney or party constitutes a certificate by him that he has read the pleading, motion or other paper; that to the best of his knowledge, information and belief there is good ground to support it; and that it is not interposed for delay . . . If a pleading, motion, or other paper is signed in violation of this Rule, the court, upon motion or upon its own initiative, may impose upon the person who signed it, a represented party, or both, an appropriate sanction, which may include an order to pay to the other party or parties the amount of the reasonable expenses incurred because of the filing of the pleading, motion or other paper, including a reasonable attorneyâ€™s fee.

(emphasis added).Â  Rule 11, SCRCP, explicitly provides the circuit court with authority to impose appropriate sanctions for violations of the rule â€œupon its own initiative.â€Â  Therefore, Rayâ€™s contention is without merit.
Turning to the sanction itself, the circuit court repeatedly cautioned and admonished Ray to include any contractual or statutory authority to support his request for fees in the proposed default orders.Â  Ray refused to do so.Â  Instead, Ray adopted the practice of submitting two proposed default orders to the circuit court for approval.Â  Under this practice, one proposed default order would not contain a request for attorneyâ€™s fees, and as a result, it would be signed by the circuit court.Â  Thereafter, Ray would submit another proposed default order in the same matter to the circuit court, but this time he would request feesâ€”but fail to attach or include the contractual or statutory authority for his requestâ€”even though the circuit court had already signed and filed an order in the matter.[5]Â  Moreover, Ray continued in this practice even after explicit instructions from the circuit court directing him to discontinue doing so.Â  
As a result of this conduct, the circuit court chose, in its broad discretion, to sanction Ray under Rule 11, SCRCP, for his submission of successive proposed default orders in Kerns, Baldwin, and Lamont because he had no â€œgood faith grounds or reasons to support them,â€ and that Rayâ€™s actions continue â€œto interfere with the orderly administration of the court.â€Â  There is sufficient evidence in the record to support these factual findings.Â  Therefore, the circuit court did not abuse its discretion in finding Rayâ€™s conduct warranted sanctions under Rule 11, SCRCP.
II.
Ray next argues service and notice of the rule to show cause were defective, that he was denied due process and equal protection, and that the circuit court lacked personal jurisdiction.Â  We disagree.
Initially, we note Rayâ€™s argument regarding due process and equal protection are not preserved for appellate review because he did not raise the issue until his Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion.Â  See Patterson v. Reid, 318 S.C. 183, 185, 456 S.E.2d 436, 437 (Ct. App. 1995) (â€œA party cannot for the first time raise an issue by way of a Rule 59(e) motion which could have been raised at trial.â€).Â Â  
Additionally, Rayâ€™s appearance before the circuit court negates his arguments regarding service and jurisdiction.Â  See Rule 4(d), SCRCP; South Carolina Dept. of Social Services, on behalf of Roseboro v. Burris, 297 S.C. 537, 539, 377 S.E.2d 578, 579-80 (1989) (holding a voluntary appearance equivalent to proper service, which vests the court with jurisdiction).Â  Accordingly, we find Rayâ€™s arguments without merit. 
III.
Rayâ€™s remaining issues can be summarized as follows: (1) the sanctions are void because of the circuit courtâ€™s intemperance and prejudice against him personally; (2) the circuit court misapplied the law; (3) the circuit court disregarded the record in making its own findings of fact; (4) the sanctions are arbitrary; and (5) Ray had a good faith basis to file the successive motions.Â  We disagree.
On appeal there is a presumption in favor of the correctness of a decree, and the burden of showing error by the circuit court is on the appellant.Â  Snyderâ€™s Auto World, Inc. v. George Coleman Motor Co., Inc., 315 S.C. 183, 186, 434 S.E.2d 310, 312 (Ct. App. 1993); Cook v. Eller, 298 S.C. 395, 398, 380 S.E.2d 853, 855 (Ct. App. 1989).
As we have held, the circuit court was within its discretion in sanctioning Ray for his practice of filing multiple proposed default orders, despite numerous admonitions not to do so.Â  Rayâ€™s arguments fail to carry his burden of establishing reversible error.Â  Moreover, the record does not support the arguments Ray advances to this court. Â Â Â Â Â Â  
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, the circuit courtâ€™s decision to impose sanctions against Ray and BB&T is hereby
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and GOOLSBY and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

[1] Â We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] Â The above facts are taken from BB&T of South Carolina v. Fleming, 360 S.C. 341, 601 S.E.2d 540 (2004). 
[3] Â The order was submitted in an action captioned BB&T Bankcard Corporation v. B.E. Kerns & D.A. Kerns.
[4] Â Ray claims he did not submit the second Kerns order while his appeal from the first Kerns order was pending.Â  However, the record does not support his contention.Â  For example, after receiving the second Kerns order that was signed by the court, Ray sent a letter to this court asking for an extension.Â  This court received his extension request the day after the circuit court mailed the second Kerns order, indicating Ray had in fact filed his appeal of the first Kerns order after he submitted the second Kerns order.Â  Additionally, correspondence between Ray and this court indicates Ray continued to pursue his appeal of the first Kerns order even after receipt of the signed second Kerns order.Â  Over two months elapsed before Ray withdrew his appeal of the first Kerns order.Â  
[5] Â At the hearing, Ray admitted he was aware and familiar with Rules 59 and 60, SCRCP; however, he did not use those post judgment relief procedures to seek his award of attorneyâ€™s fees in Kerns, Baldwin, or Lamont.Â  Rather, he simply filed successive, nearly identical, orders with the court seeking such relief.
