THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Linda Fowler Blanton, (k/n/a Fowler) Respondent,
        v.
        Tracy Gary Blanton, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Cherokee County
Â Georgia V. Anderson, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2007-UP-129
Heard January 10, 2007 â€“ Filed March 23, 2007Â  

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED.


  
    
      
        William G. Rhoden, of Gaffney, for Appellant.Â  
        Grace Gilchrist Knie, of Spartanburg and John S. Nichols, of Columbia, for Respondent. 
      
    
  

WILLIAMS, J.: Tracy Blanton (Husband) appeals the family courtâ€™s valuation of his business.Â  Husband contends the family court erred in valuing the business without evidentiary support and in relying on expert testimony concerning fair market value indicators.Â  Husband also argues the family court erred in its award of expert fees.Â  We affirm in part, reverse in part, and remand.
FACTS
Linda Blanton (Wife) and Husband married on May 28, 1994.Â  Both worked at Timekin until Wife left to study occupational therapy.Â  Husband also left Timekin to teach masonry at a technical institute, and later began his own construction business, Blanton Construction.Â  
Mr. Ben Kochenower testified as Wifeâ€™s expert regarding Blanton Constructionâ€™s value.Â  Kochenower is a Certified Public Accountant with offices in South Carolina.Â  Kochenower used tax returns, financial statements, and depreciation schedules to value Blanton Construction at a low end value of $67,807.Â  Additionally, Kochenower examined sales of forty-seven similar construction companies to calculate the value of Blanton Construction at a high end value of $247,536. Â Kochenower testified $67,807 and $247,536 are an â€œindication of value,â€ and value indicators are typically less than fair market value. 
Kochenower also testified that his hourly rate is $165, and he worked on this case approximately forty to fifty hours.Â  He charged Wife $5,000 for his services, but Wife testified she was not able to pay Kochenowerâ€™s fees.Â  
Like Wife, Husband enlisted an expert to testify regarding the value of Blanton Construction.Â  Husbandâ€™s expert was his accountant, Gail Humphries.Â  Humphries also did not testify regarding fair market value, but assessed the â€œnet worth valueâ€ of the business at $17,208. Humphries examined Blanton Constructionâ€™s assets, liabilities, and credit cards.Â  Additionally, Humphries relied heavily on information provided by Husband in her valuation of Blanton Construction.Â  However, Humphries did not consider Husbandâ€™s personal checking account, which contained $72,686, in her valuation. 
The trial court valued Blanton Construction at $100,000 and awarded Wife $5,000 in expert fees.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In domestic matters, we may find facts based on the preponderance of the evidence, but we are not required to disregard the findings of the family court judge, who was in a better position to evaluate the witnessesâ€™ testimony and credibility.Â  Doe v. Doe, 319 S.C. 151, 155, 459 S.E.2d 892, 894 (Ct. App. 1995).
LAW/ANALYSIS
A. Evidentiary Support
Husband argues the family courtâ€™s valuation of Blanton Construction lacks evidentiary support.Â  We agree.
When valuing marital property, a business should be valued at its fair market value as a going concern.Â  Brandi v. Brandi, 302 S.C. 353, 357, 396 S.E.2d 124, 126 (Ct. App. 1990).Â  â€œ[F]air market value is the amount of money which a purchaser willing but not obligated to buy the property would pay an owner willing but not obligated to sell it, taking into account all uses to which the property is adapted and might in reason be applied.â€Â  Reid v. Reid, 280 S.C. 367, 373, 312 S.E.2d 724, 727 (Ct. App. 1984) (internal quotations omitted).Â  Factors to consider when determining the fair market value include â€œinventory, accounts payable and receivable, and other legitimate assets or liabilities.â€Â  Brandi, 302 S.C. at 357, 396 S.E.2d at 126.Â  
South Carolina Code Section 20-7-474(1) (Supp. 2005) provides that when determining values of property for equitable apportionment, the family court â€œshall make findings of fact from credible evidence . . . .â€Â  
In this case, the family court valued Blanton Construction at $100,000. The family courtâ€™s order merely listed the expertsâ€™ valuations of Blanton Construction.Â  Even though the valuation was within the range provided by the two experts, the family court made no evidentiary findings to support its conclusion as required by section 20-7-474(1). 
We note that neither Wifeâ€™s expert nor Husbandâ€™s expert testified regarding the exact fair market value of Blanton Construction.Â  Kochenowerâ€™s testimony concerned indicators of fair market value.Â  Humphries valued the businessâ€™s net worth at $17,208.Â  The dissent argues Humphriesâ€™ testimony regarding net worth should be accepted.Â  Net worth is obtained by subtracting liabilities from assets.Â  Blackâ€™s law dictionary 1639 (8th ed. 2004).Â  However, a business is to be valued at its fair market value as a going concern.Â  Brandi, 302 S.C. at 357, 396 S.E.2d at 126.Â  
A going concern is a â€œcommercial enterprise actively engaging in business with the expectation of indefinite continuance.â€Â  Blackâ€™s law dictionary 712 (8th ed. 2004).Â  Net worth and going concern differ in that the former does not take into account the ability of a business to continue.Â  Rather, net worth calculates the difference between a businessâ€™s assets and liabilities at a fixed point in time, without taking into account the ability of a business to continue.Â  The two terms are not synonymous.Â  Additionally, we find it hard to accept that a trained CPA, such as Humphries, would mistakenly use a term such as net worth in place of fair market value.Â  We believe the family court, which observed Kochenowerâ€™s and Humphriesâ€™ testimony, is in the best position to resolve this difference.Â  
The issue of Blanton Constructionâ€™s value is remanded to the family court for a determination of the fair market value, and the family court must delineate how that valuation is reached pursuant to section 20-7-474.[1] Accordingly, we reverse and remand for revaluation of the business. Â Â 
B. Expert Testimony
Husband contends the family court erred in admitting expert testimony concerning indicators of fair market value.Â  We disagree.
The admissibility of expert testimony is within the discretion of the trial judge.Â  South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Bacot, 280 S.C. 485, 490, 313 S.E.2d 45, 48 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  Expert testimony, addressed in Rule 702, SCRE, states: â€œ[I]f scientific, technical, or other specialized knowledge will assist the trier of fact to understand the evidence or to determine a fact in issue, a witness qualified as an expert by knowledge, skill, experience, training, or education, may testify thereto in the form of an opinion or otherwise.â€Â  
To determine the value of Blanton Construction, Kochenower examined tax returns, financial statements prepared by Humphries, bank statements, cancelled checks, and personal tax returns.Â  Kochenower also interviewed Humphries and Husband and requested information on closings and contracts with properties that Husband developed and sold.Â  Kochenower testified regarding the factors of fair market value, although he hesitated to testify regarding the exact fair market value of Blanton Construction. 
Kochenowerâ€™s statements regarding fair market value are admissible as expert testimony under Rule 702 because his statements may have assisted the family court judge, as trier of fact, in determining Blanton Constructionâ€™s fair market value.Â  Accordingly, the family court would not be in error if it chose to use the Wifeâ€™s expert testimony in arriving at its own conclusion as to the fair market value.
Nonetheless, Husband argues Wifeâ€™s expert should not be able to testify as to the indicators of value.Â  In other words, Husband argues that because Wifeâ€™s expert was unable to give a fair market value, his testimony should be excluded.Â  If this logic was applied to Husbandâ€™s expert, her testimony would also be excluded because Humphries did not testify as to the ultimate issue of fair market value.[2]Â  We believe Rule 702, SCRE, was implemented to avoid such a scenario.
C. Expert Fees
Husband argues the family court erred in awarding expert fees.Â  We agree.
The family court is authorized to use its discretion when awarding expert fees.Â  Crawford v. Crawford, 301 S.C. 476, 484, 392 S.E.2d 675, 680 (Ct. App. 1990).Â  However, if the family court did not rely on Wifeâ€™s expert, there is no basis to award expert fees.Â  Because the family court did not delineate how it arrived at the value of Blanton Construction, we are unable to determine if the family court actually relied on Wifeâ€™s expert.Â  
Therefore, the family courtâ€™s award of $5,000 in expert fees is reversed and remanded.Â  We note that if on remand the family court does rely on Wifeâ€™s expert in analyzing the fair market value, it may use its discretion to award Wife expert fees.
CONCLUSION
Accordingly, the family courtâ€™s decision is 
AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED.
KITTREDGE, J., concurs. 
HEARN, C.J. (concurring in part and dissenting in part):
I concur in the majorityâ€™s decision to reverse the family courtâ€™s valuation of Blanton Construction at $100,000, and write separately only to express my view that sufficient competent evidence of valuation exists in the record to allow this court to finally resolve the matter.[3]
In appeals from the family court, the appellate court has the authority to find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Wooten v. Wooten, 364 S.C. 532, 540, 615 S.E.2d 98, 102 (2005).Â  Moreover, when an order from the family court is issued without the required factual findings, the appellate court may remand the matter to the trial court or, â€œwhere the record is sufficient, make its own findings of fact in accordance with the preponderance of the evidence.â€Â  Griffith v. Griffith, 332 S.C. 630, 646-47, 506 S.E.2d 526, 535 (Ct. App. 1998) (quoting Holcombe v. Hardee, 304 S.C. 522, 524, 405 S.E.2d 821, 822 (1991)).
In Brandi v. Brandi, 302 S.C. 353, 396 S.E.2d 124 (Ct. App. 1990), our court addressed a situation similar to this matterâ€”the valuation of a marital business in the context of an equitable distribution.Â  In Brandi, the husband argued the family court improperly valued his business.Â  Id. at 356, 396 S.E.2d at 126.Â  Our court agreed and held the family court erred because it failed to value Husbandâ€™s business â€œat its fair market value . . . .â€Â  Id.Â  After so finding, this court explained it had â€œhoped to resolve this matter on the record;â€ however, the record did not contain the evidence necessary to allow such a finding.Â  Therefore, only after finding the record insufficient did our court remand the action to the family court to make the appropriate valuation.Â  Id. 
Here, unlike Brandi, the record on appeal is sufficient for us to make the findings of fact necessary to value Blanton Construction.Â  In the interest of judicial economy, I believe we should undertake the valuation rather than remand to the family court.Â  See, e.g., Buist v. Huggins, 367 S.C. 268, 275, 625 S.E.2d 636, 639 (2006) (deciding to address the merits of an issue in the interest of judicial economy when the trial court had already heard arguments and addressed the issue, and the record on appeal provided sufficient evidence to make a finding of fact); Southern Bell Tel. and Tel. Co. v. Hamm, 360 S.C. 70, 75, 409 S.E.2d 775, 778 (1991) (electing to address an issue on appeal in the interest of judicial economy after both parties had fully briefed the issue).Â  
When valuing marital property for the purposes of equitable distribution, a business should be valued at its fair market value as an ongoing business.Â  RGM v. DEM, 306 S.C. 145, 152, 410 S.E.2d 564, 568 (1991).Â  Moreover, when the goodwill of a business is dependent upon the business ownerâ€™s future earnings, as is the case here, goodwill is too speculative to be included in the marital estate.Â  Casey v. Casey, 293 S.C. 503, 504, 362 S.E.2d 6, 7 (1987); see also Donahue v. Donahue, 299 S.C. 353, 359, 384 S.E.2d 741, 745 (1989) (acknowledging that because goodwill is dependent upon future earnings, it is too speculative to be included in the valuation of a business for equitable distribution purposes).Â  
This case is nearly identical to the situation in Casey.Â Â  In that case, Husband owned a fireworks business and operated it as a sole proprietorship.Â  Casey, 293 S.C. at 504, 362 S.E.2d at 6.Â  At trial, Wifeâ€™s expert testified to the fair market value of the business, including the tangible value of the businessâ€™s assets and goodwill.Â  Id.Â  The family court, in making the equitable distribution, awarded Wife a portion of the businessâ€™s fixed assets and goodwill.Â  Id.Â  The supreme court reversed, holding goodwill was too speculative to be included in the marital estate, and accordingly, that Wife was only entitled to a portion of the tangible assets of Husbandâ€™s business.Â  Id. at 505, 362 S.E.2d at 7.Â  Likewise, in this matter, Wife is only entitled to an equitable distribution of the tangible assets of Blanton Construction, as any goodwill from Husbandâ€™s efforts with the sole proprietorship would be dependent on his future earnings and are too speculative to include in the equitable distribution. 
At trial, both Husband and Wife relied on expert testimony to assist the court in establishing the fair market value of Blanton Construction.Â  Ben Kochenower, Wifeâ€™s expert, relied upon tax returns, financial statements, depreciation schedules, bank statements, cancelled checks, and personal tax returns in his attempt to value Blanton Construction.Â  Additionally, Kochenower examined sales of forty-seven other construction companies to assist in his valuation.Â  He, however, did not use the tangible assets or liabilities of the company in his valuation method.Â  Instead, Kochenower only provided â€œindicators of valueâ€ to the family court, not a fair market value.Â  Husband relied on the expert testimony of Gail Humphries, the accountant for the business who testified directly to the tangible asset value of Blanton Construction.Â  Humphries calculated the tangible asset value at $17,208 after taking into account the companyâ€™s tangible assets less outstanding liabilities.[4]Â  While Humphries used â€œnet worth valueâ€ rather than the magic words â€œfair market value,â€ it is evident from Humphriesâ€™ entire testimony that she placed a fair market value on the business as its tangible assets only.Â  This view of valuation is consistent with the principles espoused in Casey.
Pursuant to my belief that only the tangible asset value of this business is subject to equitable distribution, sufficient evidence exists in the record to value Blanton Construction at $17,208.Â  Accordingly, a remand to the family court is both unnecessary and contrary to the interest of judicial economy.[5]

[1] Additionally, the family court should note that when the goodwill of a business is dependent upon the business ownerâ€™s future earnings, the goodwill is too speculative for inclusion in the valuation of the marital estate.Â  Casey v. Casey, 293 S.C. 503, 504, 362 S.E.2d 6, 7 (1987).
[2] Husband stated in his brief, â€œMrs. Humphries gave no opinion as to the fair market value of Blanton Construction.â€ 
[3] Â Consistent with my view that no remand is warranted, I concur only in the majorityâ€™s decision to reverse the award of expert fees to Wife.
[4] Â In the opinion, the majority notes that â€œHumphries did not consider Husbandâ€™s personal checking account, which contained $72,686 . . .â€ on October 7, 2003.Â  When questioned on cross-examination about this amount, Humphries responded that while this amount was relevant â€œyou would also have to his consider his other debts. . . . Heâ€™s got to pay back the bank.â€Â  Moreover, at oral arguments it was acknowledged that same account contained less than $1,000 at the end of the month.
[5] Â Based on my disposition, I need not address the issue as to whether the family court could properly rely on indicators of fair market value in valuing Blanton Construction.Â  See Whiteside v. Cherokee County Sch. Dist. No. One, 311 S.C. 335, 340, 428 S.E.2d 886, 889 (1993) (stating appellate court need not address remaining issues when resolution of prior issue is dispositive). AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Donald Bruce Clark, and Robert N. Rosen, both of Charleston and Lawrence E. Richter, Jr., of Mt. Pleasant, for Appellant.
        John Graham Altman, III, of Hanahan, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Â Vicky Griffith (Griffith) appeals the family courtâ€™s decision that it lacked jurisdiction to hear her motion asking the court to construe and enforce its final custody order regarding reasonable telephone contact.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Griffith and Bart Altman (Altman) never married, but they have a son, born May 27, 1999.Â  On December 6, 2004, Altman was awarded custody of their son, and the court issued an order providing a visitation schedule. Â Part of the order provided that â€œ[b]oth parents shall have reasonable and at all times private telephone contact with the child . . . .â€Â  
On March 13, 2006, Griffith filed a motion asking the court to define specific times for telephone communication between herself and the child.Â  Griffith also sought attorneyâ€™s fees related to the motion.Â  Griffith submitted affidavits in support of her motion, and Altman submitted an affidavit in response to the motion.Â  
On May 1, 2006, the court held a hearing on Griffithâ€™s motion.Â  After hearing arguments from both sides, the court dismissed the motion due to a lack of subject matter jurisdiction.Â  On June 21, 2006, Griffith timely filed a motion for reconsideration and requested the court alter or amend the judgment pursuant to Rule 59 (e), SCRCP.Â  The court denied the motion.Â  This appeal follows.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Griffith argues the family court erred in refusing to construe and enforce its final order that granted Griffith â€œreasonableâ€ telephone contact with her child.Â  We disagree.
The pivotal issue before this Court is whether the relief Griffith sought in her motion is either a clarification of the Final Order or a modification of the Final Order.Â  In construing or clarifying an ambiguous order, the determinative factor is to ascertain the intent of the judge who wrote the order.Â  Eddins v. Eddins, 304 S.C. 133, 135, 403 S.E.2d 164, 166 (Ct. App. 1991).Â  On the other hand, to modify a final order, the party seeking modification must show a substantial or material change of circumstances.Â  Sharps v. Sharps, 342 S.C. 71, 76, 535 S.E.2d 913, 916 (2000).Â  
Griffith requested that the family court define â€œspecific times for telephone communicationâ€ between the child and the parents. Â Griffith contends the use of the term â€œreasonableâ€ is ambiguous and should be defined by this Court. 
Griffith cites Cannon v. Cannon, 275 S.C. 424, 272 S.E.2d 179 (1980) to support her argument that the Final Order should be construed and specific telephone contact should be defined.Â  In Cannon, the Mrs. Cannon requested an order requiring Mr. Cannon to show cause why he should not be held in contempt for refusing to allow her to obtain items of personal property as provided for in the Final Order.Â  After a contempt hearing, the family court found there was â€œsome basis for misunderstanding between the parties due to the fact that the previous order was not explicit enough to be enforced.â€Â  Consequently, the family court refused to find Mr. Cannon in contempt; instead it specified which items of personal property belonged to each party.Â  Cannon, at 425, 272 S.E.2d at 179.Â  
The case at bar differs from Cannon in both its procedural posture and in the effect that defining the alleged ambiguous term will have on the parties.Â  Unlike Cannon, Griffith has not brought an action in contempt, rather she has brought a motion to define the term â€œreasonable.â€Â  Also, whereas the ruling in Cannon specified the items referred to in the Final Order, Griffithâ€™s request would put a burden on each parent by mandating that each rearrange their lives around a precise telephone visitation schedule.
In this case, the family court correctly found that imposing a telephone contact schedule would have a significant impact on the childâ€™s daily routine as well as each parentâ€™s daily routine.Â  This impact would constitute a material change. Â Griffith did not file a motion for modification of the Final Order and did not allege a substantial or material change in circumstances.Â  Therefore, we find no error in the family courtâ€™s dismissal of Griffithâ€™s action.Â  In light of our disposition of the case, it is not necessary to address Griffithâ€™s remaining issues.Â  Futch v. McAllister Towing of Georgetown, Inc., 335 S.C. 598, 613, 518, S.E.2d 591, 598 (1999) (appellate court need not address remaining issues when disposition of prior issue is dispositive).Â  
Accordingly, the family courtâ€™s decision is
AFFIRMED.[1]
HUFF, BEATTY, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
State of South Carolina, Respondent,
v.
Elizabeth Rosette Bush, Defendant,
        David Nicholson d/b/a All Out Bonding Company signing as agent for:Â  Palmetto Surety Corporation, Surety,
        of whom All Out Bonding Company is the Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
D. Garrison Hill, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-131
Submitted March 1, 2007 â€“ Filed March 28, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Robert T. Williams, Sr., of Lexington, for Appellant.Â  
Shawn L. Reeves, of Columbia, for Respondent. Â 
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  All Out Bail Bonding, Inc. (All Out) appeals the partial estreatment of Elizabeth Rosette Bushâ€™s bond.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
In December 2004, All Out provided a $15,000 bond for Bush necessitated by her indictment for second-degree arson.Â  When Bush failed to comply with several provisions of her bond, including failing to report to the bonding company and failing to notify All Out of a change in her address and telephone number, All Out moved the court to be relieved from its obligation.Â  That motion was denied.Â  However, a special condition was added to Bushâ€™s bond that she was â€œnot to leave the residence without first notifying Bonding Company.â€Â  In January of 2006, All Out moved again to be relieved of its obligation based on Bushâ€™s arrest on new charges and a violation of the special condition of her bond.Â  The request was denied.Â  Bush had failed to appear in court in May of 2005 and March of 2006.Â  Finally, Bush failed to appear again in April 2006, and a bench warrant was issued for her arrest.Â  At a hearing on June 9, 2006, the court determined that $2,500 of Bushâ€™s bond should be estreated.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The issue of whether a bond forfeiture should be remitted, and if so, to what extent, is vested in the discretion of the trial judge.  Â State v. Workman, 274 S.C. 341, 343, 263 S.E.2d 865, 866 (1980) (citing State v. Holloway, 262 S.C. 552, 557, 206 S.E.2d 822, 824 (1974)).Â  â€œRelief from bond forfeiture is in the discretion of the trial court.â€Â  State v. Boatwright, 310 S.C. 281, 283, 423 S.E.2d 139, 141 (1992).Â  An abuse of discretion occurs when the courtâ€™s ruling is based on an error of law or when based on factual conclusions is without evidentiary support.Â  State v. McClinton, 369 S.C. 167, 170, 631 S.E.2d 895, 896 (2006).Â  An abuse of discretion also occurs when the ruling reveals no discretion was exercised.Â  Id.

    LAW/ANALYSIS
All Out argues that the court abused its discretion in estreating Bushâ€™s bond when the company had asked to be relieved of its surety obligation on two prior occasions.Â  We disagree.Â  
In considering whether to grant relief from a bond forfeiture the court must consider (1) the purpose of the bond, (2) the nature and willfulness of the default, and (3) any prejudice or additional expense resulting to the State. Â See Workman, 274 S.C. at 343, 263 S.E.2d at 866.Â  In this case, the court determined that All Out had attempted to keep track of Bush and that her compliance with the bond conditions had been problematic from the beginning.Â  Nevertheless, the court concluded the purpose of the bond, to insure Bushâ€™s appearance, was not met, the State was prejudiced by Bushâ€™s failure to appear, and her violations seemed to be willful.Â  Based on its consideration of these factors, the court decided to estreat the bond in the amount of $2,500.Â  The record shows that the court considered the requisite factors and exercised its discretion to estreat the bond, not in the full amount, but in the partial amount of $2,500.Â  We discern no abuse.Â  
 AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., GOOLSBY, and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

[1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Patricia E. King and Robbie King Jones, as representatives ofÂ  W.R. King and Ellen King,
Appellants,
v.
Margie B. King and Robbie Patricia Ione King, Individually and as co-personal representatives of the Estate of Christopher C. King, deceased and Nelson M. King, Chester Telephone Company and Branch Banking & Trust (BB&T),
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Chester County
Â Kenneth G. Goode, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-132
Submitted March 1, 2007 â€“ Filed March 28, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Willie F. Bradley, Jr, of Columbia, for Appellants.
Raymon E. Lark, Jr. and Timothy F. Rogers, of Columbia, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Â Patricia E. King and Robbie King Jones (Appellants), as representatives of W.R. King and Ellen King (parents), appeal the circuit courtâ€™s order dismissing this action for failure to prosecute and allowing Margie B. King and Robbie Patricia Ione King (Respondents) to proceed with their counterclaims.Â  We affirm.[1]  
FACTS
In November 1998, Appellants filed this action for enforcement of a loan and ownership/operation of Kingâ€™s Funeral Home.[2]Â  Respondents filed a timely answer. Â In November 1999, Appellants filed an amended complaint in which they dismissed one defendant.Â  Respondents again filed a timely answer in which they asserted additional counterclaims.Â  
In April 2001, Appellants served a â€œRequest for Leave to Amendâ€ and a â€œFirst Amended Complaintâ€ on Respondents.Â  Appellants sought to add plaintiffs and defendants and new causes of action.Â  However, the â€œFirst Amended Complaintâ€ was neither authorized by an order of the circuit court nor by consent of the parties. 
By letter dated May 3, 2001, Judge Alford informed Appellants they may amend their complaint to add new parties.Â  Judge Alford instructed Appellants to â€œprepare a proposed order in that regard and send a copy of the prepared order to opposing counsel at the same time you send it to me.â€Â  
In May 2001, Respondents deposed two of Appellantsâ€™ witnesses: Robbie King Jones and Moses Caldwell.Â  During the deposition of Robbie King Jones, a disagreement arose regarding Respondentsâ€™ questioning and Appellantsâ€™ counselâ€™s interjections.Â  Respondents terminated the deposition â€œuntil [they] could come before [the court] and get a ruling onâ€ the objections and actions by Appellants.Â  After Robbie King Jonesâ€™ deposition ended, counsel for Appellants informed Caldwell he did not have to appear at his deposition.Â  Although he initially refused to go to the deposition, the sheriff persuaded Caldwell to obey the subpoena and appear at his deposition.Â  However, Caldwell refused to answer any of Respondentsâ€™ questions because Appellantsâ€™ counsel was not present.Â  Thereafter, Respondents filed a motion for contempt, a motion to compel removal of a lis pendens, motion for protective order against Appellantsâ€™ counselâ€™s speaking objections during depositions, a motion for stay, and a motion to compel answers to discovery requests.Â  
On June 1, 2001, the circuit court held a hearing to consider motions and matters of concern between the parties.Â  During this hearing, the circuit court acknowledged both parties have at some point failed to cooperate with the discovery process.[3]Â  The circuit court then informed both parties discovery must be completed forthwith in order to get the case ready for trial.Â  The circuit court also warned both parties that â€œif there are any further impediments to the discovery, any other problems with it, I will consider sanctions.â€Â  The circuit court further noted the possible sanctions include dismissing the case altogether for failure to cooperate.Â  
Also during the hearing, the circuit court held Appellants had ten days to provide supplemental answers to Respondentsâ€™ interrogatories.Â  In addition, the circuit court instructed Appellants to provide documents and answers to Respondentsâ€™ discovery requests in compliance with the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure.Â  Thereafter, the circuit court stated directly to Appellants: â€œGive [the Respondents] the information they want; quit stonewalling.Â  You run the risk of getting this whole lawsuit thrown out.â€Â  
As to the lis pendens on Respondentsâ€™ property, the circuit court held the Respondents needed to provide information proving the property was not related to the law suit and then Appellants would have to remove the lis pendens.Â  
The circuit court considered also Appellantsâ€™ motion to amend the complaint.Â  The court agreed the complaint should be amended to include all interested parties; however, the court also informed Appellants they â€œshouldnâ€™t serve an amended complaint until you get permission from the court to do that . . . file it and then you can file an amended complaint and serve people.â€Â  The court then instructed Appellants to â€œprepare [the court] another orderâ€ to add the interested parties.Â  The court also stated that â€œif [Appellants have] already submitted . . . an order, Iâ€™ll sign it.â€Â  
After the circuit court heard and ruled on all motions, the court asked Respondents to prepare an order extending the time for discovery to one hundred and twenty days to allow the new parties time to complete discovery.Â  The court also told Appellants: â€œIâ€™m going to allow you to amend to add the parties you want to add . . . and allow you to file an amended complaint.â€Â  Then, before the hearing ended, Respondents asked whether they could â€œdraft a proposed order and it wonâ€™t be next week or the next week . . .;â€ the court answered affirmatively.Â  
After the June 2001 hearing, neither party filed any order.Â  A status conference was scheduled for March 18, 2004.Â  The status conference was apparently cancelled when Appellants were late.Â  
In April 2004, Respondents filed a motion to dismiss for failure to prosecute.Â  After a hearing, the circuit court held dismissal was warranted based on Appellantsâ€™ â€œwillful violation and total disregard of [court orders]â€ and repeated failure to litigate this matter.Â  The court also held Respondentsâ€™ counterclaims remained viable.Â  Appellants filed a motion to reconsider, which the circuit court denied.Â  This appeal followed.Â Â Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œWhether an action should be dismissed for failure to prosecute is left to the discretion of the [circuit court], and [its] decision will not be disturbed, except upon a clear showing of an abuse of discretion.â€Â  McComas v. Ross, 368 S.C. 59, 62, 626 S.E.2d 902, 904 (Ct. App. 2006). Â An abuse of discretion occurs (1) when the courtâ€™s ruling is based upon an error of law, such as application of the wrong legal principle; (2) when based upon factual conclusions, the ruling is without evidentiary support; (3) when the court is vested with discretion, but the ruling reveals no discretion was exercised; or (4) when the ruling does not fall within the range of permissible decisions applicable in a particular case.Â  Ex parte: Capital U-Drive-It, Inc., 369 S.C. 1, 5, 630 S.E.2d 464, 467 (2006).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.  Dismissal for Failure to Prosecute 
Appellants contend the circuit court erred in dismissing their case for failure to prosecute.Â  We disagree.Â  
Rule 41(b), SCRCP, provides that a defendant may move for dismissal of an action for failure of the plaintiff to prosecute or to comply with the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure or any order of court.Â  â€œThe plaintiff has the burden of prosecuting his action, and the trial court may properly dismiss an action for plaintiffâ€™s unreasonable neglect in proceeding with his cause.â€Â  Don Shevey & Spires, Inc. v. Am. Motors Realty Corp., 279 S.C. 58, 60, 301 S.E.2d 757, 758 (1983). Â â€œSuch power is deemed to be necessarily vested in trial courts [in order for them] to manage their own affairs so as to achieve orderly and expeditious disposition of cases.â€Â 
Crestwood Golf Club, Inc. v. Potter, 328 S.C. 201, 212, 493 S.E.2d 826, 832 (1997) (citation omitted).
Generally, the dismissal of actions for failure to prosecute is appropriate in cases where: (1) the dismissals are imposed to maintain the orderly disposition of cases in the face of repeated warnings or multiple opportunities to proceed with trial; and (2) only then upon a finding of unreasonable neglect.Â  McComas v. Ross, 368 S.C. 59, 62, 626 S.E.2d 902, 904 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  In addition,
â€œthere must be some showing of indifference to the rights of the defendant.â€Â  Id. at 63, 626 S.E.2d at 904.
As this court noted in McComas, the Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals requires trial courts to consider four factors before dismissing a case for failure to prosecute: 1) the plaintiffâ€™s degree of personal responsibility; (2) the amount of prejudice caused the defendant; (3) the presence of a drawn out history of deliberately proceeding in a dilatory fashion; and (4) the effectiveness of sanctions less drastic than dismissal.â€ Â Id. at 63, 626 S.E.2d at 904-05 (citing Hillig v. Commâ€™r of Internal Revenue, 916 F.2d 171, 174 (4th Cir. 1990)).
In this case, we find the circuit court did not commit an abuse of discretion in dismissing Appellantsâ€™ case for failure to prosecute because the dismissal came after repeated warnings, Appellants had infinite opportunities to move the case forward, Appellants unreasonably neglected to proceed with their cause of action, and Appellants demonstrated an indifference to Respondentsâ€™ rights.Â  The circuit court instructed Appellants numerous times to comply with discovery and file an amended complaint.Â  The circuit court also warned Appellants that further illegitimate delays in discovery could lead to dismissal.Â  The record fails to demonstrate that Appellants complied with all of the courtâ€™s requests.[4]Â  In addition, the only reason this case has not moved forward is because Appellants have neglected to file an amended complaint; therefore, Appellants had unlimited opportunities to proceed to trial.Â  Further, from the June 2001 hearing through Respondentsâ€™ filing of the motion to dismiss, Appellants failed to demonstrate that they took any steps toward moving this case forward, and thereby demonstrated an extreme indifference to the rights of the Respondents.Â  Based on these facts, we cannot find the circuit court abused its discretion in dismissing this case. Â 
Appellants assert the trial court erred in relying on Georganne Apparel, Inc. v. Todd, 303 S.C. 87, 399 S.E.2d 16 (Ct. App. 1990).Â  We disagree.
Georganne Apparel involved a long history of delays by the plaintiffs.Â  In September 1986 the circuit court, at the plaintiffâ€™s request, struck the case from the trial roster pursuant to Rule 40(c)(3), SCRCP. Â The case was reinstated a year later at the plaintiffâ€™s request.Â  On February 22, 1988, the plaintiff and the defendant accountants entered into a consent order whereby the plaintiff agreed to limit its claim against the accountants to professional negligence only.Â  On May 16, 1988, the circuit court, upon a motion by the defendant accountants, issued an order precluding the plaintiff from calling its designated accounting expert as a witness because the plaintiff had failed to cooperate with the defendant accountants in setting up a deposition of the expert witness.Â  In an order of May 20, 1988, more than two years after the original complaint, the circuit court granted the plaintiffâ€™s motion to dismiss the case without prejudice pursuant to Rule 41(a)(2), SCRCP, on the conditions that it pay costs to the defendants before refilling and that it limit the refilled action to those causes of action set forth in the current complaint as limited by the consent order.Â  On September 15, 1988, the plaintiff filed a new complaint which named a new defendant and added numerous causes of action, thereby violating the circuit courtâ€™s order.
The circuit court on November 30, 1988, dismissed the case with prejudice.Â  The court found that the plaintiffâ€™s addition of a new defendant and causes of action were in blatant violation of the May 20, 1988, order. Â The court also stated that it was â€œmindful of the history of abuse this case presents.â€Â  The court noted the plaintiff had made representations to the court that were contradicted by an affidavit.Â  The court also found that the defendants were prejudiced by the plaintiffâ€™s actions.Â  The circuit court concluded:

In sum, Plaintiff's willful and blatant violation of the expressed terms and conditions contained in [the circuit courtâ€™s order] of May 20, 1988, is the final chapter in the history of Plaintiffâ€™s unwillingness to follow the rules and orders of this Court, which activity brings into disrepute our legal system and the rules under which it operates. Accordingly, and mindful of the totality of circumstances, the Court is of the opinion that it should exercise its discretion under Rule 41(a)(2) and (b) to dismiss these actions with prejudice.Â  

Georganne Apparel, 303 S.C. at 92, 399 S.E.2d at 18-19.
This court held the trial court was clearly within its discretionary powers when it granted relief under the terms of Rule 41(a)(2) and (b) and that the relief granted was not too harsh under the totality of the circumstances.Â  Id. at 92, 399 S.E.2d at 19.Â Â  
The facts and procedural history in Georganne Apparel do differ from those in the present case as cases are rarely exactly alike.Â  However, as in Georganne Apparel, this case also involves a â€œwillful and blatant violationâ€ of the courtâ€™s order.Â  The circuit court specifically instructed Appellants to provide an order allowing the amendment of the complaint and to comply with discovery.Â  Appellants failed to comply with these instructions for over two and a half years. Â As this court stated in Georganne Apparel, Â â€œ[t]here is a limit beyond which the court should allow a litigant to consume time of the court and to prolong unnecessarily time, effort, and costs to defending parties.â€Â  Id. at 92, 399 S.E.2d at 19. Â We find no error in the circuit courtâ€™s citation of Georganne Apparel.Â  
Appellants contend the circuit court erred in dismissing the case because any substantial delay in prosecuting the case was caused by identifying the numerous heirs to the estate involved and complicated issues not involved in ordinary litigation.Â  This argument was neither raised to nor ruled on by the trial court.Â  Therefore, it is not preserved for our review.Â  See Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (â€œIt is axiomatic that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€).Â  At the hearing, Appellantsâ€™ only argument against dismissal was their counselâ€™s contention that he believed Respondentsâ€™ counsel was going to prepare the order.Â  Respondentsâ€™ counsel explained that he only volunteered to draft the discovery scheduling order.Â  Earlier in the June 2001 hearing the circuit court had specifically instructed Appellantsâ€™ counsel to draft the order allowing the amendment of Appellantsâ€™ complaint.Â  As this was a matter of judging the credibility of the parties, we defer to the circuit court and find the court did not err in declining to accept Appellantsâ€™ excuse.Â  See Menne v. Keowee Key Property Ownersâ€™ Assâ€™n, Inc., 368 S.C. 557, 567, 629 S.E.2d 690, 696 (Ct. App. 2006) (â€œBecause the appellate court lacks the opportunity for direct observation of the witnesses, it should accord great deference to trial court findings where matters of credibility are involved.â€).
Appellants also argue that public policy favors sanctions be directed toward the individual responsible for violating the court order rather than the innocent parties.Â  Thus, the circuit court should have sanctioned their attorney rather than dismissing their case.Â  This issue was neither raised to nor ruled on by the circuit court.Â  Thus, it is not properly before this court. Â See Wilder Corp., 330 S.C. at 76, 497 S.E.2d at 733 (â€œIt is axiomatic that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€). 
II.  Failure to Dismiss Respondentsâ€™ Counterclaims 
Appellants next assert the circuit court erred in allowing Respondents to proceed with their counterclaims.Â  We disagree.[5]  
On the merits, Rule 41(c), SCRCP, allows the circuit court to dismiss an action, upon a partyâ€™s motion, for the other partyâ€™s failure to prosecute a counterclaim, cross-claim, or third-party claim.Â  Crestwood Golf Club, Inc. v. Potter, 328 S.C. 201, 211, 493 S.E.2d 826, 832 (1997).Â  This courtâ€™s review of the circuit courtâ€™s dismissal or non-dismissal of a counterclaim for failure to prosecute is the same as review of dismissal or non-dismissal of plaintiffâ€™s cause of action. See Rule 41(c) (providing â€œ[t]he provisions of this rule apply to the dismissal of any counterclaim, cross-claim, or third-party claim.â€).Â  Â Â 
We find the circuit court did not commit an abuse of discretion in holding Respondentsâ€™ counterclaims remain viable.Â  In this case, Respondents have admittedly failed to take an assertive role in moving the case forward.Â  Undeniably, Respondents impeded discovery by failing to attend depositions in March 2001.Â  Also, Respondents failed to file a proposed order extending the time for discovery to 120 days as ordered by the court at the June 2001 hearing.Â  However, Respondents differ from Appellants in two respects.Â  First, Respondents did not fail to comply with a direct court order.Â  While the court ordered Respondents to file a proposed order extending discovery, the proposed order was contingent upon Appellantsâ€™ amended complaint as the whole purpose behind the proposed order was to allow new parties time to complete discovery; therefore the discovery order only needed to be filed after Appellantsâ€™ amended complaint.Â  Second, the onus of pushing for trial was on the Appellants and not the Respondents.Â  As this court stated in Don Shevey & Spires, Inc. v. Am. Motors Realty Corp:Â  

The defendants, no less than the plaintiff, had the right . . . to press for trial; but the duty to do so was the plaintiffâ€™s, not theirs. Â While a defendant may bring about an expeditious trial of a case, he has no legal obligation to do so; except to meet such actions as are taken by the plaintiff, he may remain passive

279 S.C. 58, 60, 301 S.E.2d 757, 759 (1983) (quoting Thomas & Howard Co. v. Fowler, 238 S.C. 46, 52, 119 S.E.2d 97, 100 (1961)).Â  Thus, Respondents were within their right to â€œremain passiveâ€ in the intervening years.Â  Id.Â  Therefore, we find the record supports the circuit courtâ€™s holding that Respondents may proceed with their counterclaims.Â  
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, we find the circuit court did not err in dismissing Appellantâ€™s case for failure to prosecute and allowing Respondentsâ€™ counterclaims to remain viable.Â  Accordingly, the circuit court is
AFFIRMED.
HUFF and BEATTY, JJ., and CURETON, A.J., concur.Â  

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] In February 1998, Appellants, as individuals, originally filed this action in federal court.Â  The federal court dismissed the action for lack of personal jurisdiction.Â  
[3] The court noted Respondents failed to appear at various depositions called by Appellants in March 2001, a time when Appellants were not represented by counsel.Â  
[4] The Record on Appeal does not contain evidence that Appellant complied with the circuit courtâ€™s order to provide the documents and information requested by Respondents.Â  Medlock v. One 1985 Jeep Cherokee, 322 S.C. 127, 132, 470 S.E.2d 373, 376 (1996) (the appellant has the burden of presenting a record sufficient to allow the appellate court to make a decision).Â  
[5] We note, despite Respondentsâ€™ contention, this issue is properly preserved.Â  Appellants preserved this issue because they argued Respondentsâ€™ counterclaims should be dismissed in their response to Appellantsâ€™ Motion to Dismiss, and the circuit court ruled upon the issue.Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Bonnie Thompson, Respondent,
v.
        Richard Russell, Irma Ruth Mabry k/n/a Irma Ruth Russell, individually and As Personal Representative of the Estate of Richard Russell, Defendants,
        of whom Irma Ruth Mabry k/n/a Irma Ruth Russell, individually and As Personal Representative of the Estate of Richard Russell is
        Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From York County
S. Jackson Kimball, III, Special Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-133
Submitted March 1, 2007 â€“ Filed March 29, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
LeRoy Pendleton, of Clover, for Appellant.Â  
Daniel Dominic Dâ€™Agostino, of York, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Irma Ruth Russell (Irma) appeals the master in equityâ€™s determination regarding the priority of liens against property in the estate of Richard Russell (Richard).[1]Â  We affirm.[2]
FACTS
Irma and Richard cohabitated in a romantic relationship beginning in 1995.Â  Richard was married to Vivian Russell at the time and did not obtain a divorce from Vivian until November of 2001.Â  In April 2002, Irma and Richardâ€™s relationship ended, and Irma filed suit in family court seeking a division of marital assets alleging that she and Richard had entered into a common law marriage.Â  The order from the family court indicated that while it had personal jurisdiction over the parties, the issue of subject matter jurisdiction was not determined.Â  Nevertheless, the order included a property settlement agreement between the two.Â  The parties acknowledged that Irma had no interest in real property located at 930 St. Paul Church Road in Clover and that money from the sale of property located at 102 Jamestown Circle in Clover would be held in escrow by Richardâ€™s attorney.Â  The agreement further stated that Richard would pay Irma a total of $64,700.00 once the sale of the real estate and automobiles listed in the agreement was complete.Â  The agreement indicated that it was a â€œcomplete contractual resolutionâ€ of the partiesâ€™ claims and would be enforceable â€œas a contract in the event that either party later raised the issue of subject matter jurisdiction as a defense in any enforcement action.â€ (emphasis added). 
In December of 2003, Bonnie Thompson (Thompson) obtained a default judgment against Richard in the York County Circuit Court for $58,197.81.Â  She went through the process of attempting to execute on the judgment, including holding supplemental proceedings to determine Richardâ€™s assets.Â  Richard never cooperated with this process, and eventually, the circuit court ordered the properties at 930 St. Paul Church Road and 102 Jamestown Circle sold to satisfy the judgment.Â  Â 
When the properties were scheduled for sale, Irma sought a determination that she had a superior interest in the properties.Â  Thompson also moved to determine the priority of her judgment lien, and the case came before the master in equity.Â  The master granted summary judgment to Thompson on two grounds.Â  First, he determined the family court order did not create a lien, because the agreement was only in the nature of a contract between the parties.Â  Second, he held the family court had no jurisdiction over the matter.Â  Irma appeals.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Summary judgment is appropriate when there are no genuine issues of material fact and the moving party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law.[3]Â  Rule 56, SCRCP.Â  â€œSummary judgment is not appropriate where further inquiry into the facts of the case is desirable to clarify the application of the law.â€Â  Gadson v. Hembree, 364 S.C. 316, 320, 613 S.E.2d 533, 535 (2005).Â  â€œThe purpose of summary judgment is to expedite disposition of cases which do not require the services of a fact finder.â€Â  George v. Fabri, 345 S.C. 440, 452, 548 S.E.2d 868, 874 (2001).
LAW/ANALYSIS
The master determined that Thompsonâ€™s judgment had priority over any lien asserted by Irma for two reasons, and this court can affirm on either or both grounds.Â  See Iâ€™On, L.L.C. v. Town of Mt. Pleasant, 338 S.C. 406, 420, 526 S.E.2d 716, 723 (2000) (holding the decision to address any additional sustaining grounds is within the discretion of the appellate court).Â  
First, Irma argues that the master failed to consider various rules of civil procedure and statutes in determining the family courtâ€™s order did not create a lien in her favor.Â  We disagree.Â  Irma relies on Rules 54 and 58 of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure for the proposition that any order set forth by the court automatically constitutes a â€œjudgmentâ€ and that such judgment automatically becomes a lien on the debtorâ€™s real property pursuant to Section 15-35-810 of the South Carolina Code.Â  Rule 54 defines a judgment to include â€œany decree or order which dismisses the action as to any party or finally determines the rights of any party.â€Â  Rule 54(a), SCRCP.Â  Rule 58 states â€œthe clerk, unless the court otherwise orders, shall forthwith prepare, sign, and enter the judgment . . . .â€Â  Rule 58, SCRCP.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Section 15-35-810 (Rev. 2005) indicates that â€œfinal judgments and decrees entered in any court of record in this State . . . shall be declared to create a lien . . . .â€
While the law is correctly cited by Irma, the order merely affirms the contractual arrangement between the parties that Richard will pay Irma $64,700.00.Â  It acknowledges the existence of the agreed-upon obligation, but does not go the additional step of concluding that the debt was due and unpaid giving rise to a judgment or lien.Â  Thompson, on the other hand, reduced the debt owed her by Richard to a money judgment.Â  She then went through the process of executing on the unsatisfied judgment.Â  Consequently, under the long-established law in this state, her judgment has priority over any claim Irma may have in the properties.Â  See King v. Fraser, 23 S.C. 543, 565 (1885) (â€œIt is certainly the general rule that a bona fide lien . . . has priority over all debts which are then unsecured . . . .â€) 
Irma also contends that the master lacked subject matter jurisdiction to declare an order of the family court void.Â  We affirm the masterâ€™s determination as an alternative sustaining ground.Â  The record shows that Richard was legally married to Vivian Russell during the great majority of the time he cohabitated with Irma.Â  This impediment would have prevented the parties from establishing a common law marriage during the term of the existing marriage, and their separation soon after the divorce makes proving the existence of a marriage much less likely.Â  See Johns v. Johns, 309 S.C. 199, 201-02, 420 S.E.2d 856, 858 (Ct. App. 1992) (â€œIn South Carolina, . . . [a] relationship illicit at its inception does not ripen into a common law marriage once
the impediment to marriage is removed. Instead, the law [in this State] presumes that the relationship retains its illicit character after removal of the impediment.â€) (internal citations omitted).Â  
Irma could have attempted to show that the partiesâ€™ relationship became marital in nature after Richardâ€™s divorce from Vivian, but there is no evidence in the record before us to support such a determination.Â  See Yarbrough v. Yarbrough, 280 S.C. 546, 551, 314 S.E.2d 16, 19 (Ct. App. 1984) (holding that an agreement to enter a common law marriage after an impediment is removed may be established by the partiesâ€™ conduct).Â  
Where there is no marriage, the family court is without jurisdiction to make determinations regarding property.Â  See Hallums v. Bowens, 318 S.C. 1, 3, 428 S.E.2d 894, 895 (Ct. App. 1993) (â€œThe family courts of this state have jurisdiction to deal with family problems. It has no jurisdiction to settle property disputes between unmarried people.â€).
Furthermore, the parties asked the master to determine the priority of the claims.Â  Irmaâ€™s claim was derived from a family court order.Â  To accomplish his assigned task, the master had to consider the nature and validity of Irmaâ€™s claim.Â  The master did not make a ruling about the division of â€œmaritalâ€ property.Â  Such a ruling is within the province of the family court.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-420(A)(2) (Supp. 2006).Â  The master considered the validity of an order allegedly giving rise to a lien in a dispute over the priority of claims.Â  Such a case clearly falls within the general class of questions the master is empowered to answer. Â See Rule 53, SCRCP (discussing the types of cases the master is empowered to hear). 
 AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., GOOLSBY, and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

[1]  Richard Russell died after the institution of this litigation, and Irma was appointed personal representative of his estate.
[2]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[3]  The master properly treated Irmaâ€™s claim as a motion for summary judgment, because the determination of the priority of the claims would be conclusive of the entire matter.

title: State v. Salgado
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Victor Salgado, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
 Doyet A. Early, III, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-134
Submitted March 1, 2007 â€“ Filed March 29, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Chief Attorney Joseph L. Savitz III, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General Sabrina C. Todd, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Harold W. Gowdy, III, of Spartanburg; for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Victor Salgado was convicted of criminal domestic violence, third or subsequent offense, and sentenced to thirty-three months in prison.[1]Â  He appeals, arguing the trial court erred in allowing the hearsay statements of his wife, who did not testify, into evidence.Â  We affirm.[2]
FACTS
On September 16, 2002, a crying five-year-old girl appeared at the front door of Sergeant Jerry Millwood of the Spartanburg County Sheriffâ€™s Office.Â  Based on comments the child made to him, Sergeant Millwood called 911 to report a possible criminal domestic violence at the house next door.Â  Deputy Tanya Aldridge and Sergeant McKnight responded to the scene.Â  They were met at the door by Salgado, and he denied that his wife, Laura Salgado (the victim), was home.Â  Deputy Aldridge and Sergeant McKnight searched the residence and discovered broken and misplaced furniture, food on the walls, blood on the floor, and broken dishes.Â  The victim was discovered in a rear bedroom with a destroyed doorframe.Â  She had fresh wounds on her head and arm.Â  Sergeant McKnight spoke with the victim at the scene, and she was bleeding, upset, and crying.Â  Although she initially did not answer Sergeant McKnightâ€™s questions, the victim nodded her head affirmatively when Sergeant McKnight asked her whether â€œheâ€ did this to her.Â  Salgado was the only other adult in the house at the time.Â  The victim agreed to give a statement to Deputy Aldridge.Â  Sergeant Millwood assisted with taking pictures of the crime scene. Â Salgado was arrested for criminal domestic violence.Â Â  
By the time of the trial, the victim could not be located.Â  The State introduced the testimony of Sergeant Millwood, Deputy Aldridge, and Sergeant McKnight.Â  Over Salgadoâ€™s objections, Sergeant McKnight was allowed to testify that the victim identified Salgado as her assailant when she was asked whether â€œheâ€ did this to her.Â  Although the victimâ€™s written statement was not introduced, the photographs of the disarray in the house and of the victimâ€™s injuries were introduced at trial.Â  Salgado was convicted of criminal domestic violence, third or greater offense, and sentenced to thirty-three months.Â  He appeals. 
LAW/ANALYSIS
Salgado argues the trial court erred by allowing into evidence the hearsay statement the victim gave to Sergeant McKnight identifying Salgado as her assailant.Â  He asserts that the victimâ€™s statement was not an â€œexcited utterance,â€ as the trial court found, because her answers to Sergeant McKnightâ€™s questions were not â€œspontaneous, but reluctant and the product of reflection.â€Â  We disagree.
Although hearsay is generally not admissible at trial, an â€œexcited utteranceâ€ is an exception to the hearsay rule.Â  Rule 803(2), SCRE.Â  An excited utterance is a â€œstatement relating to a startling event or condition made while the declarant was under the stress of excitement caused by the event or condition.â€Â  Id. Â â€œThe rationale behind the excited utterance exception is that the startling event suspends the declarantâ€™s process of reflective thought, reducing the likelihood of fabrication.â€Â  State v. Sims, 348 S.C. 16, 20, 558 S.E.2d 518, 521 (2002).Â  For a statement to qualify as an excited utterance, three elements must be proven:Â  (1) the statement must relate to a startling event or condition; (2) the statement must have been made while the declarant was under the stress of the excitement; and (3) the stress of the excitement must have been caused by the startling event or condition.Â  Id. at 21, 558 S.E.2d at 521. 
Courts must consider the totality of the circumstances in determining whether a statement falls within the excited utterance exception.Â  Id. at 23, 558 S.E.2d at 522. Â The burden of establishing facts which would qualify a statement as an excited utterance is upon the proponent of the evidence.Â  State v. Davis, 371 S.C. 170, 178-79, 638 S.E.2d 57, 62 (2006).Â  The determination of whether a statement is an excited utterance is a matter within the trial courtâ€™s discretion.Â  State v. Burdette, 335 S.C. 34, 43-44, 515 S.E.2d 525, 530 (1999).
Initially, it is questionable whether this argument is preserved for review.Â  During Sergeant McKnightâ€™s testimony, Salgado objected to the introduction of the victimâ€™s statement as â€œhearsayâ€ in general.Â  After Salgado raised his objection, the State argued that the statement was an excited utterance, the court overruled the objection, and testimony resumed.Â  Although the court clearly found that the statement was an excited utterance, Salgado never argued to the trial court that the victimâ€™s statement was not an excited utterance because her answers were not spontaneous, were reluctant, and were the product of reflection.Â  Thus, the particular argument before us was never raised to the trial court and is not preserved for appellate review.Â  State v. Hicks, 330 S.C. 207, 216, 499 S.E.2d 209, 214 (1998) (holding that matters not raised to or ruled upon by the trial court are not preserved for appellate review).Â  
In any event, we find no merit to Salgadoâ€™s argument.Â  Testimony introduced at trial indicated that the house was in complete disarray, both Salgado and the victim were in the house together, and the victim was scared and bleeding from fresh wounds.Â  Suffering head and arm wounds during the destruction of the house was certainly a startling event.Â  The victim appeared to be still suffering from the stress of the event when the officers arrived at the scene.Â  Although the victim initially hesitated to speak with the officers, nothing in the record indicates that the initial hesitation was of such a duration as to allow the victim time for reflection.Â  Further, the testimony from both Deputy Aldridge and Sergeant McKnight was that the victim was still visibly upset and suffering from her wounds while still under the watchful eye of Salgado.Â  Considering the totality of the circumstances, we find the trial court did not abuse its discretion in finding the victimâ€™s act of nodding her head affirmatively when asked whether Salgado injured her was an excited utterance.[3]Â  
CONCLUSION
Based on the totality of the circumstances, we find the trial court did not err in finding the victimâ€™s statement was an excited utterance.Â  Accordingly, Salgadoâ€™s conviction and sentence are
 AFFIRMED.
 HUFF, BEATTY, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  The South Carolina Department of Corrections website indicates that Salgado is not currently incarcerated.Â  
[2]Â  Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[3]Â  Although not raised by Salgado, the State correctly points out that nonverbal communication can qualify as an excited utterance.Â  State v. McHoney, 344 S.C. 85, 94-95, 544 S.E.2d 30, 34-35 (2001) (noting that a victimâ€™s nonverbal responses about her attacker as elicted by a nurse were excited utterances).

text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Everette H. Newman, Trustee 17, Respondent,
v.
AFC Enterprises, Inc., Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Anderson County
Â J. C. Buddy Nicholson, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-135
Submitted February 1, 2007 â€“ Filed March 29, 2007Â Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
James A. Blair, III, and Reid T. Sherard, of Greenville, for Appellant.
Michael D. Glenn, of Anderson, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Everette H. Newman, Trustee 17, (Landlord) brought suit against AFC Enterprises, Inc. (Tenant), alleging Tenant breached a commercial lease.Â  After the parties filed cross-motions for summary judgment, the court granted Landlordâ€™s motion for summary judgment.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
W. Paschal Cochran owned the premises, the subject of this appeal, which included a building suitable for use as a restaurant.Â  Cochran entered into a lease (the original lease) with Franchise Enterprises for the use of the premises.Â  The original lease was scheduled to commence in 1986 with a â€œprimary termâ€ of fifteen years, ending in 2001.Â  The original lease granted to Franchise the right â€œto extend the primary term of the Lease for five (5) five-year periods.â€ Paragraph 28 of the original lease contains an option to terminate:

[The tenant] shall have the right, at any time during any extension of the primary term to terminate this lease by paying to [the landlord] in cash the sum equal to twenty-five percent (25%) of the unpaid portion of the rent to be paid for the remainder of such extension period. 

After the premises and lease changed hands, the lessee entered bankruptcy. Subsequently, Alta Cochran, the new landlord, and Pine Tree Foods, the new tenant, entered into an agreement to restate the terms of the lease.Â  Â Â The restated lease adopted the same terms and conditions as the original lease, with certain modifications. The restated lease contained the following provision:

Amendment to Lease: The Lease is hereby amended as follows:
The Landlord, Alta G. Cochran, has agreed to furnish $60,000.00 in cash to do certain repairs at this location. . . . There will be no increase in rent.
In consideration of Landlord paying $60,000 for improvements Lessee agrees to extend the current primary lease for an additional five years with expiration of current primary lease being extended from March 31, 2001 to March 31, 2006.Â  

The restated lease, therefore, included the options to extend the lease and the right to terminate the lease found in the original lease.Â  The rent in the lease remained, as set by the original lease, at $62,490.60 per year plus 6% of sales over one million dollars per year. 
Landlord acquired the premises, subject to the restated lease, in 1996.Â  Â Â In 1998, Tenant and Landlord executed an estoppel letter to clarify the terms of the restated lease.Â  The estoppel letter stated:

The term of the Lease commenced on March 31, 1986, full rent is now accruing thereunder and the term of the Lease expires on March 31, 2006, subject to the exercise of any extension option[s] set forth in the Lease, which options shall remain effective upon the transfer or assignment of Tenantâ€™s interest in the Lease.Â  Tenant has four (4) consecutive unexercised options to extend the term of the Lease of five (5) years each on the same terms and conditions of the Lease. 

The estoppel letter concluded:Â  â€œIn the event of a conflict between the terms of the Lease and this letter, the terms of this letter shall control.Â  Landlord understands that this letter shall serve as a material inducement for you to assume the obligations of Tenant under the Lease.â€ 
On October 25, 2001, Tenant notified Landlord that Tenant was terminating the lease, effective October 31, 2001, pursuant to the terms of Paragraph 28 of the original lease. Tenant tendered a check in the amount of $69,000.04, which it stated represented twenty-five percent of the remainder of the rent for the term of the lease. The letter indicated Tenant sought to terminate the â€œcurrent lease term (April 1, 1986 through the expiration date of March 31, 2006).â€Â  
Landlord rejected the proffered termination of the lease by letter dated November 16, 2001.Â  In the letter, Landlord indicated the termination was not accepted and Tenantâ€™s check was being deposited as November rent with credit given â€œagainst the $69,000.04 deposit for each monthly rental due as it accrues.â€Â  Landlord concluded:Â  â€œIt is my opinion that this lease is valid through March 31, 2006.â€Â  
Landlord brought the underlying action, seeking damages resulting from Tenantâ€™s alleged breach of the lease. Tenant filed an answer asserting several defenses, including payment, waiver and estoppel, and the Statute of Frauds. The parties filed cross-motions for summary judgment. 
The court granted summary judgment in favor of Landlord, finding Tenant breached the terms of the lease.Â  The court found the restated lease did not operate as one of the options to extend, but instead created a new primary lease term which continued until March 31, 2006.Â  The court found Tenant could not terminate the lease pursuant to Paragraph 28 of the original lease because no option to extend the primary lease term had been exercised.Â  The court also found Tenantâ€™s defense of waiver and estoppel failed.Â  Accordingly, the court found in favor of Landlord on the issue of liability and ordered a non-jury trial on the issue of damages.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In reviewing the grant of a summary judgment motion, this court applies the same standard which governs the trial court: summary judgment is proper when there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  Rule 56(c), SCRCP; Baughman v. Am. Tel. & Tel. Co., 306 S.C. 101, 115, 410 S.E.2d 537, 545 (1991).Â  In determining whether any triable issues of fact exist, the evidence and all inferences which can be reasonably drawn from the evidence must be viewed in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.Â  Strother v. Lexington County Rec. Commâ€™n, 332 S.C. 54, 61, 504 S.E.2d 117, 121 (1998).Â  On appeal from an order granting summary judgment, the appellate court will review all ambiguities, conclusions, and inferences arising in and from the evidence in a light most favorable to the nonmoving party below.Â  Osborne v. Adams, 346 S.C. 4, 7, 550 S.E.2d 319, 321 (2001). 
LAW/ANALYSIS
Tenant maintains the trial court erred in finding it breached the lease by terminating it.Â  Tenant contends there was a genuine issue of material fact regarding the exercise of an extension and whether there was a meeting of the minds between Tenant and Landlord in the restatement of the lease and the execution of the estoppel letter.Â  Finally, Tenant asserts the court erred in improperly applying waiver and estoppel to the instant action.Â  We disagree.
I.  Right to Terminate
Tenant argues it had the right to terminate because the restated lease operated as an extension of the original lease and Paragraph 28 of the original lease allows for termination in the manner exercised.Â  We disagree.
In contract interpretation, courts are required is to ascertain and give legal effect to the intentions of the parties as expressed in the language of the contract.Â  United Dominion Realty Trust, Inc. v. Wal-Mart Stores, Inc., 307 S.C. 102, 105, 413 S.E.2d 866, 868 (Ct. App. 1992).Â  If a contractâ€™s language is clear and capable of legal construction, this courtâ€™s function is to interpret its lawful meaning and the intent of the parties as found in the agreement.Â  Smith-Cooper v. Cooper, 344 S.C. 289, 295, 543 S.E.2d 271, 274 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  
Where the language used in a contract is clear and unambiguous, the court will be guided by the language of the contract, taken and understood in its plain, ordinary, and popular sense, to determine the contractâ€™s force and effect.Â  See Warner v. Weader, 280 S.C. 81, 83, 311 S.E.2d 78, 79 (1983); Sphere Drake Ins. Co. v. Litchfield, 313 S.C. 471, 473, 438 S.E.2d 275, 277 (Ct. App. 1993).Â  Courts do not have the authority to make new contracts for parties.Â  Rather, their duty is limited to interpretation of the contract made by parties, â€œregardless of its wisdom or folly, apparent unreasonableness, or failure to guard their rights carefully.â€ Â C.A.N. Enters., Inc. v. S.C. Health & Human Servs. Fin. Commâ€™n, 296 S.C. 373, 378, 373 S.E.2d 584, 587 (1988).Â  
Tenant acknowledges that the original lease was terminated with the bankruptcy of a prior tenant, thus necessitating the restated lease.Â  The provisions of the restated lease make it clear that the terms of the original lease were being adopted by the parties, with the exception of any modified terms.Â  The principle provision modified was the term of the lease.Â  The parties to the restated lease negotiated a new term for the primary lease in consideration of the landlord paying up to $60,000.00 towards improvements on the premises. Based on the clear and unambiguous language of the restated lease, the parties intended the primary lease term to run until March 31, 2006, and not March 31, 2001, as stated in the original lease. 
In addition, the estoppel letter drafted by Tenant and signed by Landlord states the term of the lease commenced on March 31, 1986 and ends March 31, 2006.Â  If the parties to the estoppel letter intended the restated lease provision to be construed as an extension of the original lease, they could have stated such in the estoppel letter.Â  However, the plain, unambiguous wording of the estoppel letter indicates the primary term of the lease expires on March 31, 2006.Â  Finally, the estoppel letter takes the additional step of clarifying:Â  â€œIn the event of a conflict between the terms of the Lease and this letter, the terms of this letter shall control.â€Â  Â Â 
Accordingly, based on the clear and unambiguous terms of the restated lease and the estoppel letter, Tenant was not operating â€œduring any extension of the primary term,â€ but was instead still operating during the primary term of the lease.Â  Therefore, under Paragraph 28, there is no genuine issue of fact whether Tenant had the right to terminate the lease prior to March 31, 2006.Â  As a result, the court properly determined Tenant breached the lease by failing to fully perform the provisions of the lease through March 31, 2006.
II.  Payment, Waiver, and Estoppel
Tenant contends the trial court erred in failing to find the payment of the termination fee constituted full payment under the terms of the restated lease.Â  In the alternative, Tenant maintains Landlord either waived his right to claim a breach of the lease or was estopped from claiming a breach of the lease.Â  We disagree.
First, as discussed above, Tenant had no right to terminate the lease prior to March 31, 2006.Â  Therefore, Tenantâ€™s payment of one fourth of the remaining rents was not a proper termination of the lease and could not be considered full payment pursuant to the provisions of the restated lease and estoppel letter.
Next, Tenant asserts Landlord waived his right to claim a breach of the lease by accepting Tenantâ€™s payment of the termination fee and depositing Tenantâ€™s check in the amount of $69,000.04.Â  Waiver is defined as â€œa voluntary and intentional abandonment or relinquishment of a known right.â€Â  Janasik v. Fairway Oaks Villas Horiz. Prop. Regime, 307 S.C. 339, 344, 415 S.E.2d 384, 387 (1992).
â€œGenerally, the party claiming waiver must show that the party against whom waiver is asserted possessed, at the time, actual or constructive knowledge of his rights or of all the material facts upon which they depended.â€Â  Id.Â  Whether a party is barred by estoppel or waiver can only be determined in light of the circumstances of each case.Â  See Id.
In the instant case, Tenant sent a letter to Landlord stating the $69,000.04 check was â€œfor payment of the termination fee.â€ Landlord responded by letter:

I am this day depositing the $69,000.04 check which you sent me by letter . . . Not as recognition of it as a termination fee but in order to meet my November and future mortgage payments.Â  I do this because you have not sent the November rent payment and have indicated future monthly rental checks will not be forthcoming.
It is still my opinion that this lease is valid through March 31, 2006.Â  Until we can clear up this issue, I will give you credit against the $69,000.04 deposit for each monthly rental due as it accrues.Â  When you start back the monthly rentals, I will forward the remaining balance to you. 

Tenant again wrote Landlord indicating it sought to terminate the lease, it would no longer be operating under the lease, and that the lease was â€œof no further force and effect.â€Â  Tenant did not seek a return of the money held by Landlord.Â  It simply reiterated its belief that the lease was properly terminated.
Under the circumstances of this case, we find no genuine issue of material fact indicating Landlord waived his right to claim Tenant breached the lease.Â  Landlord clearly indicated the reason he deposited the check was because he believed the lease to still be in effect and required monthly rental payments by Tenant.Â  All actions taken by Landlord, including the letter and the subsequent credits for monthly rents against the deposit, provide strong evidence that Landlord did not intend to waive his right to claim a breach of the lease by depositing the money.Â  Accordingly, the trial court properly granted summary judgment to Landlord because the retention of Tenantâ€™s check did not act as a waiver of Landlordâ€™s right to pursue additional damages from Tenant for breach of the lease.
Lastly, Tenant maintains Landlord should be estopped from asserting a breach of the lease based on Landlordâ€™s inaction in clarifying the provisions of the estoppel letter and in failing to immediately return the â€œtermination feeâ€ sent by Tenant.Â  Tenant points to Metromont Materials Corp. v. Pennell, which states:Â  â€œIt is a well recognized principle of equity â€˜that if a party is silent when he should speak, or supine when he should act, he will not afterwards be permitted to either speak when he should be silent, or to act when he failed to do so at the first proper and opportune moment.â€Â  270 S.C. 9, 22, 239 S.E.2d 753, 760 (1977) (citing King v. Ligon, 180 S.C. 224, 235, 185 S.E. 305, 309 (1936)).Â  In addition, this court has explained in great detail:

Under South Carolina law, the essential elements of estoppel are divided between the estopped party and the party claiming estoppel.Â  As to the estopped party, the essential elements are:Â  (1) conduct amounting to a false representation or concealment of material facts, or conduct calculated to convey the impression that the facts are otherwise than, and inconsistent with, the partyâ€™s subsequent assertions; (2) intention or expectation that such conduct be acted upon by the other party; and (3) actual or constructive knowledge of the real facts.Â  As to the party claiming estoppel, the essential elements are:Â  (1) lack of knowledge or the means of acquiring, with reasonable diligence, knowledge of the true facts; (2) reasonable reliance on the other partyâ€™s conduct; and (3) a prejudicial change in position.Â  Unlike waiver, the estopped party need not intend to relinquish or change any existing right for estoppel to arise.Â  The reliance by the party claiming estoppel must be reasonable, and it must proceed in good faith.Â
